questions.text: A pathologist examines a surgically resected pituitary tumour under a microscope. The tumour comprises sheets of monomorphic, round to polygonal cells with central nuclei and sparse to absent reticulin network. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Pituitary adenoma

 

Explanation: 

Pituitary adenoma: 

  • Pituitary adenomas are benign tumors that arise from the pituitary gland and are characterized by sheets of monomorphic, round to polygonal cells with central nuclei and a sparse to absent reticulin network

  • Cellular monomorphism and the absence of a significant reticulin network distinguish pituitary adenomas from normal anterior pituitary parenchyma.
  • ⁠They are well-circumscribed and encapsulated. 
  • ⁠They are the most common type of pituitary tumor and can be classified based on size as follows.

 

Pituitary carcinoma(Option B): Is very rare and have malignant cells showing nuclear pleomorphism along with invasive growth and metastasis.

Schwannoma (Option D): Schwannomas are tumors of Schwann cells found along peripheral nerves. They display spindle-shaped cells in a palisading pattern and stain positive for S-100 protein. They do not arise in the pituitary gland.

 

 

Craniopharyngioma (Option C):
Incorrect – Shows squamous epithelium, calcification, and wet keratin, not monomorphic sheets or reticulin loss.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the cells in the distal tubule and cortical collecting tubule is NOT correct?

choices.text: Principal cells are responsible for sodium reabsorption and potassium secretion.
Type A intercalated cells secrete hydrogen ions and reabsorb bicarbonate
Amiloride and triamterene act as potassium-sparing diuretics by blocking sodium channels in principal cells
Spironolactone and eplerenone increase sodium reabsorption and potassium secretion in principal cells

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Spironolactone and eplerenone increase sodium reabsorption and potassium secretion in principal cells.

Explanation: Spironolactone and eplerenone decrease sodium reabsorption and potassium secretion in principal cells.

Cells of Collecting Duct:

Characteristic

Principal Cells

Intercalated Cells

Main Function

Sodium reabsorption and potassium secretion (Option A)

Acid-base regulation

Proportion

60-70% of cells in collecting tubules and ducts.

30-40% of cells in collecting tubules and ducts.

Types

                                -
  • Type A
  • Type B

Key Processes

Na+ reabsorption via Na+ channels

K+ secretion via K+ channels

Water reabsorption (regulated by ADH).

Type A: (Option B)

  • H+ secretion
  • HCO3- reabsorption

Type B:

  • HCO3- secretion
  • H+ reabsorption

Key Transporters

Na+-K+ ATPase pump in basolateral membrane.

Type A

  • H+-ATPase (apical
  • H+-K+-ATPase (apical)
  • Cl--HCO3- exchanger (basolateral)

Type B:

  • H+-ATPase (basolateral)
  • Pendrin (Cl--HCO3- exchanger, apical)

Hormonal Regulation

Responsive to aldosterone

Not primarily regulated by aldosterone.

Diuretic Targets

Primary targets for potassium-sparing diuretics

Not primary targets for most diuretics.

Specific Diuretics
  • Spironolactone and eplerenone (aldosterone antagonists)
  • Amiloride and triamterene (Na+ channel blockers) (Option C)

Not specifically targeted by common diuretics.

Effect of K+-sparing Diuretics

Decrease Na+ reabsorption and K+ secretion

Minimal direct effect.

questions.text:
A patient with a longstanding history of alcoholism is admitted with jaundice, abdominal distension & weight loss. A liver biopsy done during his previous admission showed the following changes, and suspicion of malignant transformation is raised now. Elevation of which of the following markers will support the differential?


	HepPar-1
	Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP)
	Glypican-3 (GPC3)
	CA 15-3
	Tissue polypeptide antigen
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 1,2 and 3

Explanation :

The following markers will be elevated in case of hepatocellular carcinoma :

  • HepPar-1 (Statement 1)
  • Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) (Statement 2)
  • Glypican-3 (GPC3) (Statement 3)
  • Neurotensin
  • Arginase-1
  • CA-19-9

 

Chronic liver disease with cirrhosis is the major cause of transformation into hepatocellular carcinoma, and some of the common causes are listed below :

  • Alcohol (as given in the above scenario)
  • Chronic hepatitis B & C
  • Metabolic diseases
  • Non-alcoholic steatohepatitis
  • Aflatoxins from Aspergillus

questions.text: A 35-year-old male with a history of asthma presents with symptoms occurring four times a week, occasional nighttime awakenings, and the need for rescue inhaler use three times a week. His post-bronchodilator FEV1 is 72% of the predicted value. According to the asthma classification guidelines, how would you categorize the severity and control of his asthma?
questions.solution:
Severity: FEV1 of 72% falls under moderate asthma (50–79% of predicted).

Control:

  • Daytime symptoms > 2 times per week → partly controlled.
  • Nocturnal symptoms present → partly controlled.
  • Use of rescue inhaler > 2 times per week → partly controlled.

Classification of Asthma Severity

  • Spirometry Assessment:
    • Post-bronchodilator FEV1: Air exhaled in one second after bronchodilator use.
    • FEV1/FVC Ratio: Indicates obstruction if <0.7.
    • Severity Categories:
      • Mild: FEV1 ≥ 80% of predicted (Option A ruled out)
      • Moderate: FEV1 50-79% of predicted (Option B)
      • Severe: FEV1 30-49% of predicted (Option C ruled out)
      • Very Severe: FEV1 < 30% of predicted
    • Classification Systems:
      • ATS/ERS (2004)
      • GOLD (2008)
      • NICE Clinical Guideline 101 (2010)
  • Clinical Assessment:
    • Evaluates patient symptoms, activity limitations, and exacerbation frequency.
    • Provides a comprehensive view of asthma's impact on the individual.

Asthma Control Assessment

Characteristic Feature

Controlled (Option A ruled out)

Partly Controlled (Option B)

Uncontrolled (Options C & D ruled out)

Daytime Symptoms

None

Symptoms > twice/week

Frequent daytime symptoms

Limitations of Activities

None

Any limitations

Significant limitations

Nocturnal Symptoms

None

Any nighttime symptoms

Frequent nighttime symptoms

Need for Rescue Treatment

< twice/week

> twice/week

Frequent use of rescue medication

Lung Function

Normal (PEF or FEV1)

< 80% of predicted/personal best

Significantly reduced lung function

Exacerbations

None

≥ 1 per year

Weekly exacerbations

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman with a copper IUD inserted 9 months ago presents with lower abdominal pain, fever (38.5°C), and no visible IUD strings. She has multiple sexual partners. On exam, she has lower abdominal tenderness. What is the most likely complication?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Pelvic inflammatory disease (PID)

 

Explanation

  • The patient’s symptoms of fever and lower abdominal pain, along with her history of multiple sexual partners, point to the diagnosis of pelvic inflammatory disease, which is a complication of IUD use.

 

Side effects of IUDs:

Side effects of IUDs

Bleeding

 Breakthrough bleeding is common, resolves in 1–3 months. May need iron; persistent cases may require IUD removal.

Pain

The most common removal cause. Managed with analgesics. Resolves in 3 months.

Severe pain → rare perforation.

Pelvic inflammatory disease (Option C)
  • Presents with fever, abdominal pain, and discharge.
  • Treatment involves broad-spectrum antibiotics.
  • IUD removal if no improvement.
  • 3rd generation of IUD is protective against IUD.

Uterine perforation (Option B)
  • Rare complications linked to immediate postpartum insertion or poor technique.
  • 1st generation IUDs are associated with a higher risk of perforation.

Failure of contraception ➜ pregnancy

  • MIRENA has the lowest pregnancy rates. Abortion is legally allowed on request. If threads visible → remove and continue pregnancy with risks explained. If threads not visible → assess uterus. If no complications, IUD can be removed and pregnancy continued with risk of abortion/preterm labor. 

Ectopic pregnancy (Option D)
  • Recognized by lower abdominal pain, dark vaginal bleeding, or amenorrhea.
  • Women at high risk should avoid IUDs.

Expulsion
(Option A)
  • Typically occurs within weeks of insertion or during menstruation.
  • Higher risk in young, nulliparous, postpartum women or using 1st generation IUDs

Migration of IUD
  • Rarely causes intestinal obstruction.
  • Diagnosed via X-ray imaging if suspected.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman with a 12-day history of missed periods and a positive pregnancy test undergoes a procedure to empty her uterus. Identify the instrument used in this early pregnancy management procedure:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Menstrual regulation syringe

Explanation:

The instrument shown above is a menstrual regulation syringe.    

Aspect

Manual Vacuum Aspiration (MVA)
(Option B)

Menstrual Regulation (Option D)

Use

Uterine evacuation up to 12 weeks of pregnancy for medical termination.

Aspiration of endometrial cavity within 14 days of missed period in a woman with a previous normal cycle.

Instrument used

MVA Syringe: Has double pinchable valves

MR Syringe: Has a single pinchable valve

Anesthesia

Local anesthesia

Sedation or paracervical block

Indications

Medical termination of pregnancy, incomplete/missed abortion, molar pregnancy, blighted ovum, endometrial sampling/biopsy.

Missed period, failed abortion, molar pregnancy, ectopic pregnancy exclusion.

Uterine curette (Option A): Commonly used in D&C, a method for uterine evacuation, it is more invasive and typically used in later stages of pregnancy or for different indications.

Karman Cannula (Option C) is a component used in the MVA procedure but does not function independently as the evacuation instrument.

questions.text: If the head circumference of a newborn is 35 cm, what would be the expected measurement at 1 year of age?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) 47 cm

 

Explanation:

The head circumference (HC) at one year is 47 cm.

 

Period

Rate of increase in Head Circumference

0-3 months

2 cm/month

3-6 months

1 cm/month

6-12 months

0.5 cm/month

1-3 years

0.2 cm/month

 

Considering the above calculations,

HC at 1 year = 35 cm + (2 cm x 3 months) + (1 cm x 3 months) + (0.5 cm x 6 months)

= 35 + 6 + 3 + 3

= 47 cm

questions.text: All of the following are true about a primary health centre (PHC) except?

choices.text: The presence of an AYUSH officer is not essential
At least 2 staff nurses per PHC should be present
The recommended bed count is at least 6 per PHC

questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Type A PHC: delivery load <15

 

Explanation:

  • Type A PHC: delivery load < 20

Standards per PHC:

Staffing count
  • Type A: 13-18
  • Type B: 14-21

Staffing division
  • Essential: 1 medical officer, 2 nurses, 1 pharmacist, 1 health worker male & 1 health worker female, 1 lab technician (Option C)
  • Desirable: 1 AYUSH officer (Option A)

Categorization
  • Type A: <20 deliveries (Option B)
  • Type B: >20 deliveries

Bed count
  • Six (Option D)

Services
  • 24*7 emergency services
  • Minimum 6 hours of outpatient service
  • Antenatal, perinatal (normal delivery & cesarean section) and postnatal services
  • MTP & contraception
  • Neonatal & infant care
  • Pediatric care: pneumonia, diarrhea, SAM
  • Communicable & non-communicable diseases services

questions.text: Which of the following is a correct pairing of a structure and its corresponding embryological origin?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Parotid gland – Surface ectoderm

 

Explanation:

The surface ectoderm gives rise to the Parotid gland.

 

Derivatives of Surface Ectoderm:

Structures

Derivatives

Epithelium & Glands
  • Skin epithelium
  • Sweat glands (Option A)
  • Sebaceous glands (Option B)
  • Myoepithelioctyes of skin

Eyes
  • Conjunctiva
  • Surface epithelium of cornea
  • Lens (Option D)

Salivary Glands
  • Parotid gland (Option C)
  • Submandibular gland
  • Sublingual gland

Opening Structures

  • Stomodeum
  • Proctodeum
  • Rathke pouch (Anterior pituitary)

questions.text: A researcher is interested in examining the prevalence of hypertension among adults in a city and wants to identify any associated risk factors such as age, diet, and physical activity at a single time. The researcher collects data from a large sample of adults in the city. Which type of study design is the researcher using in this scenario?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Cross-sectional study

 

Explanation:

  • A cross-sectional study is used to determine the prevalence of a disease in a population at a specific time.
  • It is also known as a snapshot of the total population.
  • Here it is cross-sectional study because it calculates prevalence of a disease and relies on primary data, i.e., researcher collects the data himself.
  • To assess the incidence, a Cohort study (Option A) starts by determining whether risk factors are present.
  • Case-control study (Option C) determines whether an exposure is associated with an outcome. It starts with diseased and non-diseased.
  • An Ecological study (Option D) compares exposure and disease frequency in a series of populations. The unit of study is population. Ecological study uses secondary data.

questions.text: You have been posted in a rural PHC where you just received a new batch of vaccines for the upcoming vaccination drive. You need to educate your team on the conditions that have to be fulfilled in order to reuse opened vaccine vials during the drive. Which of the following would you not suggest regarding the same?

choices.text: The Vaccine Vial monitor has not reached the discard point.
An aseptic technique must be used to withdraw all doses.
Vaccines are stored strictly under an appropriate temperature (+6° C to +10° C) range during transportation and storage at cold chain point.
The expiry date should not have passed.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Vaccines are stored strictly under an appropriate temperature (+6° C to +10° C) range during transportation and storage at cold chain point
 

Explanation:

  • Here, we need to explain the conditions for fulfilling the Open Vial Policy; this statement is not true.
  • Under Open Vial Policy, Vaccines are stored at an appropriate temperature range of (+2°C to +8°C) during transportation & storage at cold chain points.
  • Other conditions to be fulfilled under open vial policy include:
  • The Vaccine Vial monitor has not reached the discard point (Option A): Monitoring the Vaccine vial Monitor (VVM) is an essential aspect of vaccine management followed under the Open Vial Policy
  • An aseptic technique must be used to withdraw all doses (Option B): Maintaining sterility during the withdrawal of the vaccine is important to prevent contamination, a requirement under the Open vial policy.
  • The expiry date has not passed (Option D): Expired vaccines can lose their efficacy and can even become harmful.

questions.text: A 50-year-old patient with obstructive jaundice from a common bile duct stone, confirmed by elevated bilirubin and alkaline phosphatase, underwent successful stone extraction via ERCP. Post-procedure, the patient received education on bile flow regulation. Which of the following is not associated with bile synthesis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Cholecystokinin

 

Explanation:

CCK primarily stimulates the contraction of the gallbladder, which releases stored bile into the duodenum to aid in fat digestion. It also enhances pancreatic enzyme secretion. However, CCK does not directly regulate the synthesis of bile in the liver.

 

Regulation of Bile:

 

Hormonal Regulation
  • Secretin (Option B): Stimulates the secretion of a watery, bicarbonate-rich solution by epithelial cells in the bile ducts.
  • Cholecystokinin (CCK): Induces gallbladder contraction and relaxation of the sphincter of Oddi, facilitating the release of concentrated bile into the duodenum in response to fatty foods.

Neural Regulation
  • Vagal Stimulation: Promotes weak gallbladder contraction.
  • Enteric Nervous System: Nerve fibres in the intestine stimulate gallbladder motility and secretion.

Feedback Regulation
  • It is influenced by the presence of fats and acids in the duodenum.
  • Bile salts are the most potent regulators of Bile synthesis, which is regulated by the feedback mechanism. (Option D)


 

Cholesterol (Option C): Cholesterol is a precursor for bile acids. In the liver, it is converted into primary bile acids (such as cholic acid and chenodeoxycholic acid), which are essential components of bile and are thus involved in bile synthesis.

questions.text: Which of the following statements accurately describes the Quintero staging system for Twin-to-Twin Transfusion Syndrome (TTTS)?

choices.text: Stage I is characterized by absent or reversed end-diastolic flow in the umbilical artery of the donor twin.
Stage II is defined by the presence of polyhydramnios in the recipient twin and anhydramnios in the donor twin.
Stage III involves critically abnormal Doppler findings in one or both twins.
Stage V indicates the presence of hydrops fetalis in one or both twins.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer :C) Stage III involves critically abnormal Doppler findings in one or both twins.

According to Quintero Staging System for TTTS, Stage III indicates presence of abnormal doppler findings in one of both twins, such as

  • Absent or reversed end-diastolic flow in the umbilical artery,
  • Reversed flow in the ductus venosus
  • Pulsatile flow in the umbilical vein.


 

Quintero Staging System for Twin-to-Twin Transfusion Syndrome (TTTS)

Stage

Description

Stage I (Option A ruled out)

Polyhydramnios in the recipient twin (deepest vertical pocket ≥8 cm) and oligohydramnios in the donor twin (deepest vertical pocket ≤2 cm), with a visible bladder in the donor twin.

Stage II (Option B ruled out)

The donor twin's bladder is not visible on ultrasound, indicating severe oligohydramnios.

Stage III

Critically abnormal Doppler findings, such as absent or reversed end-diastolic flow in the umbilical artery, reversed flow in the ductus venosus, or pulsatile flow in the umbilical vein in one or both twins

Stage IV

Presence of hydrops fetalis in one or both twins, indicating severe fetal compromise

Stage V (Option D ruled out)

Demise of one or both twins

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents with a 2-day history of progressive weakness that started in his legs after returning from his international trip. Today he cannot get up from bed and is having hand weakness. On examination, distal arreflexia is noted with power grade 1/5 for muscles at all joints of lower limbs and 3/5 for upper limbs. CSF study shows cytoalbuminological dissociation. Which criteria are used for diagosis of this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Brighton criteria 

Explanation:

Brighton criteria are used for diangosis of GBS. These criteria grade diagnostic certainty from Level 1 (highest) to Level 4 based on clinical findings, CSF analysis (albuminocytologic dissociation), and electrophysiological testing. 

Option B is used for multiple sclerosis.

Option C is used for Normal pressure hydrocephalus.

Option D is used for Alzeihemer disease ( Clinical + biomarker-based diagnosis).

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient reports difficulty hearing in the Right ear. Pure tone audiometry is done and the result is given in the image below. Given the audiometric findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Conductive Hearing Loss

 

Explanation:

  • Given that the audiometric findings show a significant A-B gap with normal BC thresholds and poorer AC thresholds, the most likely diagnosis is Conductive Hearing Loss, typically due to issues in the outer or middle ear.

 

 


 

Normal Ear:

 Conductive Hearing Loss (Option A): 

  • AC Thresholds: Elevated (poorer hearing) compared to normal.
  • BC Thresholds: Within normal limits.
  • A-B Gap (>20db): Significant

 

Sensorineural Hearing Loss (SNHL) (Option B) :

  • AC Thresholds: Elevated
  • BC Thresholds: Elevated to the same degree as AC.
  • A-B Gap: Minimal or absent

 

Presbycusis (Option C) :

  • AC Thresholds: Elevated, particularly in high frequencies.
  • BC Thresholds: Elevated with greater loss in higher frequencies.
  • A-B Gap: Minimal
  • Downsloping

Meniere’s Disease (Option D): 

  • Upsloping
  • A-B Gap: Typically minimal

questions.text: A 28-year-old female presents with foul-smelling, greasy diarrhoea, bloating, and abdominal cramps following a hiking trip in a remote area. Stool microscopy reveals cysts containing motile trophozoites. A duodenal biopsy shows luminal organisms, as shown in the image, without tissue invasion. Based on the clinical presentation and biopsy findings, what is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Giardia lamblia

Explanation:

The scenario is of Giardia lamblia infestation

Giardia lamblia:

Definition
  • Flagellated protozoan parasite
  • Commonly associated with contaminated water sources.

Symptoms
  • Foul-smelling-greasy diarrhoea
  • Bloating
  • Abdominal cramps.

Biopsy findings
  • Luminal organisms attached to the intestinal epithelium
  • Blunting of the villi and
  • inflammation without tissue invasion.

 
  • Giardia trophozoites on biopsy are often described as resembling "falling leaves"

Cryptosporidium (Option A)

  • Coccidian parasite
  • Usually present along brush border of the intestine.
  • Causes watery diarrhoea, especially in immunocompromised individuals

Tropheryma whipplei (Option B)

  • Causes Whipple's disease
  • Histology: PAS-positive foamy macrophages in the intestinal mucosa

Entamoeba histolytica (Option C)

  • Protozoan parasite
  • It causes amoebic ulcer in intestine identified by flask shaped ulcers.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents with pain in the thigh and a noticeable deformity, as shown in the image. This deformity can be seen in all the following conditions except?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Osteopetrosis

 

Explanation:

  • The deformity described is the shepherd's crook deformity of the femur, characterized by a bowing of the proximal femur.
  • It results in a reduction of the femoral neck angle to nearly 90°, leading to a coxa vara deformity.
  • This is commonly seen in conditions like Paget's disease of bone, osteogenesis imperfecta, and fibrous dysplasia. However, osteopetrosis (Option C), a condition marked by excessive bone density, is not typically associated with this deformity.

 



 

  • Osteopetrosis is a condition characterized by excessive bone density and is typically associated with Erlenmeyer flask deformity, also known as metaphyseal flaring.

 

Paget's disease of bone (Option A): This condition involves abnormal bone remodeling that can lead to softened, enlarged bones prone to bowing and the characteristic "shepherd's crook" deformity, especially in the femur.

Osteogenesis imperfecta (Option B): Due to defective collagen, bones are brittle and prone to recurrent fractures and progressive bowing deformities, including the "shepherd's crook" shape, from normal weight-bearing.

Fibrous dysplasia (Option D): Replacement of normal bone with fibrous tissue, particularly in the proximal femur, results in weakened areas that can progressively bow into the distinct "shepherd's crook" deformity under mechanical stress.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents with painless, progressive genital ulcers. A tissue biopsy is taken, and a Wright-Giemsa stain is performed. The microscopic examination reveals Donovan bodies within macrophages as shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Granuloma inguinale

Explanation:

  • The clinical presentation of painless, progressive genital ulcers, along with the presence of c on Wright-Giemsa stain, is characteristic of granuloma inguinale (donovanosis), caused by Klebsiella granulomatis.
  • Donovan bodies are intracytoplasmic inclusions found in macrophages and are a diagnostic feature of this condition.

Syphilis (Option A): Typically presents with painless genital ulcers but is diagnosed by serologic tests and darkfield microscopy, not by finding Donovan bodies.

Gonorrhea (Option B): Generally presents with purulent discharge and painful urination; it does not produce Donovan bodies.

 

Chlamydia (Option C): Often asymptomatic or presents with discharge and dysuria, but also does not produce Donovan bodies.

questions.text:
As shown in the figure, a 10-year-old boy presents with a painless swelling over his left lower eyelid. He reports visiting the Amazon forest on vacation with his family recently. If left untreated, which of the following is not a long-term risk?



{{caption_text}}
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Sleeping sickness

 

Explanation:

American trypanosomiasis:

The given image shows Romana's sign, i.e., a swollen nodule or ‘chagoma’ at the site of infection, most commonly over the eyelids or near the mouth. This is an early sign of Trypanosoma cruzei infection, which is endemic to South America and is therefore called American trypanosomiasis.

Trypanosoma cruzei is transmitted via the bite of the Reduviid bug, or kissing bug (named so because the bite is painless).

Early symptoms are non-specific and include fever, lymphadenopathy, and the Romana sign.

If untreated, it can lead to Chaga’s disease, the manifestations of which include

  1. Dilated cardiomyopathy - heart failure (option B), arrhythmias, sudden cardiac death.
  2. Megaesophagus and megacolon (options C and D) - due to autonomic nerve destruction.

Diagnosis of acute disease is by demonstration of T cruzi trypomastigote on blood smears.

Treatment of acute disease involves Nifurtimox or Benznidazole.
Chaga’s disease is incurable and requires supportive care as appropriate.

 

Sleeping sickness:

  • This is caused by T. brucei (rhodesiense or gambiense). It is endemic to rural Africa and is transmitted by the tse tse fly. It is also known as African trypanosomiasis.
  • Early infection is non-specific, with fever, cervical lymphadenopathy (Winterbottom’s sign: posterior cervical triangle lymphadenopathy), Kerandl sign (delayed pain after a sharp blow or squeeze to soft tissue) and arthralgia, which lasts for varying lengths of time.
  • Late infection is characterized by neuropsychiatric manifestations, with sleep-wake cycle disturbance prominent.

questions.text: A 35-year-old pregnant woman at 34 weeks gestation presents to the emergency department with severe chest pain radiating to her left arm. An ECG shows ST-segment elevation in the anterior leads, and her serum high-sensitivity troponin I levels are elevated. The patient is diagnosed with an ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI). What is the most appropriate initial management for this patient?

choices.text: Immediate induction of labor to reduce cardiac stress
Administration of aspirin, heparin, and initiation of percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI)
Conservative management with bed rest and observation
Administration of intravenous thrombolytics and immediate cesarean delivery

questions.solution:
• The management of acute MI in pregnant women is similar to that in nonpregnant patients.
  • The initial treatment should include aspirin and heparin to manage the thrombosis, followed by percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) to revascularize the affected coronary artery. PCI is the preferred method as it is effective and safe during pregnancy.
  • Cesarean delivery is reserved for obstetrical indications after sufficient infarct healing. Epidural analgesia is preferred for labor pain management. (Option D)
  • Immediate Induction of Labor is not the immediate priority for managing a STEMI. (Option A)
  • Conservative Management with Bed Rest and Observation would not address the immediate need for myocardial reperfusion and could lead to a worsening of the myocardial infarction. (Option C)

questions.text: A child is diagnosed with immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP). The most recent platelet count is 32,000/μL, and the child does not exhibit any signs of active bleeding. What is the appropriate next step in management for this child?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Wait and watch

 

Explanation:

 

The child doesn’t have severe thrombocytopenia and/or any life-threatening bleeding. Hence in this case the child only requires close observation.

 

Management of Immune thrombocytopenic purpura in children.

Based on platelet count
  • Platelet Count >30,000 cells/μL + No severe bleeding- Monitor closely
  • Platelet Count < 30,000 cells/μL + No severe bleeding + Platelet Count ≥ 5,000 cells/μL: Glucocorticoids (e.g., Prednisone, Dexamethasone) (Option A)
  • Platelet Count < 5,000 cells/μL or Severe Bleeding: IVIg + Glucocorticoids

Other modalities
  • Immediate Need to Raise Platelet Count, like surgery or trauma- Platelet Transfusion (Option B)
  • Persistent or Severe Cases- Monitor with intermittent IVig, If Necessary, Consider Splenectomy (Option C)

Alternative Medications
  • Anti-CD20 Antibody: Rituximab
  • TPO Receptor Agonists: Romiplostim, Eltrombopag

questions.text: In the surgical management of soft tissue sarcoma, which of the following criteria is most appropriate for achieving optimal outcomes?

choices.text: Wide local excision with a 1 cm margin
Radical excision with removal of adjacent muscle groups
Wide local excision with a 2 cm margin
Radical excision with lymph node removal

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Wide local excision with a 2 cm margin

 

Explanation:

  • Wide local excision with a 2 cm margin ensures complete tumour removal while preserving function and minimising tissue loss.
  • This approach effectively reduces the risk of local recurrence.

 

Wide local excision with a 1 cm margin (Option A) may be inadequate for many soft tissue sarcomas, potentially leading to higher rates of local recurrence.

 

Radical excision with removal of adjacent muscle groups (Option B): 

  • It is often overly aggressive and can lead to unnecessary functional impairment without significantly improving outcomes in most cases.

 

Radical excision with lymph node removal (Option D) is generally not necessary for most soft tissue sarcomas, as they typically spread hematogenously rather than through lymphatics, and routine lymph node dissection is not standard practice unless there is evidence of lymph node involvement.

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding the WHO classification of anovulation?

choices.text: Type I includes Kallman syndrome, which is associated with high FSH levels.
Type III includes women with hypogonadotropic hypogonadism.
Type I includes women with hyperprolactinemia.
Type II includes women with normogonadotropic normoestrogenic anovulation.

questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) Type II includes women with normogonadotropic normoestrogenic anovulation.

 

Explanation:

WHO group II includes women with normogonadotropic normoestrogenic anovulation.

 

WHO Classification for Anovulation:

Type/ Group

Features

Hormone levels

I (Option A)

(Central)
  • Hypogonadotropic hypogonadism
    • Sheehan syndrome, Kallmann syndrome

Low LH & FSH

Low estrogen

II (Option D)
(Peripheral)
  • Normogonadotropic hypogonadism
    • PCOD (most common)

Normal LH & FSH (abnormal ratio)

Normal estrogen

III (Option B)

(Low estrogen)
  • Hypergonadotropic hypogonadism
    • Premature ovarian failure: Radiation, chemotherapy, galactosemia

High LH & FSH

Low estrogen

 

Note: Hyperprolactinaemia (Option C) suppresses GnRH production and is classified as a separate cause (Type IV).

questions.text: A 58-year-old male smoker presents with a persistent cough and mild shortness of breath. Chest imaging reveals a solitary pulmonary nodule. A biopsy is performed, and a histopathological examination of the lung tissue is shown in the image below. What is the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Diffuse idiopathic pulmonary neuroendocrine cell hyperplasia

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Adenocarcinoma in situ

 

Explanation:

  • The histopathological image shows a localised proliferation of dysplastic cells along pre-existing alveolar septa, indicative of adenocarcinoma in situ (AIS) or bronchioloalveolar carcinoma which is a precancerous lesion of adenocarcinoma of the lung with severe cytologic atypia.
  • AIS is an early stage of lung cancer where abnormal glandular cells are confined to the airway lining without invasion and exhibit a “lepidic growth pattern” (or butterfly on fence pattern), spreading along intact alveolar structures without invasion.
  • Lesions are usually small, measuring ≤ 3 cm.

Carcinoma in situ (Option A):

  • Carcinoma in situ involves abnormal squamous cells confined to the epithelium without invading the surrounding structures.

 

Adenomatous hyperplasia (Option B):

  • Atypical adenomatous hyperplasia (AAH) is a precursor lesion of lung adenocarcinoma with mild cytologic atypia, characterised by dysplastic pneumocytes lining alveolar walls.
  • These lesions are typically small, ≤5 mm, and can be single or multiple.
  • AAH may be adjacent to invasive tumours or independently within the lung tissue and signifies an initial stage in adenocarcinoma development.

Diffuse idiopathic pulmonary neuroendocrine cell hyperplasia (Option D):

  • DIPNECH (Diffuse idiopathic pulmonary neuroendocrine cell hyperplasia) is a preneoplastic condition characterised by the abnormal proliferation of neuroendocrine cells in the lungs, which can progress to develop into neuroendocrine tumours over time like small cell carcinoma and carcinoid tumours.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Warthin's tumour and its diagnostic features is correct?

choices.text: It is best identified on imaging by its hypoechoic appearance and confirmed with FNAC.
A Tc99 pertechnetate scan showing a "hotspot" is indicative of Warthin's tumour.
Warthin's tumour generally exhibits low uptake on Tc99 pertechnetate scans

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) A Tc99 pertechnetate scan showing a "hotspot" is indicative of Warthin's tumour.

Explanation:

Warthin's tumour shows increased uptake on Tc99 pertechnetate scans because of its high mitochondrial content. Histopathological features include papillary structures, cystic spaces, oncocytic epithelial cells, and lymphoid stroma.

Tc99 Pertechnetate Scan:

  • Purpose: Assesses salivary gland function and detects abnormal areas.
  • Hot Spot: Increased uptake of the radioactive tracer (Option D), indicating high mitochondrial content typical of Warthin's tumour.

Histopathology (HPE) (Option C):

  • Papillary Structures: Finger-like projections extending into cystic spaces.
  • Cystic Spaces: Fluid-filled cavities within the tumor.
  • Oncocytic Epithelial Cells: Two layers of cells with abundant mitochondria lining the papillary and cystic areas.
  • Lymphoid Stroma: Supporting tissue with lymphocytes and germinal centres, resembling lymph node tissue.

It is best identified on imaging by its hypoechoic appearance and confirmed with FNAC (Option A): While FNAC is used for diagnosis, Warthin's tumour typically shows a "hot spot" on Tc99 pertechnetate scans due to high mitochondrial content, not just hypoechoic appearance. FNAC might not always reveal the distinct features of Warthin's tumour.

questions.text: A group of 4 experts on cardiac health were invited to interact with an audience of about 100 members. However, they were not given any set agenda to speak upon nor did they have any set speeches. They are allowed to discuss among themselves during the event as well and there is no set order of speaking. What kind of event were they invited to?
questions.solution:
Correct option: A) Panel discussion

 

Explanation:

  • In a panel discussion, 4 to 8 persons who are qualified to talk/ discuss the topic sit and discuss a given problem or topic in front of a large group or audience, without a set agenda or order of speaking and with audience interaction at the end of the discussion.
  • Symposium: In contrast to a panel discussion, a symposium involves 4-8 experts talking on a given topic with set agendas, speeches, and an order of speaking. .(Option B)

Panel discussion

Symposium

4-8 experts

4-8 experts

Two-way or Socratic

Two-way or Socratic

No set agenda

Set agenda

Not set speeches

Set speeches

No set order of speaking

Set order of speaking

Audience is present

Audience is present

Experts can discuss among themselves (they can intervene in between)

Experts cannot intervene in between (they cannot discuss among themselves)

Feedback can be taken

Feedback can be taken

Workshop (Option C):

  • A workshop is a practical educational experience in which participants learn new skills or techniques over a series of four or more meetings.

Seminar (Option D):

  • A seminar is a lecture-style presentation where a speaker provides information on a particular subject and the audience is allowed to ask questions and participate in a discussion.
  • It has a set agenda and speech.

questions.text:
A 25-year-old male presents with right lower quadrant abdominal pain and is diagnosed with acute appendicitis. The surgical team plans to perform an appendectomy. Which of the following correctly represents the type of Incision used in appendicectomy?



 

a-Lanz
b-Rutherford Morrison
c-McBurney’s
d-Paramedian
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) 1-c, 2-b, 3-a, 4-d

Explanation:

The Incisions typically used for appendicectomy are given in the table below:

McBurney's incision
  • Centered on McBurney's point, perpendicular to the umbilical ASIS line
  • Junction of lateral 1/3 from umbilicus & medial 2/3 from ASIS
  • McBurney's point corresponds to the base of the appendix
  • Muscle splitting incision
  • Aka Grid iron incision / McArthur incision

Lanz incision

Placed transversely 2 cm below the umbilicus on the line joining the midpoint of the clavicle to the midpoint of the inguinal ligament
  • Muscle splitting incision
  • Cosmetically better incision
  • Aka Modified McBurney's incision / Rocky Davis incision / Bikini incision (good cosmetic appearance)

Rutherford-Morrison incision
  • Extension of McBurney's incision for retrocecal appendicitis
  • Upward & laterally by cutting conjoint tendon
  • Muscle cutting incision
  • Preferred for retrocecal appendix

questions.text: A 25 y/o woman presents to the dermatologist with intense itching and anxiety, convinced that tiny insects are crawling on her skin. She frequently inspects her body and applies various lotions to prevent what she believes are infestations, although no evidence of insects or bites is found on examination. She is aware that her fear may be exaggerated, but she cannot stop feeling anxious about it. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Acarophobia

 

Explanation:

  • Acarophobia is the fear of mites or small insects crawling on the skin, which fits the patient's symptoms of irrational anxiety about infestations without objective evidence.

 

Phobias and Impulses:

  • Phobias:
    • Classified under Neurotic and Somatoform Disorders.
    • Defined as a persistent, unrealistic, and intense fear of an object or situation, often recognised as irrational by the individual.
    • Types of phobias:
      • Agoraphobia: Fear of open spaces, crowds, or leaving home; commonly affects women and may involve panic attacks. (Option D)
      • Social Phobia: Fear of social interactions or situations (e.g., public speaking).
      • Specific Phobia: Fear of particular objects or situations, examples include:

Acrophobia

Fear of heights (Option C)

Acarophobia

Fear of mites/insects (Option B)

Claustrophobia

Fear of confined spaces

Needle Phobia

Fear of injections

Algophobia

Fear of pain

Xenophobia

Abnormal fear of strangers

Gamophobia

Fear of marriage/relationships

Zoophobia

Fear of animals
  • Impulses:
    • Highlighted in forensic psychiatry due to potential links to criminal behaviour.
    • Defined as sudden, irresistible forces driving a person to act without motive or forethought.

Types of impulses:

Kleptomania

Compulsive stealing

Dipsomania

Compulsive drinking of alcohol

Pyromania

Urge to set fires

Mutilomania

Desire to harm animals

Oniomania

Compulsive shopping

Trichotillomania

Compulsive hair-pulling

Suicidal Impulse

The urge to commit suicide, often triggered by intoxication

Homicidal Impulse

Urge to commit homicide, linked to chronic intoxication

 

Delusional parasitosis (Option A): In delusional parasitosis, patients have a fixed false belief of being infested with parasites, typically without insight into the irrationality of their belief.

 

Causes of Delusional Parasitosis

Primary Psychiatric Disorders:

  • Schizophrenia
  • Bipolar disorder
  • Depression
  • Anxiety
  • OCD
  • Illness anxiety disorder

 

Medical Causes:

  • Illnesses: Hyperthyroidism, B12/folate deficiencies, diabetes.
  • Neurological: Dementia, stroke, multiple sclerosis.
  • Substance Abuse: Methamphetamine, alcohol withdrawal, cocaine.
  • Infections: HIV, tuberculosis, leprosy, syphilis.
  • Medications: Topiramate, ciprofloxacin, steroids, ketoconazole.

questions.text:
In their CRISPR-Cas9 experiment with a mammalian cell line, the research team observes the repair of DNA double-strand breaks. Which repair mechanisms are they most likely observing?


	Non-Homologous End Joining (NHEJ)
	Homologous End Joining (HEJ)
	Nucleotide Excision Repair (NER)
	Base Excision Repair (BER)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 1 and 2

Explanation:

In a CRISPR-Cas9 experiment, the Cas9 enzyme introduces double-strand breaks (DSBs) in DNA. The cell then uses two primary repair mechanisms for these DSBs:

  • Non-Homologous End Joining (NHEJ):
    A quick, error-prone repair mechanism that directly ligates the broken DNA ends without a template. Commonly results in insertions or deletions (indels), making it useful for gene knockouts.

  • Homologous Recombination / Homologous End Joining (HEJ):
    A high-fidelity repair mechanism that uses a homologous DNA template (often supplied by the experimenter) to repair the break accurately. Used in gene knock-in strategies.

DNA Repair Mechanisms in CRISPR Context

Mechanism Role in CRISPR Repair DNA Damage Type Handled
Non-Homologous End Joining Yes Double-strand breaks (DSBs)
Homologous End Joining (HR) Yes Double-strand breaks (DSBs)
Nucleotide Excision Repair No Bulky lesions (e.g. UV damage)
Base Excision Repair No

Small base damage or single-strand breaks

 

1, 2, 3 (NHEJ, HEJ, NER) (Option B):
Incorrect because NER does not participate in double-strand break repair.

1 and 4 (NHEJ and BER) (Option C):
Incorrect because BER handles single-strand lesions, not DSBs.

All of the above (Option D):
Incorrect because NER and BER are not involved in repairing Cas9-induced DSBs.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male with diabetes mellitus presents with fatigue and abdominal discomfort. He denies any history of alcohol consumption. Laboratory tests show elevated serum AST and ALT levels. Imaging reveals hepatic steatosis. Which of the following is consistent with the patient's presentation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) AST/ALT < 1 with diabetes mellitus

 

Explanation:

The clinical presentation is consistent with Non-alcoholic steatohepatitis, characterised by AST/ALT < 1.

 

Features

NASH

(Non-alcoholic steatohepatitis)

Alcoholic steatohepatitis

Risk factors

Obesity 

Diabetes mellitus (Option C)

Dyslipidemia (Option D ruled out)

Alcohol intake

AST/ALT Ratio

AST/ALT < 1 (Option A and B ruled out)

AST/ALT > 2

GGT levels

Normal

Increased

questions.text: A 40-year-old male was found shot dead in a parking lot. Forensic examination revealed that the cause of death was a shotgun injury. Considering the type of injury, what is the probable range of the shot?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) < 1 metre

 

Explanation:

  • A close-shot injury (< 1 metre) has a circular or elliptical entry wound with blackening, burning, tattooing, and singeing of hair.
  • The wound track and surrounding tissues appear cherry-red due to carbon monoxide absorption.

 

Gunshot wound characteristics based on Range of shooting:

Shooting Range

Range

Wound Description

Contact shot

Muzzle in direct contact

Circular entry wound with muzzle imprint, severe tissue damage, blackening, and burning of the wound edges. Cherry-red tissue due to carbon monoxide absorption.

Close-shot (Option A)

< 1 meter

Circular or elliptical entry wound with blackening, burning, tattooing, singeing of hair, and cherry-red tissue discolouration due to carbon monoxide absorption.

Short-range (Option B)

1-2 meters

Circular 4-5 cm wound (Rat hole) with irregular borders, no blackening, burning, or tattooing.

Intermediate shot (Option C)

2-4 meters

Large, irregular wound surrounded by multiple satellite wounds.

Distant shot (Option D)

> 4 meters

The entry wound fades, leaving multiple small pellet wounds.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female presenting with persistent right ear fullness, hearing loss, and pressure particularly during flights is suspected of having Eustachian tube blockage. During rhinoscopy, a structure labelled as X in the image below is noted. Identify this structure.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Fossa of Rosenmuller

 

Explanation:

The structure marked ‘X’ in the above image is the fossa of rosenmuller.

Anatomy of Nasopharynx

  • The nasopharynx, also known as the epipharynx, is the uppermost portion of the pharynx, located behind the nasal cavities and extends from the base of the skull to the soft palate or the horizontal plane that passes through the hard palate.
  • Boundaries of the nasopharynx:

Boundaries

Relations

Roof

Formed by basisphenoid and basiocciput.

Posterior wall
  • C1 vertebra covered by prevertebral muscles and fascia
  • The roof and the posterior wall merge gradually with one another.

Floor
  • It is formed by the soft palate anteriorly but is deficient posteriorly.
  • The nasopharynx connects to the oropharynx (nasopharyngeal isthmus).

Anterior wall
  • Formed by posterior nasal apertures or choanae.
  • Posterior ends of nasal turbinates and meatuses are seen.

Lateral wall

  • Eustachian tube
  • Torus tubarius: A cushion-like elevation that borders the Eustachian tube from above and behind. (Option B)
  • Fossa of Rosenmuller: A recess above and behind the torus tubarius (the most common site for carcinoma origin).
  • Salpingopharyngeal fold: A ridge extends from the lower end of the torus tubarius to the lateral pharyngeal wall.

 

 

Pyriform fossa (Option A) or pyriform sinus (smuggler’s pouch) are the two depressions on the lateral sides of the aryepiglottic folds.

  • It is a site where foreign bodies can lodge and form the lateral channel for food.

 

Post cricoid region (Option D) is the part of the anterior wall of the laryngopharynx between the upper and lower borders of the cricoid lamina.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with a chronic cough productive of copious sputum. He reports frequent respiratory infections over the past several years. Physical examination reveals digital clubbing and coarse crackles on auscultation. An HRCT is done and shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) Bronchiectasis

Explanation:

The clinical presentation of a male with chronic cough, copious sputum, past history of frequent respiratory infections, clubbing, coarse crackles on auscultation, and HRCT showing thickened and dilated bronchi (tram-track appearance) is suggestive of bronchiectasis.

  • Bronchiectasis is characterised by the irreversible dilation and distortion of bronchi, typically due to chronic inflammation and recurrent infections.

The image below shows bronchiectasis with markedly dilated bronchi in the upper and lower lobes.

 

Tuberculosis (Option A):

  • HRCT shows cavitary lesions, tree-in-bud nodules, or consolidations, not the bronchial dilation seen in bronchiectasis.

Asthma (Option B):

  • HRCT is usually normal or may show bronchial wall thickening but not bronchial dilation.

COPD (Option C):

  • HRCT shows emphysematous changes (air trapping, bullae) and airway narrowing but lacks the tram-track or signet ring appearance seen in bronchiectasis.

questions.text: Identify the correct option.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 5- Abducens nerve; 3- Vagus nerve

 

Explanation:

Attachment of the nerves to the brain:

  • 1, 2 - Forebrain
  • 3- Arises from ventral midbrain
  • 4- Dorsal midbrain (cannot see its origin in the Anterior view of the brainstem)
  • 5- Lateral pons
  • 6, 7, 8- Ponto medullary junction (from medial to lateral respectively)
  • 9, 10, 11- Lateral to olives (from superior to inferior respectively)
  • 12- Between pyramid and olives

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common type of radiolucent renal stone?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Uric Acid Stones

 

Explanation:

Radiopaque stones:

  • Calcium Oxalate Stones (Option A ruled out)
  • Calcium Phosphate Stones
  • Struvite Stones
  • Cystine stones are also mildly radiopaque (Option C ruled out)

 

Radiolucent stones include:

  • Uric acid stones (most common) (Option B)
  • Xanthine stones (rarely seen, mainly in patients with xanthinuria) (Option D ruled out)

Stone Type

Features

Image

Calcium Oxalate
  • The most common type of stone (60–85% of all stones) ; Radiopaque
  • Associated with hypercalciuria, hypercalcaemia, hyperoxaluria, hyperuricosuria, and hypocitraturia
  • Types: monohydrate (dumbbell shaped) , dihydrate (envelope shaped)

 


 

Calcium Phosphate
  • Pure calcium phosphate stones are rare
  • Types include apatite and brushite stones
  • Apatite stones are seen with infection; brushite stones are associated with distal renal tubular acidosis

Struvite
  • Aka staghorn calculi / Triple phosphate stone (Ca, Mg, NH4+, Phosphate)
  • Radiopaque
  • Infection stones that form in alkaline urine due to urease-producing bacteria (e.g., Proteus, Klebsiella, Serratia, Enterobacter)

Cystine
  • Radiopaque, Constitute approximately 1% of stones
  • Result from cystinuria, an autosomal recessive inherited disease that causes decreased reabsorption of cystine
  • Very hard stones due to disulfide bonds

Uric Acid
  • Radiolucent
  • Promoted by hyperuricosuria, which can be caused by conditions like gout and myeloproliferative disorders
  • Precipitates in acidic urine and remains soluble in alkaline urine

questions.text: Which type of metaplasia characterizes the histological changes observed in Barrett's oesophagus?

choices.text: Transformation of columnar epithelium to squamous epithelium
Replacement of squamous epithelium with columnar epithelium containing goblet cells
Conversion of glandular epithelium to squamous epithelium
Substitution of mesenchymal cells with epithelial cells

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Replacement of squamous epithelium with columnar epithelium containing goblet cells

Explanation:

  • Barrett's oesophagus is characterized by the replacement of the normal squamous epithelium of the lower oesophagus with columnar epithelium containing goblet cells. (Goblet cells contain acidic mucin staining positive with alcian blue, which helps to differentiate from intestinal epithelium)
  • This metaplastic change is considered an adaptive response to chronic exposure to gastric acid and bile reflux in the setting of gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD).

questions.text: Which of the following statements is TRUE regarding the rotator cuff muscles?

choices.text: The rotator cuff includes the Supraspinatus, Infraspinatus, Subscapularis, and Teres major, which collectively aid in shoulder abduction and external rotation.
The Subscapularis is the only rotator cuff muscle involved in internal rotation of the humerus.
The Infraspinatus and Teres minor are responsible for medial rotation of the shoulder joint.
The rotator cuff muscles are primarily located in the anterior aspect of the shoulder joint

questions.solution:
Correct option: B) The Subscapularis is the only rotator cuff muscle involved in internal rotation of the humerus.

 

Explanation:

 

Rotator Cuff Muscles:

Muscle (Tendon)

Action

Nerve Supply

Supraspinatus

Initiates abduction of the shoulder

Suprascapular nerve(C5,C6)

Infraspinatus

External( lateral)rotation of the shoulder

Suprascapular nerve(C5,C6)

Teres minor

External(lateral) rotation of the shoulder

Axillary nerve (C5,C6)

Subscapularis

Internal (medial) rotation of the shoulder

Upper and lower subscapular nerves (C5,C6,C7)

 

 The rotator cuff is composed of the Supraspinatus, Infraspinatus, Subscapularis, and Teres minor, not Teres major (Option A).

 

The Infraspinatus and Teres minor are involved in external (lateral) rotation, not medial rotation. (Option C)

 

The rotator cuff muscles are located primarily around the shoulder joint, with some being posterior (e.g., Infraspinatus, Teres minor) and one anterior (Subscapularis) (Option D).

questions.text: A 15-year-old male presents to the ED after experiencing a brief episode of syncope. He reports occasional palpitations and dizziness. His family history is significant for sudden cardiac death at a young age. An ECG of leads V1-V3 is given below. Which of the following management options is most appropriate for this patient, given the findings?

choices.text: Prescribe a beta-blocker and advise lifestyle modifications
It is also called Broken heart syndrome

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Deploy an implantable cardioverter-defibrillator.

Explanation:

  • ECG shows Coved ST elevations greater than 2 mm in the right precordial leads (V1-V3).
  • Instead of SCD in the family, ICD should be deployed as early as possible

questions.text: A 65 y/o presents with jaundice, weight loss, and abdominal pain. O/E a palpable mass is noted in the right upper quadrant. Imaging studies reveal a mass involving the gallbladder, with signs of local invasion but no distant or lymph node metastasis. A biopsy confirms gallbladder carcinoma. Based on the TNM classification, which stage is most likely for this patient's tumour?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) T3 N0 M0

Explanation:

The patient's presentation of jaundice, weight loss, abdominal pain, and a palpable mass, along with imaging showing local invasion but no distant metastasis, suggests an advanced stage. According to the TNM classification:

  • T3: Tumor perforates the serosa and/or invades the liver or adjacent organs.
  • N0: No regional lymph node metastasis.
  • M0: No distant metastasis.

This corresponds to T3 N0 M0.

 

Category

Description
 

Tis

Carcinoma in situ

T1

Tumor invades lamina propria or muscle layer

T1a

Tumor invades lamina propria

T1b

Tumor invades muscle layer

T2

Tumor invades perimuscular connective tissue

T2a

Tumor does not extend to serosa

T2b

Tumor extends to serosa, but does not invade the liver

T3

Tumor perforates serosa and/or invades liver/adjacent organs

T4

Tumor invades main portal vein/hepatic artery/multiple extrahepatic organs
 

N0

No regional lymph node metastasis

N1

Metastases to 1-3 regional lymph nodes

N2

Metastases to >3 regional lymph nodes
 

M0

No distant metastasis

M1

Distant metastasis

This TNM classification assists in determining treatment approaches and provides prognostic information for gallbladder carcinoma.

questions.text: A 6-month-old infant is brought to the clinic by their parents reporting that their infant is not meeting developmental milestones, such as rolling over or sitting up. On examination, the infant has eczema and a noticeable musty odor. Hair and skin pigmentation appear lighter. Which of the following enzymes is deficient in this infant?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Phenylalanine hydroxylase

Explanation:

  • The infant’s symptoms, like failure to meet developmental milestones, eczema, a musty odor, and lighter hair and skin pigmentation, are characteristic of Phenylketonuria (PKU).
  • PKU is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by a defect in the enzyme phenylalanine hydroxylase (PAH).
  • This enzyme deficiency disrupts the body's ability to metabolize the amino acid phenylalanine, leading to its accumulation in the body.

 

Deficiency in tyrosinase (Option B) causes albinism. It does not typically present with a musty odor or developmental delays.

 

Deficiency in tyrosine aminotransferase (Option C) can cause tyrosinemia type 2, which primarily affects the eyes and skin but does not present with a musty odor or developmental delays

 

Deficiency in 4-HPPD (Option D) is less common and typically does not include the musty odor. It causes tyrosinemia type- 3 (Hawkinsuria) with a swimming pool (chlorine) odor.

questions.text: A 6-month-old child has recently passed away after a long ICU stay. Examination reveals microphthalmia and microcephaly. Other known diagnoses included ventricular septal defect, polycystic kidney disease, and omphalocele at birth. What is the chromosome involved?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Chromosome 13

 

Explanation:

The given scenario describes Patau syndrome or Trisomy 13.

Clinical features and associations include

  • Rocker-bottom feet (Seen in both trisomy 13 and trisomy 18)
  • Severe intellectual disability
  • Keyhole/ Coloboma (eyes)
  • Microphthalmia, microcephaly, holoprosencephaly
  • Cleft lip/palate
  • Polydactyly
  • Congenital heart disease: PDA (Patent Ductus Arteriosus) or VSD (Ventricular Septal Defect)
  • Renal defects-Polycystic kidney disease
  • Umbilical hernia,Omphalocele

 

Trisomy 18 is Edward syndrome: Clinical features include a prominent occiput (Strawberry skull) and rocker-bottom feet (Option B ruled out)

questions.text: A 15 year old boy has been assessed for cognitive abilities, and his mental age is determined to be 9 years. What is the IQ based on the provided information?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 60

 

Explanation:

The child’s IQ calculated using the formula is 60, indicating significant limitations in intellectual functioning.

  1. Using the IQ formula:
    IQ=(Mental Age/Chronological Age)×100
  2. Substituting the ages:
    • Mental Age: 9 years
    • Chronological Age: 15 years
  3. IQ = (9/15)×100 = 60 (Options B, C, and D)

 

Intellectual Disability

  • Significant limitations in both:
    • Intellectual functioning –reasoning, learning, problem-solving.
    • Adaptive behaviour – conceptual, social, and practical skills.
  • Onset before 18 years.

 

Intelligence quotient

  • Intelligence is usually measured by calculating IQ.
  • IQ is an intelligence quotient.
  • IQ = (Mental age ÷ Chronological age) x 100
    • Chronological age - Age calculated from the date of birth.
    • Mental age - The age of one's intellect.
    • Various tests are done to calculate mental age.
  • Normal IQ: 90-109
  • Borderline IQ: 80-89
  • Mental retardation: IQ < 70

questions.text: A rural clinic generates biomedical waste daily with no nearest biomedical waste treatment facility nearby. What is the most appropriate method for disposing of biomedical waste in this situation?

choices.text: Use of disinfectants and dispose with municipal waste

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Deep Burial

 

Explanation:

Deep Burial:

  • Indication: No common biomedical waste treatment facility (CBWTF) is available nearby.
  • 2 metres deep.
  • Common practice in PHCs.
  • Biomedical waste should not be disposed of in regular landfills (Option A) due to its hazardous nature and potential for environmental contamination.

 

The use of disinfectants and dispose with municipal waste (Option C) does not ensure proper treatment of biomedical waste and may lead to contamination of municipal waste streams, posing risks to waste handlers and the public.

questions.text: A 35 year old man visits the clinic with a persistent cough and fever lasting for more than 2 weeks. He also reports experiencing night sweats and significant weight loss over the past month. Sputum smear tests or radiological tests are not yet done. According to the new terminologies in NTEP, how should this patient's case be categorized?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Presumptive TB case

 

Explanation:

  • The patient should be categorized as a "Presumptive TB case" according to NTEP's new terminologies as the patient is showing cough, fever or night sweats & apparent loss in weight for more than 2 weeks.
  • The term Presumptive TB case is used in place of TB suspect (Option B) and refers to individuals who show symptoms suggestive of TB but have not yet been confirmed with a diagnosis.
  • This term is crucial for early identification and screening of TB cases to initiate timely diagnosis and treatment.
  • The new NTEP changes in terminologies are as follows:

Category

Description

Criteria/Features

Presumptive TB Case
  • Used in place of TB suspect.
  • Individuals showing symptoms suggestive of TB but not yet confirmed.
  • Cough, Fever, Night sweats +- Weight loss > 2 weeks

Clinically Diagnosed TB Case

(Option A)
  • Sputum negative but with high clinical suspicion of TB.
  • Used in place of Sputum negative TB case. (Option C)
  • Persistent symptoms despite negative sputum smear
  • High clinical suspicion based on symptoms, radiological and histological features

Bacteriologically Confirmed TB Case
  • Biological specimen is positive for sputum AFB and/or CBNAAT.
  • Used in place of Sputum positive TB case.
  • Positive sputum smear for AFB
  • Positive CBNAAT test confirming the presence of TB bacteria

questions.text:
A 60-year-old woman presents with a newly diagnosed left-sided breast mass on routine mammography. Core needle biopsy shows the following findings. Further molecular study revealed the involvement of the CDH1 gene. Which of the following statements are incorrect concerning this type of breast cancer?



1) Increased E-cadherin expression is observed in tumor cells.

2) Minimal desmoplasia and fibrosis were observed on microscopy.

3) A contralateral breast examination is usually required due to bilateral involvement.

4) It is associated with a poor prognosis compared to other types of breast cancer.

5) Metastatic spread affects leptomeninges and retroperitoneum.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer : C) 1,4

 

Explanation :

Invasive lobular breast carcinoma:

  • CDH1 gene mutation: Decreased E-cadherin levels (also seen in signet ring gastric adenocarcinoma). (Statement 1)
  • Clinically: Bilateral and multicentric lesions; if one breast has ILC, both breasts should be examined. (Statement 3)
  • Microscopy Features:
    • The tumor cells are dyscohesive, present back to back, and are called Indian file pattern.
    • Shows minimal desmoplasia and fibrosis. (Statement 2)
  • Metastatic spread to the retroperitoneum and leptomeninges is called carcinomatous meningitis. (Statement 5)
  • Excellent prognosis because it usually belongs to Luminal A and B categories.(Statement 4)

questions.text:
An elderly male diabetic patient came with loss of vision in the left eye associated with pain in the left eye. On examination, the left eye appears red, and visual acuity- Perception of light+ and IOP is raised in the same eye. The patient gives history of blurring and diminution of vision for the past 1 year. The slit lamp examination is given below.


 

Choose the correct diagnosis and appropriate pathophysiology for this patient.
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Phacolytic glaucoma - Secondary open-angle glaucoma

 

Explanation:

  • Given clinical scenario is suggestive of Glaucoma and the slit lamp image of a milky white cortex with a sunken nucleus corresponds to the Morgagnian type of hyper mature cataract - leading to secondary open-angle glaucoma called Phacolytic glaucoma. (Option C and D)

 

Feature

Phacomorphic Glaucoma

Phacolytic Glaucoma

Pathogenesis
  • Intumescent cataract blocks the pupil.
  • this pushes the iris forward,
  • blocking the anterior chamber angle,
  • leading to angle-closure glaucoma.
  • Leakage of lens proteins from a hypermature cataract clogs the trabecular meshwork.

Causes
  • Intumescent cataract (mature cataract)
  • Anterior subluxation of lens
  • Spherophakia
  • Hypermature (Morgagnian) cataract
  • Obstruction of the trabecular meshwork by lens proteins.

Clinical Features
  • Symptoms are similar to acute primary angle-closure glaucoma.
  • Shallow anterior chamber.
  • Ciliary congestion, dilated pupil, and swollen cataract is visible.
  • Closed anterior chamber angle on gonioscopy.
  • Features of acute congestive glaucoma due to high IOP.
  • Deep anterior chamber.
  • Open anterior chamber angle on gonioscopy.

Management
  • Medical Treatment: IV mannitol, systemic acetazolamide, topical beta-blockers.
  • Laser Iridotomy: To relieve angle closure.
  • Surgical Treatment: Cataract extraction with PCIOL implantation.
  • Medical Therapy: To lower IOP.
  • Surgical Treatment: Extraction of the hypermature cataract and PCIOL implantation.

 

Phacomorphic glaucoma is seen in the intumescent stage of cataract - a type of secondary closed-angle glaucoma. (Option A and B)

questions.text: Identify the type of tissue shown in the image below:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Cardiac muscle

Explanation:

The image shows a tissue section with the following key histological features:

  • Branched and striated fibers

  • Centrally located nuclei

  • Intercalated discs (seen as dark transverse lines)

  • One or two nuclei per cell

These features are characteristic of cardiac muscle tissue.

Skeletal Muscle

Cardiac Muscle

Smooth Muscle

Longitudinal Section:

  • Fibers are long, parallel, and non-branching.
  • Characteristic transverse striations are visible.
  • Multiple flat nuclei located at the periphery.
  • Fibers are separated by connective tissue (Epimysium, perimysium, endomysium).

Transverse Section:

  • Fibers appear as irregularly round structures with peripheral nuclei.
  • Muscle fibers are grouped into numerous fascicles.
  • Myofibrils appear as small dots within fibers at higher magnification.

 
  • Composed of individual cells with centrally placed nuclei.
  • Displays transverse striations.
  • Clear perinuclear halo around the nucleus.
  • Cells are separated by intercalated discs (transverse lines).
  • Fibers exhibit branching.
  • Blood vessels are present.
  • Loose connective tissue is seen above and below muscle layers.

Longitudinal Section:

  • Fibers are spindle-shaped with tapering ends.
  • Centrally located elongated nucleus.
  • No visible striations.

Transverse Section:

  • Spindle-shaped cells are cut at varying lengths, producing different shapes and sizes.
  • Nuclei are visible in cells cut through the center.
  • Cells cut away from the center do not show nuclei.

 

 Purkinje fibers (Option D):
Incorrect because Purkinje fibers are a specialized type of cardiac conducting fiber, larger, pale-staining, and often lack prominent striations. They are not the dominant feature in this section.
