questions.text: A 54-year-old female presents with significant weight loss and a characteristic rash as in the image. Blood tests reveal elevated plasma glucagon levels exceeding 1000 pg/mL. A CT scan shows a large mass in the tail of the pancreas. Which of the following statements regarding her condition is correct?

choices.text: The mass is commonly found in the head of the pancreas
The initial treatment includes antibiotics and steroids
The rash seen is necrolytic migratory erythema
Surgical resection is the treatment option for this condition

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) The rash seen is necrolytic migratory erythema

Explanation:

The scenario here is of the diagnosis glucagonoma, which is characterized by elevated plasma glucagon levels exceeding 1000 pg/mL and the typical rash found in this condition called necrolytic migratory erythema.

Glucagonoma

Glucagonomas are neuroendocrine tumours that arise from multipotential stem cells of endodermal origin.

Clinical features:

Characteristic dermatitis:

  • It presents as necrolytic migratory erythema, primarily affecting intertriginous areas such as the groin and buttocks.
  • The rash may fluctuate in severity (wax and wane).        

Other common symptoms:

  • Glucose intolerance.
  • Significant weight loss.

Tumor Characteristics:

  • Most glucagonomas are large at the time of diagnosis and are typically located in the tail of the pancreas. (Option A ruled out)

Diagnosis:

  • This is confirmed by elevated plasma glucagon levels, typically exceeding 1000 pg/mL.
  • CT Scan:
    • The initial localization method is a helical multiphasic contrast-enhanced CT scan.
    • High sensitivity for detecting intrapancreatic neuroendocrine tumours, exceeding 80%.
  • MRI:
    • Used for indeterminate lesions.
  • May provide superior sensitivity for identifying liver metastases.
  • Somatostatin Receptor Scintigraphy (SRS):
    • Positive results are seen in 97% of patients with glucagonoma.
    • It effectively detects small, hidden metastases both within and outside the abdomen.
    • Useful for staging the tumour.

Initial Treatment:

  • Somatostatin analogues like octreotide and lanreotide effectively reduce symptoms and manage the rash related to glucagon hypersecretion by inhibiting glucagon. (Option B ruled out)
  • Involves total parenteral nutrition and supplementation of amino acids and zinc to address malnutrition and counteract weight loss effects from glucagon.
  • Antibiotics, zinc replacement, and steroids may enhance recovery from necrolytic migratory erythema (NME).

Surgical Recommendations:

  • For localized disease, distal pancreatectomy and splenectomy are advised.
  • The only curative option for a small percentage of patients with localized tumours. (Option D ruled out)

Complications:

  • Up to 33% of patients may experience a hypercoagulable state, and therefore, perioperative anticoagulation is generally recommended.

questions.text:
Match the following actions of insulin with the correct category:

Categories:

a) Increased by insulin
b) Decreased by insulin

Insulin Action:


	Cell growth
	Reabsorption of K+, Na+, and phosphate from the kidney
	Food intake
	Entry of phosphate and magnesium into the cell
	Body weight
	Lipolysis
	Potassium uptake into cells
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) a)-1,2,4,5,7 & b)-3,6

Explanation: 

a) Increased by insulin

  • Cell growth: Insulin promotes cell growth and proliferation.
  • Reabsorption of K+, Na+, and phosphate from the kidney: Insulin enhances the reabsorption of these electrolytes in the kidneys.
  • Entry of phosphate and magnesium into the cell: Insulin facilitates the uptake of phosphate and magnesium into cells.
  • Body weight: Insulin can increase body weight due to its effects on fat storage increasing adipose tissue mass.
  • Potassium uptake into cells: Insulin promotes the movement of potassium into cells, which can lower blood potassium levels. Therefore is very useful in the management of acute renal failure. Insulin is considered a physiological regulator of plasma K+ concentration.

b) Decreased by insulin

  • Food intake: Insulin can promote satiety by increasing leptin levels in plasma, leading to decreased food intake. Also partly mediated by its inhibitory effect on neuropeptide Y release from the hypothalamus.
  • Lipolysis: Insulin inhibits lipolysis, which is the breakdown of fats into fatty acids and glycerol.

questions.text: In a large ventricular septal defect (VSD), which factor primarily determines the direction and magnitude of the left-to-right shunt?

choices.text: Ratio of pulmonary vascular resistance (PVR) to systemic vascular resistance (SVR)
Ratio of left ventricular pressure to right ventricular pressure
Ratio of systemic vascular resistance (SVR) to pulmonary arterial pressure

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Ratio of pulmonary vascular resistance (PVR) to systemic vascular resistance (SVR)

Explanation:

In large VSDs, the direction and magnitude of the left-to-right shunt are primarily influenced by the ratio of pulmonary vascular resistance (PVR) to systemic vascular resistance (SVR).

 

Pathophysiology in VSD:

Size of the Defect and Shunt Magnitude:

  • The physical size of the VSD influences the magnitude of the left-to-right shunt.
  • In a large VSD, the shunt's magnitude is primarily determined by the ratio of pulmonary vascular resistance (PVR) to systemic vascular resistance (SVR). (Option B)

 

Size of the left atrium (Option A): Left atrial size is a consequence of shunt volume rather than its primary determinant; the primary driving forces are ventricular pressures and downstream resistances.

Ratio of left ventricular pressure to right ventricular pressure (Option C): In a large VSD, ventricular pressures tend to equalize, making the downstream vascular resistances (PVR and SVR) the dominant factor dictating shunt flow.

Ratio of systemic vascular resistance (SVR) to pulmonary arterial pressure (Option D): This ratio compares a resistance to a pressure, which is an inappropriate comparison for determining the shunt direction and magnitude across the VSD; the critical factors are the relative resistances of the systemic and pulmonary circulations.

questions.text: Which technique of incisional hernia is done at point B?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Inlay

 

Explanation:

The inlay technique is characterized by placing the mesh within the defect and suturing it to the fascial edges.

Incisional Hernia Mesh Placement Techniques:

Technique

Mesh Placement

Procedure

Advantages

Disadvantages

Inlay

(Option B)

Within the fascial defect itself

Mesh is sutured to the edges of the fascial defect.

It can be used for large defects where primary closure isn't possible.

High recurrence rates due to mesh separation from fascial edges under abdominal pressure

Onlay

(Option A)

On top of the anterior rectus sheath/external oblique aponeurosis

Subcutaneous tissue is dissected off; the fascial defect is closed primarily, and the mesh is placed on top and secured

Technically easier and less invasive.

Higher risk of seroma formation, mesh infection, and skin necrosis.

Retromuscular

(Option C)

Behind the rectus muscle but anterior to the posterior rectus sheath

The posterior rectus sheath is opened, the mesh is placed in the created space, and the posterior sheath is closed over it

Lower recurrence rates, mesh well incorporated into tissues

More complex procedure, risk of injury to neurovascular bundles.

Preperitoneal

(Option D)

Between the peritoneum and the posterior rectus sheath.

Peritoneum is separated from posterior rectus sheath, mesh is placed in this space, peritoneum is closed over it.

Good mesh incorporation, lower risk of adhesions.

Technically challenging, risk of peritoneal tears.

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman has a purulent discharge from a surgical wound after an abdominal surgery performed two weeks ago. An analysis of the discharge, reveals Gram-positive cocci. Further testing shows that the organism is catalase-positive and coagulase-negative. What is the most likely organism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Staphylococcus epidermidis

Explanation:

Staphylococcus epidermidis is present on normal human skin and is the most common cause of CoNS infections in humans. When the host's defenses are breached (in this scenario it is the surgery), stitch abscess frequently results from it.

 


 

(Options A, C, and D)

 

CONS (Coagulase negative staphylococcus):

  • Normal flora of the human body
  • S. epidermidis, S.haemolyticus, and S.lugdunensis cause device-associated and healthcare-associated infections.
  • The most frequent cause of CoNS infections in people is S. epidermidis.
  • It causes biofilm formation and prosthetic heart valve infection( <12 months post-replacement)
  • It is normal skin flora and causes illness when the host's defenses are compromised. It frequently results in stitch abscesses.

questions.text: Which of the following is considered the primary pacemaker for respiration in the brainstem?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Pre-Bötzinger Complex

Explanation:

The Ventral Respiratory Group consist of 4 clear zones.

 

Zones

Location

Function

Pre-Bötzinger Complex

Ventrolateral medulla

A primary pacemaker for respiration that generates the basic rhythmic pattern of breathing.

Bötzinger Complex

(Option B ruled out)

Medulla oblongata, dorsal

Modulates respiratory rhythm; involved in expiratory phase regulation and inhibition of inspiration.

Rostral Ventral Respiratory Group (VRG)

(Option A ruled out)

Medulla oblongata, rostral

It contributes to rhythm generation and integrates respiratory signals; it is involved in the inspiratory and expiratory phases.

Caudal Ventral Respiratory Group (VRG)

(Option D ruled out)

Medulla oblongata, caudal

Primarily involved in controlling the expiratory phase of respiration.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents with fatigue, weakness, and pallor. Blood tests reveal microcytic anemia with elevated serum iron and ferritin levels. Bone marrow biopsy shows ringed sideroblasts. Genetic testing confirms a mutation in the ALAS2 gene. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) X-linked sideroblastic anemia

 

Explanation:

 

  • X-linked sideroblastic anemia (XLSA) is caused by mutations in the ALAS2 gene, which is responsible for the enzyme 5-aminolevulinate synthase 2, essential for the first step in heme synthesis.
  • This condition typically presents with microcytic, hypochromic anemia, elevated serum iron and ferritin levels, and ringed sideroblasts in the bone marrow.
  • The confirmed mutation in the ALAS2 gene in the patient points to XLSA, distinguishing it from other forms of anemia.
  • Overactivation of ALAS2 gene causes x linked protoporphyria

 

Differences Between X-Linked and Autosomal Recessive Sideroblastic Anemia:

Characteristic

X-Linked Sideroblastic Anemia (XLSA)

Autosomal Recessive Sideroblastic Anemia (ARSA)

(Option D)

Genetic Cause

Mutation in the ALAS2 gene

Mutations in various genes involved in glycine transport into mitochondria, including SLC25A38 and GLRX5

Gender Predominance

Primarily affects males

It affects both males and females equally

Clinical Presentation

Microcytic, hypochromic anemia; ringed sideroblasts; increased serum iron and ferritin

Microcytic anemia; ringed sideroblasts; variable symptoms

Pathway Affected

Heme synthesis (5-aminolevulinate synthase 2)

Mitochondrial function, iron-sulfur cluster biogenesis

Common Symptoms

Fatigue, pallor, weakness

Fatigue, pallor, weakness; potential systemic symptoms

Diagnosis

Genetic testing for ALAS2 mutations

Genetic testing for specific gene mutations

Management Options

Pyridoxine, iron chelation, blood transfusions

Iron chelation, blood transfusions, supportive therapies

 

  • Iron Deficiency Anemia (Option A) is characterized by low serum iron and ferritin levels, which do not match the elevated levels seen in the case.
  • Thalassemia (Option B) involves defective globin chain production and normal iron levels, unlike the elevated iron levels and ringed sideroblasts present here.

questions.text:
Following sign was seen while performing a radiological investigation



Identify the investigation and the corresponding diagnosis.

choices.text: Digital subtraction Angiography- Carotid body tumor

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Digital subtraction Angiography- Carotid body tumor

 

Explanation:

Investigation shown is Digital Subtraction Angiography (DSA) and Lyre sign is seen at the carotid bifurcation, which is suggestive of Carotid body tumor - a type of Paraganglioma.

 

Radiological findings in carotid body tumor:

NCCT

Large well defined mass seen over carotid bifurcation

CECT

Well defined peripherally enhancing lesion at carotid bifurcation

MRI (T2-weighted)

Mass splaying the carotid bifurcation is seen

MR Angiogram

Bilateral carotid body tumor seen

Digital subtraction Angiography (DSA)

Lyre sign positive (Option C)

 

MR Angiogram- Glomus jugulare (Option A): The image is clearly a Digital Subtraction Angiography (DSA) due to the sharp, flow-related contrast and bone subtraction, not an MRA. A Glomus jugulare tumor is located in the jugular foramen, superior to the carotid bifurcation shown here.

Digital subtraction Angiography-glomus jugulare (Option B): While the imaging modality is correctly identified as DSA, the location and "splaying" appearance are characteristic of a carotid body tumor, not a glomus jugulare, which arises from the jugular bulb.

MR Angiogram- Carotid body tumor (Option D): The diagnosis of a Carotid body tumor is consistent with the image findings, but the imaging modality depicted is a Digital Subtraction Angiography, not an MR Angiogram.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman presents with continuous, painless vaginal bleeding for two months following 7 weeks of amenorrhea. She previously experienced heavy menstrual bleeding. Examination reveals a slightly enlarged uterus. A biopsy of the endometrium is shown below. Which is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Metropathia hemorrhagica

 

Explanation: The clinical presentation and the biopsy revealing Swiss cheese endometrium suggest Metropathia hemorrhagica, which is a specialised form of anovulatory AUB, typically affecting women aged 40-45 and is characterised by continuous, painless vaginal bleeding, often following a period of amenorrhea.

  • The uterus may be slightly enlarged.
  • This condition can mimic abortion or ectopic pregnancy if preceded by amenorrhea but without pain.
  • Endometrial biopsy: Hyperproliferative endometrium - Cystic Glandular Hyperplasia (CGH), also known as the Swiss cheese endometrium

questions.text: A 35-year-old female experiences numbness and tingling in her right arm, worsened by arm elevation. During examination, she abducts her arms to 90° with external rotation, flexes her elbows to 90°, and opens and closes her hands for 3 minutes, which reproduces her symptoms. Which test was most likely performed?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Roos Test

 

Explanation:

  • The scenario describes the Roos test (also known as the Elevated Arm Stress Test), which is used to diagnose thoracic outlet syndrome (TOS).
  • The test involves the patient abducting their arms to 90°, externally rotating them, flexing the elbows to 90°, and repeatedly opening and closing the hands for 3 minutes.
  • Reproduction of symptoms like numbness or tingling during this test indicates a positive result, suggestive of TOS.

Roos Test 

Common provocative diagnostic tests for Thoracic Outlet Syndrome (TOS):

Test

Maneuver

Result

Adson's Test (Option A)

Arm abducted 30° and maximally extended. Patient extends neck, turns head toward the ipsilateral side, and inhales deeply.

Decrease or absence of ipsilateral radial pulse.

Elevated Arm Stress Test (EAST) / Roos Test (Option B)

Arms in "surrender" position (abducted 90°, external rotation, elbows flexed 90°).

The patient slowly opens and closes hands for 3 minutes.

Pain, paresthesia, heaviness, or weakness precipitated.

Upper Limb Tension Test (ULTT) / Elvey Test (Option D)
  • Position 1: Arms abducted 90°, elbows flexed.
  • Position 2: Active dorsiflexion of wrists.
  • Position 3: Tilt head (ear to shoulder) in both directions.

Symptoms in the ipsilateral arm (Position 1 & 2); Contralateral symptoms in Position 3.

 

Wright's test (Option C) is a clinical sign in which the radial pulse weakens or disappears when the arm is abducted and externally rotated.

Adsons test 

Elvey Test

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents with knee pain and reports that he feels a "catching" sensation during movement after a recent sports injury. On examination, there is localized tenderness along the joint line, and he experiences difficulty fully extending the knee. Which of the following clinical features is most characteristic of a meniscal tear?

choices.text: Pain on passive extension of the knee
Locking of the knee during movement

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Locking of the knee during movement

 

Explanation:

  • The most characteristic clinical feature of a meniscal tear is locking of the knee during movement.
  • This symptom, along with the “catching” sensation and joint line tenderness, strongly suggests a meniscal injury

 

Meniscal Injuries:

Anatomy of the Menisci

  • Location: Fibrocartilaginous structures between femur and tibia in the knee joint.
  • Types:
    • Medial Meniscus: Inner side of the knee; less mobile and more prone to injury due to capsule attachments.
    • Lateral Meniscus: Outer side of the knee; more mobile than the medial meniscus.
  • Structure: Composed of circumferential collagen fibers with radial strands; prone to longitudinal tears.
  • Functions:
    • Aids proprioception through mechanoreceptors that detect joint motion and position.
    • Enhance joint stability and congruency.
    • Facilitate smooth knee motion.
    • Distribute load during weight-bearing (50% in extension; up to 90% in flexion).

Mechanism of Meniscal Tears

  • Common Causes:
    • Rotational and Shearing Forces: Twisting a flexed knee under weight (common in sports).
    • Age-Related Degeneration: Reduced mobility in older adults leads to tears with minimal force.
  • Tear Mechanism by Age:
    • Younger Individuals: Traumatic tears from specific sports incidents.
    • Older Individuals: Tears may occur with less force due to degenerative changes, often without a distinct injury.


 

Clinical Features of Meniscal Tears

Symptom/ Feature

Description

Pain

Localized to the joint line, particularly medial; worsens with activities stressing the meniscus.

Swelling

Delayed onset, usually hours after injury; presents as effusion. (Option A ruled out)

Mechanical Symptoms
  • Locking: Difficulty fully extending the knee; suggests "bucket-handle" tear. (Option C)
  • Catching: Sensation of knee getting stuck, indicating loose fragment.
  • Giving Way: Knee buckling during twisting movements, suggesting instability.

Examination Findings
  • Tenderness: Localized along the joint line, typically medial.
  • Limited Extension: Difficulty achieving full knee extension.
  • Quadriceps Wasting: Possible in chronic cases.
  • Special Tests: Clinical tests (McMurray's, Apley's, Thessaly) assist diagnosis; MRI is the gold standard.

 

Pain on passive extension (Option B) is more indicative of ligamentous injuries rather than meniscal tears.

 

Dislocation of the knee (Option D) joint is not a feature of meniscal tears; it suggests a more severe injury or instability.

  • Inconvenience of application

 

Calcipotriene (also known as calcipotriol) and dithranol are examples of vitamin D analogs commonly used to treat psoriasis.

Adalimumab (Option A) is a tumor necrosis factor (TNF) inhibitor. It works by blocking the action of TNF. It is used to treat various autoimmune conditions such as psoriasis, psoriatic arthritis, rheumatoid arthritis, and ankylosing spondylitis.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male patient is undergoing major abdominal surgery under general anesthesia. After induction of anesthesia, the patient's CVP is measured at 3 cm H2O. The patient’s heart rate is 110/min, blood pressure is 80/50 mmHg. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial management step based on the CVP and clinical findings?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Administer a fluid bolus

Explanation:

Low CVP (3 cm H2O) suggests hypovolemia, which is consistent with the patient's tachycardia and hypotension. Administering a fluid bolus is the first-line treatment to increase preload and improve hemodynamics.

 

Central Venous Pressure (CVP) Monitoring:

CVP measures the pressure in the thoracic vena cava near the right atrium, reflecting right ventricular preload and overall fluid status.

Measurement Method (Invasive):

Central venous catheter placed in large veins (e.g., subclavian or internal jugular), connected to a pressure transducer

Normal Range: 3-8 mmHg.

Low CVP Causes:

  • Hypovolemia (blood loss or dehydration).
  • Venodilation (e.g., in septic shock).

Elevated CVP Causes:

  • Heart failure, fluid overload, valve dysfunction.
  • Increased intrathoracic pressure (e.g., mechanical ventilation, tension pneumothorax).

Clinical Use:

  • Guides fluid resuscitation.
  • Helps assess heart function and venous return.

 

Vasopressors (Option A) may be required if hypotension persists after adequate fluid resuscitation, but not as the initial step.

Blood transfusion (Option C) is not indicated unless there is evidence of blood loss or anemia.

Increasing anesthetic depth (Option D) is inappropriate here, as the patient is likely hypovolemic.

questions.text: A 28 year old male presents to the STD clinic with a history of swelling in the inguinal region as shown in the image below. He has a history of unprotected sexual intercourse in the past few months and reports a painless ulcer, which healed without scarring. Which of the following is false regarding this condition?

choices.text: Can be associated with hepatitis C co-infection
Presents with an indurated ulcer and painless lymphadenopathy
Esthiomene is a complication in the tertiary stage of this disease

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Presents with an indurated ulcer and painless lymphadenopathy

Explanation:

The given clinical presentation of a male with a history of unprotected sexual intercourse, swelling in the inguinal region (inguinal lymphadenopathy) and a painless ulcer that has healed without scarring is suggestive of lymphogranuloma venerum, caused by Chlamydia trachomatis. The incorrect statement is that it presents with an indurated ulcer and painless lymphadenopathy.

Lymphogranuloma venerum (LGV): 

  • It is a sexually transmitted disease caused by serovars L1-L3 of Chlamydia trachomatis (M/C strain causing LGV: L2). It occurs in sexually active adults of all ages. It can cause LGV-associated proctitis in homosexuals, associated with HIV and hepatitis C co-infection.
  • The incubation period of LGV is around 3-30 days, and the disease presents in three stages, described in the table below:

Primary

Secondary

Tertiary

3-30 days

Days-weeks

Years after a chronic, untreated infection

Small papule/pustule/
Non-indurated ulcer at the site of inoculation which heals spontaneously with no scarring.
  • Lymphatic involvement of nodes that drain the primary lesion.
  • Classic form: Tender unilateral or bilateral inguinal and/or femoral adenopathy (Groove sign of Greenblatt).
  • The lymph nodes may coalesce to form a bubo or abscesses that may rupture spontaneously with the development of
    Fistulae or sinus tracts.
  • There may be systemic features such as malaise and fever.

Lymphatic obstruction due to chronic inflammation leads to fistula formation, strictures, and disfiguring conditions such as genital elephantiasis and esthiomene, which refers to hypertrophic enlargement with ulceration of the external genitalia.
  • Diagnosis of LGV can be confirmed by the Nucelic Acid Amplification Test (NAAT). Antibody detection by real-time PCR can also be done. Treatment includes:
    • First line: Doxycycline 100mg BD x 21 days.
    • Second line: Erythromycin 500mg 4 times a day x 21 days.
    • Third line: Azithromycin 1g weekly once x 21 days.

 

Caused by Chlamydia trachomatis L1-L3 (Option A): This statement is true; these specific serovars are the causative agents of LGV.

Can be associated with hepatitis C co-infection (Option B): This statement is true; co-infections with other STIs, including HCV, are possible in individuals with LGV.

Esthiomene is a complication in the tertiary stage of this disease (Option D): This statement is true; esthiomene (genital elephantiasis) is a recognized chronic complication of untreated or persistent LGV infection.

questions.text: A 45-year-old professional singer presents with complaints of vocal fatigue and difficulty producing high-pitched sounds for the last 3 months. She denies any difficulty in swallowing or breathing. On laryngoscopic examination, no significant abnormalities are seen, and one vocal cord appears to be in normal resting position while other vocal cord is in abducted position . What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Unilateral SLN palsy

 

Explanation:

  • In this scenario, the patient is a professional singer who reports difficulty with high-pitched sounds, which is a hallmark of unilateral SLN palsy.
  • The external branch of the superior laryngeal nerve innervates the cricothyroid muscle, which tenses the vocal cords, crucial for producing high-pitched sounds.
  • In unilateral SLN palsy, the patient does not experience breathing or swallowing difficulties, and laryngoscopic examination may appear normal.

 

Unilateral SLN Palsy

  • Motor Loss: Cricothyroid muscle - decreased ability to tense the vocal cord.
  • Sensory Loss: Above the vocal cord on the affected side.
  • Vocal Cord Position: The affected vocal cord appears shortened and wavy; may exhibit flapping due to loss of tension.
  • Other Features:
    • Askew position of the glottis with the anterior commissure rotated towards the healthy side.
    • Voice changes such as weakness and inability to raise pitch, affecting singing ability.
  • Treatment: Primarily voice therapy to improve vocal function and manage symptoms.

 

Bilateral SLN Palsy

  • Motor Loss: Both cricothyroid muscles - bilateral loss of vocal cord tension.
  • Sensory Loss: Above the vocal cords bilaterally.
  • Vocal Cord Position: Both vocal cords may be shortened and lack tension, potentially leading to difficulties with voice production.
  • Other Features:
    • Inhalation of food and secretions resulting in coughing and choking.
    • The voice is weak and husky.
  • Treatment:
    • Tracheostomy with a cuffed tube and esophageal feeding tube, if aspiration is severe.
    • Epiglottopexy (reversible) - close laryngeal inlet - to protect the lungs from aspiration.
    • Voice pitch improvement through surgical approximation of the thyroid and cricoid cartilages.

 

Bilateral SLN palsy (Option A):

  • The patient would have more pronounced symptoms, including a monotonous voice, significant difficulty with high-pitched sounds, and aspiration due to poor sensation in the upper larynx.

 

Unilateral RLN palsy (Option C)

  • Causes hoarseness and, on laryngoscopy, shows one vocal cord in a paramedian position.
  • In contrast, this patient's difficulty is specifically related to high-pitched sounds, pointing to SLN involvement rather than RLN.

 

Bilateral RLN palsy (Option D):

  • It is a severe condition that typically results in stridor or significant respiratory difficulty due to both vocal cords being fixed in the paramedian position.
  • The absence of breathing or swallowing problems in this patient rules out bilateral RLN palsy.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy falls off the monkey bars, landing on his outstretched hand, and immediately experiences severe pain and swelling around his elbow. An X-ray reveals a supracondylar fracture of the humerus. Which of the following features will not be seen if his radial nerve is injured?

choices.text: Loss of extension of metacarpophalangeal joints

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Absence of triceps reflex

 

Explanation:

  • The absence of triceps reflex is seen in the injury of the radial nerve around the shoulder joint, not the elbow joint.

 

Radial nerve lesions:

Type

Injury

Clinical Features

Low Lesions

Fractures or dislocations at the elbow
  • Cannot extend the metacarpophalangeal joints (Option A ruled out)
  • Thumb weakness (Option C ruled out)
  • Radial deviation of the wrist (Option B ruled out)

High Lesions

Humerus fractures or prolonged tourniquet pressure
  • Wrist drop
  • Inability to extend MCP joints or elevate thumb
  • Sensory loss around the anatomical snuffbox

Very High Lesions

Around the shoulder

  • Weakness of wrist and hand
  • Paralysis of triceps and absence of triceps reflex (Option D)

 

Type of Injury

Treatment

Open Injuries
  • Immediate exploration and nerve repair or grafting

Closed Injuries
  • Wait 12 weeks for recovery before exploring
  • Use EMG if no improvement; if denervation is detected, perform nerve exploration and repair or grafting

Fractures of Humerus
  • Assess for nerve injury on admission
  • If the injury appears post-manipulation or internal fixation, explore and repair or graft immediately

Recovery Management
  • Perform passive hand movements
  • Splint the wrist in extension-cock up splint:

  • Avoid ‘lively’ hand splints to prevent metacarpophalangeal joint contractures

Long-term Disability
  • Use tendon transfers: pronator teres to short radial extensor, flexor carpi radialis or ulnaris to finger extensors, palmaris longus to thumb abductor

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman presents with joint pain, fatigue, and a malar rash. Laboratory tests reveal positive ANA and anti-dsDNA antibodies. According to the EULAR/ACR classification criteria, which of the following criteria is not required for diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct answer- D) Ocular symptoms

  • Though GI and ocular symptoms are part of SLE manifestations, they aren't included in the EULAR/ACR Classification Criteria for SLE.
  • This classification includes both clinical & immunological criteria; the patient must fulfil at least one clinical criterion, and ≥10 points are classified.
  • ANA positive ( titer of ≥ 1:80 on Hep-2 cells) is the required entry criteria to classify SLE.

 

EULAR/ACR Classification Criteria for SLE

Clinical Domain and Criteria

Weight

Immunological Domain and Criteria

Weight

Constitutional

  • Fever
  

2

Antiphospholipid antibodies (Option A ruled out)

  • Anti-cardiolipin antibodies or
  • Anti-b2GP1 antibodies or
  • Lupus anticoagulant
  

2

Hematologic

  • Leukopenia
  • Thrombocytopenia
  • Autoimmune hemolytic anemia
  

3

4

4

Complement proteins

  • Low C3 or low C4
  • Low C3 and C4
  

3

4

Neuropsychiatric (Option C ruled out)

  • Delirium
  • Psychosis
  • Seizure
  

2

3

5

SLE – speciﬁc antibodies

  • Anti-ds DNA antibody or
  • Anti-Smith antibody
  

6

Mucocutaneous

  • Non-scarring alopecia
  • Oral ulcers
  • Subacute cutaneous OR discoid lupus
  • Acute cutaneous lupus
  

2

2

  • Pleural or pericardial eﬀusion
  • Acute pericarditis

  • Joint Involvement

Renal

  • Proteinuria >0.5 g/24 h
  • Renal biopsy Class II or V lupus nephritis
  • Renal biopsy Class III or IV lupus nephritis

  • A positive ANA test is required as an entry criterion.
  • A diagnosis is made if a total score of ≥10 points is reached based on clinical and immunological features.
  • All the criteria should be mainly explained by SLE but not be attributed to other medical conditions or factors.

questions.text:
Match the following

 


	
		
			
			Heart sound 
			
			
			Condition seen 
			
		
		
			
			1) Wide Split S2
			
			
			a) RBBB
			
		
		
			
			2) Paradoxical Splitting S2
			
			
			b) Mitral regurgitation
			
		
		
			
			3) Fixed Splitting S2
			
			
			c) LBBB
			
		
		
			
			4) Narrow Split S2
			
			
			d) Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy 
			
		
		
			
			 
			
			
			e) ASD
questions.solution:
Correct Option: A) 1-b, 2-c, 3-e, 4-d

 

Correct match:

Condition

Type of Split

Wide split

Mitral regurgitation due to early A2

Paradoxical split

LBBB due to delayed closure of A2

Fixed Splitting

ASD

Narrow splitting

Dynamic out flow tract obstruction will cause more time for blood to exit from left side. This causes delayed closure of A2 causing narrow split S2

questions.text: A 6-month-old infant presents with hypotonia, poor feeding, constipation and developmental delays. The child was born at term with a low birth weight. Which of the following conditions is most likely to be the underlying cause?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Congenital Hypothyroidism

Explanation:

The presenting features along with low birth weight suggests Congenital Hypothyroidism.

 

Congenital Hypothyroidism presents with features like:

 

  • Hypotonia: Low muscle tone due to inadequate thyroid hormone levels.
  • Poor Feeding: Infants with congenital hypothyroidism often have difficulty feeding, which can result in poor weight gain.
  • Developmental Delays: Delay in reaching developmental milestones is common, including motor and cognitive delays.
  • Congenital hypothyroidism can be associated with intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR), leading to a low birth weight.

 

Down Syndrome (Option A): While Down syndrome can cause developmental delays, it usually presents with characteristic features such as hypotonia and distinct facial dysmorphisms, and it is not specifically associated with low birth weight.

 

Cerebral Palsy (Option C): This condition often results from brain injury and might present with hypotonia, but it typically becomes apparent later and is less likely to be the cause of poor feeding and low birth weight at 6 months.

 

Fragile X Syndrome (Option D): This genetic disorder leads to developmental delays and behavioral issues but does not usually cause hypotonia or poor feeding in the early months of life.

questions.text: MRCP imaging studies done for a 35 year old woman who presented with a history of recurrent cholangitis, jaundice, and right upper quadrant pain reveal the following. Based on the Todani classification, what is the most appropriate surgical treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Roux-en-Y hepaticojejunostomy

 

Explanation:

Imaging shows an anomalous pancreaticobiliary junction, with a high junction of the pancreatic duct with the common bile duct resulting in a long common channel. There is fusiform dilation of the common bile duct, compatible with a type I choledochal cyst. The recommended treatment for Type I cysts is complete surgical excision, cholecystectomy, and Roux-en-Y hepaticojejunostomy.

  • Choledochal cysts are congenital anomalies characterized by the dilatation of the intrahepatic and/or extrahepatic bile ducts. The exact cause of choledochal cysts is unknown, but they are thought to be premalignant.

Todani modification of Alonso- Lej classification

Type I

Ia

Cystic dilation of the extrahepatic bile duct (Most common)

Ib

Focal segmental dilation of extrahepatic bile duct

Ic

Fusiform dilation of extrahepatic bile duct

Type II

Diverticular dilation of extrahepatic bile duct

Type III

Dilatation of intraduodenal part of bile duct (choledochocele)

Type IV

IV a

Dilatation of both intra and extrahepatic bile duct
 

IV b

Multiple cysts involving extrahepatic bile duct only

Type V

Multiple cysts involving intrahepatic bile duct only (Caroli’s disease)

 

Type

Treatment

Type I

Complete excision, cholecystectomy, Roux-en-Y hepaticojejunostomy

Type II

Complete excision

Type III

Transduodenal excision or sphincteroplasty (Option B); endoscopic drainage may suffice

Type IVa

Tailored to anatomy: extrahepatic cysts treated like Type I; partial hepatectomy (Option D) and reconstruction for localized intrahepatic involvement

Type IVb

Managed like Type I

Type V (Caroli disease)

Resection for unilobar disease; liver transplantation for diffuse disease (Option A)

questions.text: A 50-year-old patient with a history of cardiac arrhythmias presents with symptoms of allergic rhinitis. The physician considers prescribing either terfenadine or fexofenadine for symptom relief. Which differentiating factors should be considered when selecting the appropriate antihistamine for this patient?

choices.text: Fexofenadine is more likely to cause sedation.
Fexofenadine is more potent than terfenadine.
Fexofenadine is less likely to cause cardiac toxicity.
Fexofenadine is more expensive than terfenadine.

questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Fexofenadine is less likely to cause cardiac toxicity.

Explanation:

  • Terfenadine, a first-generation antihistamine, is associated with a risk of cardiac arrhythmias, including QT interval prolongation and torsades de pointes, due to its effects on cardiac potassium channels.
  • In contrast, fexofenadine, the active metabolite of terfenadine, has a lower propensity for such cardiac adverse effects.

Feature

Terfenadine

Fexofenadine

Type

First-generation antihistamine

Second-generation antihistamine

Cardiac toxicity

Withdrawn due to risk of cardiac arrhythmias (e.g., Torsades de Pointes) when co-administered with CYP3A4 inhibitors.

(Note: CAT drugs - Cisapride, Astemizole, and Terfenadine have been withdrawn due to cardiotoxicity).

Generally considered safer with minimal risk of cardiac arrhythmias.

Drug Interactions

Prone to interactions with CYP3A4 inhibitors.

Less prone to interactions with CYP3A4 inhibitors.

CNS Penetration

Penetrates blood-brain barrier.

Poor penetration of the blood-brain barrier.

Pharmacokinetics

Metabolism leads to a longer half-life and duration of action.

Minimal metabolism, shorter half-life, and shorter duration of action.

Sedative Effects

It may cause sedation and impair psychomotor performance.

Minimal sedation or impairment of psychomotor performance.

 

Fexofenadine is more likely to cause sedation (Option A): Incorrect; both cause minimal sedation, and fexofenadine is less sedating.

Fexofenadine is more potent than terfenadine (Option B): Incorrect; potency is similar as fexofenadine is terfenadine’s active metabolite.

Fexofenadine is more expensive than terfenadine (Option D): Incorrect; cost is variable and not the main clinical differentiator.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman presents with Stage III B breast cancer. Her diagnostic workup includes imaging studies and biopsy, revealing a locally advanced tumor with involvement of regional lymph nodes. The tumor is hormone receptor-positive and HER2-positive. What would be the most appropriate management approach for this patient?

choices.text: Neoadjuvant chemotherapy followed by modified radical mastectomy and adjuvant radiotherapy
Immediate modified radical mastectomy followed by adjuvant chemotherapy and endocrine therapy
Primary endocrine therapy followed by adjuvant chemotherapy and radiotherapy
Neoadjuvant chemotherapy followed by lumpectomy and adjuvant radiotherapy

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Neoadjuvant chemotherapy followed by modified radical mastectomy and adjuvant radiotherapy

 

Explanation:

Management of Locally Advanced Breast Cancer (LABC)

Stages Involved: Stage IIIA, IIIB and IIIC

  • Neoadjuvant Chemotherapy (NACT): Administered before surgery to shrink the tumor, making it operable and allowing for breast conservation if possible.
    • This also helps assess the tumor's response to treatment.
  • Modified Radical Mastectomy (MRM): Performed after neoadjuvant chemotherapy to remove the breast tissue and axillary lymph nodes.
    • The surgery aims to achieve local control and address regional disease.
  • Post-Surgery Radiotherapy (RT): Administered after MRM to reduce the risk of local recurrence and ensure any remaining microscopic disease is treated.

NACT + MRM + RT is the standard approach for LABC to ensure comprehensive treatment. This sequence allows for effective tumor reduction, surgical resection, and post-operative control to prevent a recurrence.

questions.text: A 55 y/o male with poorly controlled diabetes presents with a non-healing corneal ulcer in his right eye, despite two weeks of appropriate antibiotic therapy. The ulcer shows signs of impending perforation with severe thinning of the cornea. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: Increase the frequency of antibiotic eye drops.
Apply a pressure bandage and recommend strict bed rest.
Perform mechanical debridement and apply tissue adhesive glue.
Start topical steroids to reduce inflammation.

questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Perform mechanical debridement and apply tissue adhesive glue

Explanation: 

For impending corneal perforation, necrotic tissue is first removed (mechanical debridement), then tissue adhesive (e.g., cyanoacrylate glue) is applied to seal the thin area and prevent rupture.

  • Mechanical debridement is necessary to remove necrotic material and promote healing in a non-healing ulcer.
  • Tissue adhesive glue is indicated to prevent perforation, especially when the perforation is less than 2mm.


Increasing the frequency of antibiotic eye drops (Option A): At this stage, just increasing frequency won’t be useful.

Applying a pressure bandage and bed rest (Option B): Pressure can worsen thinning and precipitate perforation.

Topical steroids (Option D) are contraindicated as they can worsen the infection.

questions.text: A 75-year-old male patient presents with the following ocular findings and complaints of watering and photophobia. On examination, there are signs of minimal horizontal lid laxity. Which of the following surgical procedures would be the most appropriate for a long-term correction of his condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Weis procedure
 

Explanation:

  • The patient’s symptoms of watering and photophobia, along with the image of an inward-turned lower lid margin, suggest entropion.
  • The most appropriate surgical procedure for correcting entropion with minimal horizontal laxity is the Weis procedure.

 

Involutional Entropion:

Description and etiology
  • Usually seen in lower eyelid in elderly people
  • Horizontal lid laxity due to weakening of orbicularis muscle
  • Vertical lid instability due to weakening of capsulopalpebral fascia
  • Overriding of pretarsal orbicularis/Laxity of orbital septum

Clinical features
  • Foreign body sensation
  • Lacrimation
  • Photophobia
  • Horizontal lid laxity

Surgical Techniques

i. Transverse Suture and Everting Suture: (Option A)

  • Temporary cure (up to 18 months)
  • Suitable for very old patients

ii. Weis procedure: (Option B)

  • Long-term cure with minimal horizontal lid laxity

iii. Plication of Lower Lid Retractors (Jones Operation): (Option C)

  • Used in severe cases or after recurrence
  • Shortens lower lid retractors.

iv. Quickert Procedure: (Option D)

  • For cases with marked horizontal lid laxity
  • Combines horizontal lid shortening with Weis procedure

 

Grading of Entropion:

Grade-I

Only the posterior lid border is in-rolled

Grade-II

includes in-rolling up to the intermarginal strip

Grade-III

Whole lid margin including the anterior border is in-rolled

 

Complications include recurrent corneal abrasions, superficial corneal opacities, corneal vascularisation and even corneal ulceration.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male with a long history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) is prescribed an anticholinergic to help manage his symptoms. At his follow-up appointment, he reports experiencing increased shortness of breath and wheezing shortly after using his inhaler. Which of the following causes paradoxical bronchoconstriction?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Ipratropium

 

Explanation:

  • The occurrence of wheezing and increased shortness of breath after using inhaled anticholinergic in a patient with COPD suggests paradoxical bronchoconstriction.
  • Ipratropium bromide can result in such a presentation.

Mechanism of Bronchoconstriction:

  • Nebulizer: Due to hypotonic solution and antibacterial additives (benzalkonium chloride, EDTA)
  • Metered-dose inhaler (MDI): Possible due to blockade of prejunctional M2 receptors, increasing ACh release

 Tiotropium bromide and other LAMAs have no similar reports of paradoxical bronchoconstriction (Option A, C & D).

questions.text: A 45-year-old hypertensive patient presents to the emergency department with severe chest pain and a rapid heartbeat. His blood pressure is 180/120mmHg. To manage his condition, a Phentolamine is administered. Later, he experiences an allergic reaction, and epinephrine is given to treat this condition. Which of the following best describes the Vasomotor reversal of Dale?

choices.text: Epinephrine administration after phentolamine causes an increased blood pressure.
Epinephrine administration after phentolamine causes decreased blood pressure.
Epinephrine administration after phentolamine causes an increased heart rate.
Epinephrine administration after phentolamine causes decrease in heart rate.

questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Epinephrine administration after phentolamine causes decreased blood pressure.

Explanation:

  • Phentolamine is a non-selective alpha-adrenergic blocker that blocks alpha-1 and alpha-2 receptors, causing vasodilation and decreased peripheral resistance.

  • When epinephrine (which acts on both alpha and beta receptors) is administered after phentolamine blockade, alpha receptors are blocked, so epinephrine’s alpha-mediated vasoconstriction is blocked.

  • Therefore, epinephrine’s beta-2 mediated vasodilation predominates, causing vasodilation and a decrease in blood pressure (paradoxical hypotension).

  • This phenomenon is called the Vasomotor reversal of Dale or the "epinephrine reversal" phenomenon.

Epinephrine administration after phentolamine causes an increased blood pressure (Option A): Incorrect because alpha receptors are blocked, so vasoconstriction is prevented and BP decreases.

Epinephrine administration after phentolamine causes an increased heart rate (Option C): Incorrect as a description of vasomotor reversal; HR does increase but the key feature is BP decrease.

Epinephrine administration after phentolamine causes decrease in heart rate (Option D): Incorrect because heart rate increases due to beta-1 stimulation and reflex tachycardia.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child is brought to the clinic with a cough and difficulty breathing. The mother reports that the child has been lethargic and unable to drink or breastfeed. On examination, you find that the child's oxygen saturation is 88%, and there is stridor when the child is calm. The AVPU scale indicates a response to painful stimuli only. Based on the signs observed, how should this child's condition be classified?

choices.text: Severe Pneumonia or Very Severe Disease

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Severe Pneumonia or Very Severe Disease

 

Explanation:

Assessment and Classification of the Sick Child (Age 2 Months Up to 5 Years)

  • Initial Assessment: A thorough history from the mother is essential
  • Check for General Danger Signs:

Ask

Look

Action
  • Able to drink or breastfeed?
  • Does the child vomit everything?
  • H/O convulsions during this illness?
  • Lethargic or unconscious?
  • Currently convulsing?
  • If any danger signs are present, the child needs URGENT attention.

 

  • Look for chest in-drawing
  • Look and listen for stridor, wheeze
  • Check for central cyanosis
  • Check oxygen saturation
  • Check the AVPU scale (Alert, Voice, Pain, Unresponsive)
  • Assess for possible asthma/TB if wheezing with chest in-drawing or fast breathing is present.

 

Classify the cough:

Classification

Signs

Treatment

Severe Pneumonia or Very Severe Disease

Any general danger sign

OR

  • Oxygen saturation <90%
  • Stridor in a calm child
  • Central cyanosis
  • Convulsions
  • AVPU = V, P, or U
  • Start oxygen therapy if saturation < 90%.
  • Administer Benzyl Penicillin & Gentamicin.
  • Give diazepam if convulsing.
  • Prevent low blood sugar.
  • Treat wheeze if present.
  • Urgent referral or admission.

Pneumonia

Chest indrawing in calm child

OR

Fast breathing

AND

No signs of severe pneumonia
  • Administer Amoxicillin Dispersible Tablet.
  • Give Vitamin A.
  • Treat wheeze if present.
  • Follow up in 5 days
  • Advise on immediate return signs.

No Pneumonia: Cough or Cold

No signs of pneumonia or very severe disease
  • Treat wheeze if present - salbutamol for 5 days
  • Advise on immediate return signs.

questions.text: A 50 year old male with a history of chronic alcohol dependence presents with severe agitation, visual hallucinations, tremors of the tongue and eyelids, and sweating. He reports that he stopped drinking alcohol abruptly three days ago. His vital signs show tachycardia and hypertension. Which of the following management strategies is the most appropriate for his condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Administer benzodiazepines for sedation

Explanation:

  • The patient presents with delirium tremens (DTs), a severe alcohol withdrawal syndrome characterized by:

    • Severe agitation, hallucinations, tremors, autonomic instability (tachycardia, hypertension)

    • Onset: 48–96 hours after alcohol cessation

    • Risk: Seizures, cardiovascular collapse, and death if untreated

  • Benzodiazepines (e.g., diazepam, lorazepam, or chlordiazepoxide) are the first-line treatment as they:

    • Enhance GABAergic inhibition, reducing excitatory overactivity.

    • Prevent progression to seizures and cardiovascular complications.

    • Provide sedation and symptom control.

Management of Alcohol Withdrawal Syndrome

Severity Symptoms Treatment
Mild Anxiety, insomnia, tremors Supportive care, thiamine, hydration
Moderate Tachycardia, hypertension, diaphoresis, hallucinations Benzodiazepines (e.g., lorazepam, diazepam)
Severe (Delirium Tremens) Confusion, hallucinations, seizures, autonomic instability High-dose benzodiazepines, ICU monitoring

Initiate antipsychotic medication (Option A): Incorrect

  • Antipsychotics (e.g., haloperidol) can worsen seizures and prolong withdrawal.

  • Used only as an adjunct for persistent agitation after benzodiazepine administration.

 

Prescribe SSRIs (Option B): Incorrect

  • SSRIs have no role in managing acute alcohol withdrawal or DTs.

  • Mood stabilization is considered after withdrawal resolution.

 

Begin opioid replacement therapy (Option D): Incorrect

  • Opioid therapy is for opioid withdrawal, not alcohol withdrawal.

  • Alcohol withdrawal is managed with benzodiazepines.

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl presents to the clinic with concerns about not having started her menstrual periods. The urine pregnancy test was negative & the physical examination showed normal secondary sexual characteristics. Pelvic ultrasound reveals an absent uterus. What is the best investigation in the workup for this patient?

choices.text: Serum FSH , LH , TSH , PRL levels

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Karyotype analysis
 

Explanation:
In a case where a patient presents with primary amenorrhea, normal secondary sexual characteristics, and an absent uterus on ultrasound, the patient is suspected to have Müllerian agenesis (Mayer-Rokitansky-Küster-Hauser syndrome, 46, XX) or androgen insensitivity syndrome (46, XY).

Thus, the next appropriate step is to perform a karyotype analysis, which is necessary to differentiate between the two.

Serum FSH, LH, TSH, PRL levels (Option A) is incorrect because these are more helpful in patients without secondary sexual characteristics, where hormonal axis dysfunction is suspected (e.g. hypogonadism, pituitary issues). This patient has normal breast development, indicating intact hypothalamic-pituitary-ovarian axis.

MRI pelvis (Option C) is incorrect as a first-line investigation. Although MRI is superior to ultrasound in defining pelvic anatomy and confirming absence or presence of uterine remnants, it does not distinguish MRKH from CAIS and is typically reserved for later evaluation.

Examination of vaginal canal (Option D) is incorrect as the best first test. While it can reveal a short or blind vagina, it does not provide definitive diagnostic information, and may be difficult or invasive in adolescents. Moreover, even in expert centres, genetic testing precedes physical exam findings in ambiguous or complex cases.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman presents with progressively worsening knee pain over the past 6 years. She reports stiffness in the morning that lasts for less than 30 minutes and worsens after prolonged activity. On physical examination, there is tenderness, and swelling in both knees, with reduced range of movements and crepitus. An X-ray of the left knee is shown below. Despite conservative treatment, her pain persists. She is counseled on intra-articular injections. Which of the following is not an option for intra-articular treatment for her condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs (DMARDs)

 

Explanation:

  • The clinical manifestations and X-ray showing joint space narrowing, irregular joint surface, subchondral sclerosis, and osteophyte formation are consistent with a diagnosis of Osteoarthritis.
  • DMARDs target immune and inflammatory pathways to slow disease progression in conditions like Rheumatoid arthritis and are not used in osteoarthritis.

 

X-ray features seen in Osteoarthritis:

Radiological features

Pathology

Joint space narrowing

Focal areas of loss of articular cartilage

Osteophytes

Bone growth at the joint margins

Sclerosis of subchondral bone

Sclerosis of underlying bone

Bone cysts

Cyst formation in underlying bone

Bone attrition

Loss of bone

Apparent effusions

Varying degrees of synovial inflammation

Not visible on radiographs

Fibrosis and thickening of the joint capsule

 

Note: In severe cases, loose bodies are seen.

 

Treatment:

Supportive therapy:

  • Weight reduction
  • Stress management
  • Local heat provides relief of pain and stiffness
  • Quadriceps strengthening exercises - improve stability of the knee joint
  • No unnecessary knee movements.

Medical treatment:

  • Paracetamol
  • Topical NSAIDs
  • Intra-articular injections:
    • Local anesthetic (Option A ruled out)
    • Corticosteroid (Option B ruled out)
    • Hyaluronic acid (Option D ruled out)

Surgical treatment:

  • Osteotomy
  • Joint replacement (Partial or total) - in advanced disease stages
  • Arthroscopic procedures - minimally invasive procedures.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with fatigue, frequent urination, constipation, and confusion. His laboratory results show hypercalcemia and low serum parathyroid hormone level. He reports taking high-dose, over-the-counter vitamin D supplements for the past year. Which of the following conditions is most likely associated with his current presentation?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) Increased risk of hypertension

 

Explanation:

 

 

The patient's symptoms and laboratory findings are consistent with vitamin D toxicity. Excessive vitamin D intake can lead to hypercalcemia, which can manifest as fatigue, frequent urination, constipation, and confusion. Hypercalcemia causes high blood pressure. Vitamin D toxicity also causes low serum parathyroid hormone levels.

Vitamin D Toxicity:

  • Vitamin D toxicity is defined as Adults > 4000 IU and children > 2000 IU.
  • Calcium homeostasis:
    • Hypercalcemia
    • Thickening of the long bones
    • Calcification of soft tissues (Calcinosis).
    • Calcium deposition in Blood vessels (Monckeberg medial calcific sclerosis, atherosclerosis, etc)
  • Hypercalcemia: Contraction of blood vessels and High blood pressure. (Option A)
  • While excessive dietary vitamin D is toxic, overexposure to sunlight does not cause vitamin D poisoning.

Beneficial effects of High Vitamin D status:

  • Protects against prediabetes and metabolic syndrome.(Option D ruled out)
  • Protect against various cancers:
    • Prostate cancer
    • Colorectal cancer (Option B ruled out)
    • Breast cancer (Option C ruled out)

questions.text: A 68-year-old smoker presents with breathing trouble and sudden onset palpitations. The ECG is given below and has an irregular rhythm with an average heart rate of 150 beats per minute. What is the most likely diagnosis based on the ECG findings?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Multifocal Atrial Tachycardia

Explanation:

ECG Shows variable RR interval with P waves that rules out atrial fibrillation. On close observation P waves( vertical arrows) are having variable morphology. The diagnosis is MAT. Smokers develop COPD and resultant hypoxia is the trigger for development of this arrhythmia.

Atrial flutter has saw-tooth waves. Sinus tachycardia has reduced RR interval with T wave and P wave visible independently.

questions.text:
Match the following regulation mechanisms with their respective enzymatic reactions:


	
		
			
			Regulation mechanisms
			
			
			Enzymatic reactions
			
		
		
			
			1. Compartmentation
			
			
			a. Phosphorylation of glycogen phosphorylase
			
		
		
			
			2. Feedback inhibition
			
			
			b. Negative regulation of phosphofructokinase by ATP
			
		
		
			
			3. Covalent modification
			
			
			c. Segregation of glycolytic enzymes in the cytosol
			
		
		
			
			4. Proteolytic activation
			
			
			d. Activation of pepsinogen to pepsin
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) 1 - c, 2 - b, 3 - a, 4 - d

 

Explanation:

 

Regulation mechanisms

Enzymatic reactions

1. Compartmentation

c. Segregation of glycolytic enzymes in the cytosol

2. Feedback inhibition

b. Negative regulation of phosphofructokinase by ATP

3. Covalent modification

a. Phosphorylation of glycogen phosphorylase

4. Proteolytic activation

d. Activation of pepsinogen to pepsin


 

Regulatory Mechanism

Description

Examples

Compartmentation

Separating metabolic processes into different cellular compartments to regulate their activity.
  • Segregation of glycolytic enzymes in the cytosol.
  • Separation of fatty acid oxidation in the mitochondria from fatty acid synthesis in the cytosol.

Feedback Inhibition

A molecule decreases the activity of an enzyme.
  • Negative regulation of phosphofructokinase by ATP.
  • Inhibition of acetyl-CoA carboxylase by palmitoyl-CoA in fatty acid synthesis.

Covalent Modification

Addition or removal of a covalent bond of a chemical group to alter an enzyme's activity.
  • Phosphorylation of glycogen phosphorylase.
  • Acetylation of histones affecting gene expression.

Proteolytic Activation

Converting an inactive enzyme precursor into its active form through proteolytic cleavage.
  • Activation of pepsinogen to pepsin.
  • Activation of trypsinogen to trypsin.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presents for a routine physical exam. He has a history of cryptorchidism corrected by orchidopexy in childhood. What is his relative risk of developing testicular cancer compared to the general population?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) 3.7 to 7.5 times higher

 

Explanation:

Cryptorchidism increases the risk of developing testicular cancer by 3.7 to 7.5 times, even after surgical correction.

 

Testicular tumor- risk factors

Major Risk Factors
  • Cryptorchidism: Most significant risk factor, increasing risk by 3.7 to 7.5 times, even after surgical correction (orchidopexy). 
  • Family History: 3.1-fold increased risk for first-degree relatives, 6.3-fold for brothers.
  • Male Factor Infertility: Includes conditions like Klinefelter syndrome.
  • Personal History: Previous contralateral tumor or germ cell neoplasia in situ (GCNIS).
  • Maternal and Perinatal Factors: Low birth weight, perinatal inguinal hernia, maternal age at conception, and exposure to diethylstilbestrol (DES) during pregnancy.

Additional Risk Factors
  • Age: Most common in men aged 20–35; smaller peak after age 80.
  • Ethnicity: Highest incidence in Caucasian men, followed by Hispanics, Asians, and African-Americans..
  • Age at Puberty: Early puberty may increase risk; late puberty may be protective.
  • Genetic Conditions: Increased risk associated with Klinefelter syndrome and Down syndrome.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents to the clinic with complaints of chronic abdominal pain and significant weight loss over the past year. He reports frequent, bulky and foul-smelling stools. His medical history is significant for alcohol abuse over the past 20 years. Laboratory investigations reveal normal LFT, and imaging studies show calcifications in the pancreas. Considering the patient's clinical presentation and medical history, which of the following is the most appropriate treatment?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Lipase and trypsin

 

Explanation:

  • In chronic pancreatitis, there is progressive loss of pancreatic exocrine function affecting all three major enzymes — lipase, amylase, and proteases (trypsin).

  • Fat malabsorption is the most clinically significant due to lipase deficiency, but protein digestion is also impaired due to reduced protease (trypsin) secretion.

  • Therefore, enzyme replacement therapy should ideally include both lipase and protease (trypsin) to address malabsorption of fats and proteins.

  • Amylase supplementation is generally not needed, as carbohydrate digestion is less affected and often compensated by salivary amylase and brush border enzymes.

  • Hence, combined lipase and trypsin supplementation is more appropriate than lipase alone.

Aspect Details
Clinical Presentation Chronic abdominal pain, steatorrhea, weight loss, pancreatic calcifications
Etiology Chronic alcohol abuse causing chronic pancreatitis
Enzyme Deficiency Lipase (fat digestion), proteases like trypsin (protein digestion)
Treatment Pancreatic enzyme replacement therapy with lipase and protease (trypsin)

 

Lipase only (Option A): Incorrect because protein digestion impairment also contributes to malnutrition; protease replacement improves overall digestion and nutrition.

Amylase only (Option B): Incorrect because carbohydrate digestion is usually preserved; amylase replacement is unnecessary.

Proteinase and amylase (Option D): Incorrect because lipase replacement is critical for fat digestion; omission of lipase would fail to treat steatorrhea.

questions.text:
Match the following terms and definitions with


	
		
			
			Terms
			
			
			Definitions
			
		
		
			
			1. Demographic Burden
			
			
			a) Period of decrease in the dependency ratio
			
		
		
			
			2. Demographic Bonus
			
			
			b) Indicates a rise in the total dependency ratio
			
		
		
			
			3. Demographic Window
			
			
			c) Increase in economic growth rate
			
		
		
			
			4. Demographic Dividend
			
			
			d) Peak working-age population phase
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 1-b, 2-a, 3-d, 4-c

 

Explanation:

  • Demographic Burden
    • Refers to the increase in the proportion of the dependent population relative to the economically productive population.
    • It signifies the societal challenge of supporting a larger dependent population, which typically occurs due to aging demographics.
  • Demographic Bonus
    • A phase in a nation's demographic evolution in which the proportion of the dependent population relative to the working-age population declines.
    • This is often associated with economic growth opportunities as more people are in the workforce than dependents.
  • Demographic Window: Refers to a period in a nation's demographic structure when the proportion of the population in the working-age group is at its highest.
  • Demographic Dividend: An increase in economic growth driven by a growing proportion of working-age individuals in the population.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of the Boer-Meisel prognostic system?

choices.text: Extent & severity of acute pelvic infection.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Extent & severity of acute pelvic infection.

 

Explanation:

The Boer-Meisel prognostic system plays a crucial role in helping clinicians and patients make informed decisions regarding the management of tubal infertility. It was described by Boer-Meisel & coworkers to prognosticate the chances of successful intrauterine pregnancy in patients with hydrosalpinx, following tubal reconstructive surgery. It scores the extent & severity of tubal damage.

Components of the Boer-Meisel system:

  • Extent of adhesions. (Option A)
  • Nature of adhesions (filmy or dense).
  • Size of hydrosalpinx. (Option C)
  • Macroscopic condition of the endosalpinx.
  • Thickness of tubal wall. (Option B)

 

Gainesville’s staging for PID, classifies acute PID in four clinical stages, depending on the extent of involvement & clinical severity:

Stage

Description

I

Acute endometritis/salpingitis without peritonitis and no adhesions

II

Acute salpingitis with peritonitis and purulent discharge from tubal ostia

III

Acute salpingitis with superimposed tubal occlusion or tubo-ovarian complex

IV

Ruptured tubo-ovarian abscess

V

Tubercular salpingitis

questions.text: 20-year-old patient with T1DM comes for a follow up visit. Which of the following is the earliest finding in diabetic nephropathy?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A – Hyperfiltration:

  • Hyperfiltration is the earliest functional change in diabetic nephropathy and may precede any proteinuria.

Pathophysiology of hyperfiltration in diabetic nephropathy

  1. Chronic hyperglycemia leads to increased filtered glucose. Proximal tubules increase Na⁺–glucose cotransport and hence more Na⁺ reabsorbed in proximal tubule
  2. Because more Na⁺ is reabsorbed proximally, less Na⁺ reaches the macula densa
  3. Macula densa “senses” this as reduced perfusion and triggers afferent arteriolar dilation via adenosine/NO imbalance.
  4. Macula densa also activates RAAS system causing efferent arteriole vasoconstriction
  5. Afferent arteriolar dilation and efferent arteriole vasoconstriction will increase glomerular pressure causing hyperfiltration.

questions.text: A 78-year-old male patient presents to the emergency department with features of acute deep vein thrombosis. The patient has a history of atrial fibrillation and chronic kidney disease. He is currently on anticoagulant therapy. Which set of anticoagulants is safe to use in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Warfarin and unfractionated heparin

 

Explanation:

  • Warfarin and unfractionated heparin are safe for patients with chronic kidney disease.

 

Drug

Excretion

Safety in renal disease

Warfarin

(Vitamin K antagonist)

Hepatic excretion

Safe

Unfractionated heparin

(High molecular weight heparin)

Reticuloendothelial cells and hepatic excretion

Safe

Fondaparinux

(Ultra-low molecular weight heparin)

Renal excretion

Unsafe

Dabigatran

(Direct thrombin inhibitor)

Renal excretion

Unsafe

Rivaroxaban

(Direct factor Xa inhibitor)

Renal and hepatic excretion

Unsafe

 

Warfarin and Fondaparinux (Option A): Fondaparinux is contraindicated or requires dose adjustment in CKD due to renal clearance, increasing bleeding risk.

Unfractionated heparin and Dabigatran (Option C): Dabigatran is renally excreted and unsafe in significant CKD.

Rivaroxaban and Fondaparinux (Option D): Both drugs are renally cleared and unsafe in patients with severe CKD.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old woman presents with a chronic productive cough and recurrent episodes of foul-smelling sputum and hemoptysis. A high-resolution CT (HRCT) of the chest is shown below.



Which of the following radiological signs is most characteristic of the condition seen in this image?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Tram track sign

 

Explanation:

The clinical feature of chronic productive cough with recurrent foul-smelling sputum and hemoptysis suggests chronic suppurative lung disease. This, along with the characteristic "tram track sign" seen on high-resolution CT, points towards a diagnosis of bronchiectasis.

 

Radiographic Findings of Bronchiectasis:

  • Tramline Sign/Tram track sign (Option C): Thickened bronchial walls seen as single thick lines or parallel line opacities.
  • Cystic bronchiectasis: Multiple thin-walled ring shadows with air-fluid levels.

Computed Tomographic (CT) Findings:

  • Major sign: Bronchial dilation, with or without bronchial wall thickening.
  • Lack of tapering of bronchial lumina.
  • Signet ring sign: Bronchial diameter greater than the adjacent pulmonary artery.
  • Glove-finger/V/Y-shaped densities: Represent mucus-filled dilated bronchi.
  • Tree-in-bud sign (Option A):
    • More commonly seen with endobronchial spread of tuberculosis.
    • Also seen in bronchiolitis as small nodular and branching opacities. 

 

Ground-glass opacities (Option B) are hazy areas of increased lung opacity with preserved bronchial and vascular markings, typically seen in interstitial lung diseases, viral infections, or pulmonary edema, not in airway dilation.

Air bronchogram (Option D) refers to air-filled bronchi visible within opacified alveolar regions, seen in alveolar consolidation such as pneumonia, not in bronchial wall thickening or dilation.

questions.text:
A neonate on examination has bilateral cataracts and, after investigations, is found to have a patent ductus arteriosus. The baby had a low birth weight and is diagnosed with congenital rubella syndrome. On examination, the retina appears as follows.



 

 

Which of the following retinal changes is seen here?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Salt and pepper retinopathy

 

Explanation:

The retinal change seen in congenital rubella is “salt and pepper” retinopathy.


 

Congenital rubella
  • Rubella (German measles) is a mild disease in infants and children but can cause congenital rubella syndrome (CRS) if contracted during pregnancy.
  • The risk is highest in the first trimester, especially within the first 8 weeks.

Pathogenesis

  • Viremia is most intense from 10 to 17 days after infection.
  • Viral shedding is from day 10 of infection up to 2 weeks.

Risk of Defects by Gestational Age
  • Highest in the first 12 weeks of gestation and decreases significantly thereafter, with defects being rare after 20 weeks.

Clinical features of congenital rubella syndrome
  • Hearing loss (most common)
  • Vision problems (cataracts, glaucoma, salt and pepper retinopathy).
    • Cataracts are the most common ocular abnormality associated with congenital rubella.

  • Heart defects (patent ductus arteriosus > pulmonary artery stenosis (right > left) > ventricular septal defect)
  • Low birth weight
  • Neurological issues (microcephaly, intellectual disabilities, encephalitis, behavioral issues)

Chronicity and Complications
  • Chronic presence of the virus can cause ongoing damage
  • The risk of progressive rubella panencephalitis (PRP) years later is a rare complication.
  • Less common complications: Growth retardation, hepatitis, bone lesions.
  • Risk of diabetes and thyroid dysfunction

Diagnosis
  • Rubella IgM enzyme immunosorbent assay (detects antibodies)
  • Viral isolation (growing the virus from samples)
  • Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) (detects viral RNA)

Management
  • No specific treatment for CRS; supportive care is key
  • Early intervention for complications (e.g., hearing loss) is crucial

Prevention
  • Standard with droplet precaution in hospitalized cases
  • Rubella vaccination RA 27/3 live attenuated vaccine (MMR or MMRV with varicella) effectively prevents rubella and CRS
  • MMR vaccine has a 95% efficacy after one dose and 99% after two doses
  • Vaccination side effects: fever, rash, joint pain

Considerations for Pregnant Women
  • Immunoglobulin may be considered if pregnancy is not terminated, though it does not guarantee prevention of fetal infection

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT an inhibitor of Carnitine Acyl Transferase-1 (CAT-1)?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) AMPK

Explanation:

AMPK activation leads to increased fatty acid oxidation by promoting mitochondrial biogenesis and improving fatty acid metabolism. It is a metabolic regulator that often enhances Carnitine Acyl Transferase-1 (CAT-1)/ Carnitine Palmitoyl Transferase-1 CPT-1 activity rather than inhibiting it.

 

CARNITINE ACYL TRANSFERASE-1 (CPT-1)

STIMULATORS

INHIBITORS
  • Starvation
  • FFA (Free Fatty Acids)
  • AMPK (Adenosine Monophosphate-Activated Protein Kinase)
  • Glucagon
  • Well fed state
  • Malonyl-CoA (Option B ruled out)
  • Sulfonylureas (Option A ruled out)
  • Insulin (Option D ruled out)
  • Etomoxir
  • Oxfenicine
  • Perhexiline
  • PPARα antagonist

Match the following items with its corresponding Hounsfield Unit
