questions.text: A 35-year-old male patient is admitted to the hospital with high fever, chills, and severe headache. Upon examination and laboratory tests, he is diagnosed with P.falciparum malaria. The patient's medical history reveals that he has schizophrenia and is currently on antipsychotic medication. Considering the patient's medical history, which of the following antimalarial treatments is contraindicated for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Mefloquine

Explanation:

  • Mefloquine is contraindicated in patients with a history of psychiatric disorders such as schizophrenia.
  • Mefloquine can exacerbate psychiatric symptoms, potentially leading to severe psychiatric reactions, including anxiety, paranoia, depression, hallucinations, and even suicidal thoughts.

questions.text: Below is a graph showing the results of a screening test. If the cut-off point is reduced from point B to A, what will be its effect on this screening test?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Sensitivity increases

 

Explanation:

 

  • In a screening test, if the cut-off value that differentiates normal and diseased populations is changed from point B to point A on the curve [ie. Value reduced] the test's sensitivity will be increased [i.e. high true positives], but specificity will be reduced [high false positives].
  • If the cut-off is increased from point A to point B, sensitivity is reduced, and specificity is increased.

questions.text: A 58 year old man is diagnosed with an adenocarcinoma located 4 cm below the gastroesophageal junction. According to the Siewert classification system, what type of tumour does he have, and how should it be treated if it does not extend into the GE junction?

choices.text: Type I; treated as esophageal adenocarcinoma
Type II; treated as gastric adenocarcinoma
Type III; treated as gastric adenocarcinoma
Type III; treated as esophageal adenocarcinoma

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Type III; treated as gastric adenocarcinoma

 

Explanation:

Type III tumors are located between 2 and 5 cm below the GE junction and are treated according to guidelines for gastric adenocarcinoma, provided they do not extend into the GE junction.


 

Type

Adenocarcinoma around cardia

Location

Type I (Option A)

Distal esophagus

1-5cm above the cardia 

Type II (Option B)

Real Cardia

1cm above and 2cm below cardia 

Type III (Option C)

Sub-cardial stomach

2-5cm below cardia

 

Type III; treated as esophageal adenocarcinoma (Option D), Type III tumors are treated as gastric adenocarcinoma if they do not involve the GE junction.

questions.text: A doctor is called to testify in court regarding a postmortem examination they conducted. The doctor is asked to present and verify certain medical records as evidence. Under which section of the Bharatiya Nyaya Sanhita, 2023 (BNS) can the doctor be held accountable if they provide false information while under oath, in relation to evidence during legal proceedings?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Section 229

 

Explanation:

Section 229, BSA deals with punishment for false evidence.

  • If a person, while under oath in a judicial proceeding, deliberately gives false evidence, they can be charged under Section 229.
  • In this scenario, if the doctor provides false testimony regarding medical records, they can be held accountable under this section.
  • It prescribes imprisonment of up to seven years and a fine for giving false evidence during legal proceedings.

 

The Bharatiya Nyaya Sanhita, 2023 (BNS) Sections Related to Evidence:

BNS Section

Description

227

Defines perjury (willful false statement after taking an oath)

228

Defines fabricating false evidence.

229

Punishment for false evidence, including giving false testimony under oath (imprisonment up to 7 years and a fine).

234

Issuing or signing a false certificate is considered giving false evidence and is punishable under Sec. 229, BSA

238

refers to causing the disappearance of evidence of an offense or providing false information about it.

239

deals with the intentional omission to provide information about an offense by someone who is legally required to do so

241

The section deals with the destruction of a document or electronic record to prevent its production as evidence.

 

Section 238 BSA (Option B):

  • This section refers to causing the disappearance of evidence of an offense or providing false information about it.

 

Section 227 BSA (Option C):

  • This section defines perjury but does not directly assign punishment.

 

Section 241 BSA (Option D):

  • This section deals with the destruction of a document or electronic record to prevent its production as evidence.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male complains of double vision, describing seeing two overlapping images when looking in a specific direction. He reports that this problem started suddenly about two weeks ago and is most noticeable when looking towards the right side. There is no history of trauma. On examination, he has limited movement of the right eye towards the right. What is the most likely cause of this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Paralytic strabismus

 

Explanation:

  • The given scenario is diagnosed as binocular diplopia most commonly caused by paralysis of extra ocular muscles (paralytic strabismus).
  • Diplopia refers to the simultaneous perception of two images of a single object. It can be classified in the following ways,

 

1. It is classified as:

2. It can also be classified as,

  • Horizontal diplopia
  • Vertical diplopia
  • Torsional diplopia

 

Causes of diplopia:

Uniocular diplopia

Binocular diplopia
  • Subluxation of lens (Option C)
  • Polycoria (multiple pupils)
  • Incipient cataract
  • Keratoconus
  • Paralysis of extraocular muscles (e.g. paralytic strabismus) (Option D)
  • Orbital lesions
  • Orbital fractures (e.g. blowout fracture) (Option A)
  • Thick pterygium (Option B)
  • Symblepharon
  • Thyroid ophthalmopathy
  • Decentred spectacles
  • Anisometropia

questions.text: A 3-year-old girl presents with severe diarrhoea, sunken eyes, and lethargy. She's unable to drink and has cool, mottled extremities. You decide to start IV fluids immediately. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial IV fluid choice?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Ringer's Lactate with 5% Dextrose

 

Explanation:

  • Ringer's Lactate with 5% Dextrose is commonly used for treating severe dehydration in children. It offers a balanced electrolyte composition similar to plasma, helps correct acidosis, and includes glucose to prevent hypoglycemia.
  • Rapid intravenous rehydration is crucial. The total fluid volume is typically 100 mL/kg.
    • For children >12 months: Administer over 3-4 hours.
    • For infants <12 months: Administer over 6-8 hours.

 

5% Dextrose solution (Option A) provides glucose but lacks adequate electrolytes and does not effectively correct acidosis or replace lost fluids in cases of severe dehydration.

 

Normal Saline (Option B) is useful for initial fluid resuscitation but does not correct acidosis and is less balanced in electrolytes than Ringer's Lactate.

 

Half-normal saline (Option C) contains lower sodium and chloride concentrations and does not correct acidosis, making it unsuitable for severe dehydration.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is not true regarding the decriminalisation of suicide in India as per the Mental Healthcare Act, 2017?

choices.text: Suicide attempts were decriminalised as per IPC Section 309
The act provides treatment instead of punishment for suicide attempts.
Individuals who attempt suicide are presumed to have severe stress under the Act.
The Act encourages individuals to seek help without fear of legal consequences.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Suicide attempts were decriminalised as per IPC Section 309

 

Explanation:

  • Prior to the Mental Healthcare Act, 2017
  • Indian Penal Code (IPC) Section 309:
    • Attempting suicide was historically a criminal offence in India, punishable by imprisonment, fine, or both.
    • This criminalisation treated suicide attempts as violations of law rather than issues of mental health.

 

Change with the Mental Healthcare Act, 2017

  • Section 115 explicitly states that individuals who attempt suicide shall not be punished under IPC Section 309. (Option B ruled out)
  • Instead, they are presumed to be experiencing severe stress linked to mental illness (Option C ruled out) and should receive care, treatment, and rehabilitation to prevent recurrence.
  • This shift promotes a compassionate, health-centric approach, emphasizing the need for psychiatric help rather than imprisonment.
  • Mental healthcare professionals are now mandated to provide appropriate psychosocial support and treatment for underlying mental health conditions.
  • This act also helps reduce the stigma associated with mental illness, encouraging individuals to seek help without fear of legal repercussions. (Option D ruled out)

questions.text:
A 65-year-old man with a history of coronary artery disease and heart failure presents to the emergency department after experiencing lightheadedness and near syncope. On examination, he is alert but pale, with a heart rate of 43 beats per minute and a blood pressure of 80/50 mmHg. The ECG is shown below. He remains hypotensive and symptomatic despite the IV administration of a maximum dose of atropine. What is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?



{{caption_text}}
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Dopamine IV infusion

 

Explanation:

  • The clinical presentation and ECG suggesting sinus bradycardia without evidence of heart block are consistent with symptomatic sinus bradycardia with hypotension.
  • After atropine fails, the next step in the management is dopamine infusion.

 

Adult bradycardia algorithm

Epinephrine IV bolus (Option A): The recommendation is IV infusion and not as a bolus administration of the drug.

 

Amiodarone IV infusion (Option B) and digoxin IV bolus (Option D): They are not used in treating bradyarrhythmias.

questions.text: A 10-month-old infant came to the clinic for a regular follow-up visit. He missed his most recent vaccine, which was scheduled for 9 months. According to the National Immunization Schedule, which of the following vaccines is not administered to a 10-month-old infant?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) DPT

 

Explanation:

DPT Vaccine: The primary DPT series is given at 6, 10, and 14 weeks, and the first booster dose is scheduled at 16-24 months. Therefore, DPT is not given at 9 or 10 months.

National Immunization Schedule:

  • The National Immunization Schedule (NIS) in India provides a structured guideline for vaccination to protect children against various infectious diseases.
  • The schedule includes primary series, booster doses, and catch-up immunization strategies.
Age Vaccine
At Birth BCG, Hepatitis B (Birth dose), OPV (0 dose)
6 Weeks DPT-1, IPV-1, Hepatitis B-1, Hib-1, Rotavirus-1, PCV-1
10 Weeks DPT-2, IPV-2, Hepatitis B-2, Hib-2, Rotavirus-2, PCV-2
14 Weeks DPT-3, IPV-3, Hepatitis B-3, Hib-3, Rotavirus-3, PCV-3
6 Months Vitamin A (first dose)
9 Months Measles-1, PCV Booster, JE-1 (in endemic areas)
16-24 Months DPT Booster-1, IPV Booster, Measles-2, Vitamin A (second dose)
5-6 Years DPT Booster-2, OPV Booster
10 Years Tetanus and Diphtheria (Td)
16 Years Tetanus and Diphtheria (Td)

 

  • Measles Vaccine(Option A): Scheduled at 9 months as per the National Immunization Schedule (NIS) in India., If missed, it should be administered as soon as possible.

  • Pneumococcal Conjugate Vaccine (PCV) (Option C): Incorrect; primary doses completed earlier; no routine dose scheduled exactly at 10 months. Booster: Given at 9 months, and if missed, can still be administered at 10 months.

questions.text: Alcoholic went for a party and did binge drinking. He developed coffee ground vomitus episodes and developed cold clammy extremities. Post volume resuscitation UGI endoscopy was done revealed a ulcer in first part of duodenum. Which of the tests will be done to determine the aetiology of this presentation?

choices.text: Doppler to measure portal vein pressure

questions.solution:
Correct answer is B: Urease test

  • Duodenal ulcers are most commonly caused by Helicobacter pylori infection, especially in a context of acute upper GI bleeding. The urease test detects H. pylori, which produces urease enzyme.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Ultrasound abdomen for liver echotexture: Useful for alcoholic liver disease and check for ascites, splenomegaly which indicate portal hypertension.

Option C - Doppler to measure portal vein pressure : This is ruled out as question itself mentions ulcer in D1. 

Option D - Oesophageal manometry: Used for motility disorders, not for ulcer aetiology.

questions.text:
Match the following Thyroid scan images with respective conditions:

 


	
		
			 
			1.
			
			
			A. Graves Disease
			
		
		
			
			 

			2.
			
			
			B. Cold nodule
			
		
		
			 
			3.
			
			
			C. Hot Nodule
			
		
		
			
			 

			4.
			
			
			D. Toxic Multinodular Goiter
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 1-C, 2-A, 3-D, 4-B

 

Explanation:

 

 

Normal Thyroid: Uniform uptake

Hot Nodules (Image 1):

  • Increased uptake in specific areas
  • Often benign and indicate hyperfunctioning tissue.
  • Risk of Malignancy: 1-3%

Cold Nodules (Image 4):

  • Reduced uptake in specific areas
  • Risk of Malignancy: 17-20%

Grave’s Disease (Image 2): Increased uptake throughout the thyroid gland, showing heightened overall activity (Diffuse goiter) 

Toxic Multinodular Goiter (Image 3):

  • Multiple areas of varying uptake
  • Some nodules might show increased activity (Hot Nodules)
  • Some might show decreased activity (Cold Nodules)

Thyroiditis (Inflammation of the Thyroid): Decreased uptake throughout the areas of inflammation due to follicular destruction.

questions.text:
Which of the following is most likely based on the lab values given?


	Blood pH: 7.32
	Na+: 130mEq/L
	K+: 2.8 mEq/L
	Cl: 110 mEq/L
	HCO3: 12 mEq/L
	Urea: 25 mg/dL
	Creatinine: 0.6 mg/dL
	Urinary pH: 9.4
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - RTA 1:

  • Report shows metabolic acidosis with hypokalemia. This will rule out RTA 4. Now we have to select between RTA 1 and RTA 2 as both have hypokalemia with metabolic acidosis.
  • In RTA 1 due to inability to acidify urine, patient will have urine pH> 5.5 in spite of acidemia. Since urine pH given is 9.4, the answer is RTA 1
  • In contrast RTA 2 has bicarbonate loss in urine causing so much of depletion of bicarbonate in body that urine pH remains less than 5.5.

questions.text: 50-year-old man presents with severe cough for 3 months and hemoptysis episodes for past 3 days. Physical examination shows hypertension, purple abdominal wall striae, changes in hands as shown. Endobronchial lung biopsy is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely cause in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Carcinoid tumor 

  • Clinical history points to diagnosis of cushing syndrome due to ectopic source.
  • Cushing features are hyperpigmentation of knuckes and IP joints with purpule striae on anterior abdominal wall, hypertension and centripetal obesity. 
  • Endobronchial biopsy report shows organoid nests of uniform cells and the nuclei with “salt and pepper” chromatin.
  • Oat cell cancer cells will be disorganised mass of cells with nuclei that will always looked crushed and squeezed. 

 

Carcinoid Tumor (Left Slide)

  • Uniform cells with abundant cytoplasm, round nuclei, and “salt and pepper” chromatin pattern.

  • Cells arranged in nesting or trabecular pattern with minimal mitosis and necrosis.

Oat Cell Cancer / Small Cell Lung Carcinoma (Right Slide)

  • Small round cells with scant cytoplasm, hyperchromatic nuclei, and nuclear molding.

  • Shows high mitotic activity, frequent necrosis, and crush artifacts due to fragile cells.

questions.text: A 29-year-old pregnant woman in her third trimester is evaluated by her obstetrician for routine prenatal care. She reports occasional palpitations and mild shortness of breath but has no significant past medical history. The physician explains that these symptoms can be related to normal cardiac changes in pregnancy. Which of the following is a physiological cardiac change typically observed during pregnancy?

choices.text: Decreased cardiac output due to reduced blood volume
Increased systemic vascular resistance leading to hypertension
Increased cardiac output primarily due to increased heart rate and stroke volume
Decreased heart rate due to increased vagal tone

questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Increased cardiac output primarily due to increased heart rate and stroke volume


Explanation:
During pregnancy, the heart rate increases by up to 17%, and the stroke volume increases by up to 27%. As a result of this, Cardiac Output increases as

  • Cardiac Output = Heart Rate x Stroke Volume.

Decreased cardiac output due to reduced blood volume (Option A): Cardiac output is not decreased, but it is increased in pregnancy

Increased systemic vascular resistance leading to hypertension (Option B): There is a decrease in systemic vascular resistance, so BP falls during pregnancy.

Decreased heart rate due to increased vagal tone (Option D): There is increase in heart rate during pregnancy.

questions.text:
Which of the following factors plays a crucial role in determining the severity of pneumoconiosis in individuals exposed to mineral dust?

1) Fineness of particles

2) Chemical composition

3) Concentration of dust in the air

4) Period of exposure
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 1,2,3,4

 

Explanation: 

Factors influencing pneumoconiosis:

Factor

Description

Chemical Composition

Different dust types have varying toxicity levels; silica and asbestos are particularly harmful.

Fineness of Particles

Finer particles can penetrate deeper into the lungs, causing more severe damage over time.

Concentration of Dust in the Air

Higher concentrations increase the likelihood and severity of respiratory issues upon inhalation.

Period of Exposure

Longer exposure durations, especially at high concentrations, increase cumulative lung damage.

Health Status of the Person Exposed

Pre-existing lung diseases like Asthma, COPD, smokers and immune status affect susceptibility.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman at 41 weeks and 5 days of gestation presents to the labor with complaints of decreased fetal movements. The urine protein on dipstick is negative. USG reveals a small for gestational age fetus in cephalic presentation, with AFI-5 cm, placenta is fundal. All of the following are done in managing this patient except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Immediate cesarean section

Explanation:

Initiation of fetal surveillance should be done beginning at 41 weeks of gestation.

  • Fetal surveillance (Nonstress test, Amniotic fluid volume estimation, Biophysical profile, Doppler velocimetry study)(Option B)

Induction of labor: (Option C)

  • Cervix ripe: Stripping of membranes → ARM → Liquor clear → Oxytocin drip → Expected vaginal delivery.
  • Cervix unripe: Vaginal administration of PGE2 gel (6 hourly) → Cervix ripe → ARM → Liquor clear → Oxytocin drip → Expected vaginal delivery.

Unfavourable cervix and cephalopelvic disproportion, if present, prompt immediate cesarean delivery(C-Section is done in obstetric conditions).

questions.text: A 50 y/o man undergoes Jones Test 1 for chronic tearing, which shows no dye on the cotton bud placed in the inferior meatus. Following this, Jones Test 2 is performed, and fluorescein dye is detected after lacrimal syringing. What does this result suggest?

choices.text: Partial obstruction within the lacrimal passages
Complete obstruction of the nasolacrimal duct

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Partial obstruction within the lacrimal passages

 

Explanation:

  • A positive Jones Test 2 indicates that the fluorescein dye was able to enter the lacrimal sac but could not reach the nasal cavity without syringing.
  • This finding is typical of a partial blockage somewhere along the lacrimal drainage system, allowing some tear flow but not enough for normal drainage.

Jones Test 1:

  • Purpose: To distinguish between partial obstruction and excessive tear production.
  • Procedure: Fluorescein dye is placed in the conjunctival sac, and after 5 minutes, a cotton bud soaked in anaesthetic is placed in the inferior meatus inside the nose. The cotton bud is checked for dye.
  • Interpretation:
    • Positive: Dye on the cotton bud indicates patent tear drainage and suggests hypersecretion.
    • Negative: No dye indicates potential drainage issues, requiring further testing with Jones Test.

Jones Test 2:

  • Purpose: Performed if Jones Test 1 is negative to differentiate between partial obstruction and pump failure.
  • Procedure: Lacrimal syringing is done while the cotton bud remains in the nose.
  • Interpretation:
    • Positive: Dye flushed onto the cotton bud indicates partial obstruction.
    • Negative: No dye suggests lacrimal pump failure.

 

Complete obstruction of the nasolacrimal duct (Option B):

  • In the case of a complete obstruction, the dye would not move at all, even with syringing.
  • Therefore, no dye would be detected in the nose after jones test 2, which is different from the positive result in this patient.

 

Lacrimal pump failure (Option C) would result in a negative Jones Test 2, meaning that the dye wouldn't move into the nose even with syringing, because the pumping action of the lacrimal system is impaired.

 

Primary hypersecretion of tears (Option D) would present with a positive Jones Test 1, where the dye would naturally pass through the lacrimal system and into the nose without any obstruction.

  • A negative Jones Test 1 followed by a positive Jones Test 2 makes this diagnosis unlikely.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man reports to his doctor that he is having difficulty achieving an erection during intercourse. He mentions this issue has been ongoing for the past year, despite having previously enjoyed a healthy sex life. Which statement about his condition is TRUE?

choices.text: Erectile dysfunction is common in all ageing men.
Phosphodiesterase-5 inhibitors can be safely used with nitrates.
Situational erectile disorder means he can achieve erections in certain situations.
Organic Erectile Dysfunction occurs in men with relationship issues.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Situational erectile disorder means he can achieve erections in certain situations.

Explanation:

Situational erectile disorder allows for erections in specific circumstances.

 

Erectile Dysfunction

  • Incidence increases with age; reported in 2-8% of young adults and is more common in older men.
  • Not universal in aging; factors like having a partner and consistent sexual activity are protective. (Option A)
  • Episodes of erectile disorder can increase anxiety in future sexual encounters.

 

Causes:

  • Organic Causes: Due to medical conditions or medications.
    • Medical Conditions: Cardiovascular diseases (hypertension, atherosclerosis, coronary artery disease), Diabetes mellitus, Neurological disorders (multiple sclerosis, Parkinson's disease, spinal cord injuries), Endocrine disorders (hypogonadism, hyperprolactinemia, thyroid dysfunction), Chronic kidney disease, Liver cirrhosis, Pelvic or prostate surgeries, Sleep disorders (obstructive sleep apnea).
    • Medications: Antihypertensives (beta-blockers, thiazide diuretics), Antidepressants (SSRIs, tricyclic antidepressants), Antipsychotics (typical and atypical), Anti-androgens (finasteride, spironolactone), Opioids, Chemotherapy agents, Anticonvulsants, H2-receptor antagonists (cimetidine).
  • Psychogenic Causes: More common in young and middle-aged men; often related to psychological factors such as fear, anxiety, or relationship issues. (Option D)

 

Types of Male Erectile Disorder:

  1. Lifelong Male Erectile Disorder:
    • Never able to achieve an erection sufficient for insertion. (Option B)
    • Rare, occurring in about 1% of men under 35.
  2. Acquired Male Erectile Disorder:
    • Previously able to achieve penetration but later unable to do so.
    • Affects 10-20% of all men.
  3. Situational Male Erectile Disorder:
    • Able to have erections in certain situations (e.g., with a sex worker) but not with a partner.

 

Investigations used to record nocturnal erections are:

  • Nocturnal penile tumescence
  • Penile plethysmography (which measures blood pressure in the penis).

These are used to differentiate between organic and psychogenic erectile dysfunction.

 

Treatment of Erectile Dysfunction

Pharmacotherapy

Phosphodiesterase-5 inhibitors (PDE-5 inhibitors)

  • Nitric oxide enhancers- facilitates blood flow into the penis and enhances erection.
  • Drugs- Sildenafil, tadalafil, vardenafil and Avanafil.
  • Not used along with organic nitrates- Can cause sudden fall in blood pressure and can be fatal. (Option B)

Other medications:

  • Oral phentolamine: May reduce sympathetic tone and relax muscles of corpora cavernosa and subsequently improve the erection.
  • Alprostadil contains naturally occurring prostaglandin E (vasodilating agent).
  • Alprostadil- Directly injected into corpora cavernosa or given intraurethral through a cannula as a pellet.

Psychotherapy

Dual sex therapy:

  • It was derived by Masters and Johnson.
  • It is also effective for other sexual disorders as well.
  • It means it treats the couple (not individual). Both the partners are involved in the treatment.
  • Couples are taught: To improve their communication and Exercises to increase sensory awareness.

Sensate focus exercises:

  • It has two stages:
  • Non-genital sensate focus: Couples should touch, rub, or kiss each other body parts excluding breasts, and genitals
  • Genital sensate focus: Stage II Involves only breasts and genitals. Subsequently, the couple can engage in complete intercourse.
  • Purpose of exercises is to make the couple aware that pleasure can be given and received by methods other than sexual intercourse (penetration).

Others:

  • Behavioral therapy
  • Hypnotherapy
  • Psychoanalysis

questions.text: A 5-year-old child presents with abdominal pain, irritability, and developmental delays. On examination, the child shows a wrist drop. Which of the following chelating agents is the most appropriate first-line treatment for this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Succimer (meso-DMSA)

 

Explanation:

  • Succimer (meso-DMSA) is the preferred oral chelating agent for lead poisoning in children due to its effectiveness and safety profile.

Overview of Chelating Agents

  • Mechanism:
    • Form stable complexes with metal ions to block interactions with biological systems.
    • Promote elimination of metals via urine or feces.

Common Chelating Agents

Chelating Agent

Indication

Administration Route

Dimercaprol (BAL) (Option A ruled out)

Arsenic and mercury poisoning

Intramuscular (IM)

Succimer (meso-DMSA) (Option B)

Lead poisoning (especially in children)

Oral

Unithiol (DMPS)

Mercury and lead toxicity

Oral or Intravenous (IV)

D-penicillamine (Option C ruled out)

Copper and lead poisoning

Oral (but with side effects)

CaNa₂EDTA (Option D ruled out)

Lead poisoning

IV

Deferoxamine (DFO)

Iron overload (e.g., in thalassemia)

IV or IM

Prussian Blue

Thallium and cesium poisoning

Oral

 

Factors Affecting Chelation Efficacy

  • Metal Type: Different metals require specific chelators due to varying affinities.
  • Age: Age impacts both toxicity levels and chelation effectiveness, necessitating tailored treatments.
  • Timing: Early use of chelators improves patient outcomes.

questions.text: A 16-year-old male presents with irregular hypopigmented macules on his forehead and anterior part of the body. Examination reveals a white forelock and V-shaped leukoderma on the mid-forehead. Small spots of hyperpigmentation are also noted within the hypopigmented lesions. Which of the following genetic abnormalities is most likely responsible for the observed clinical features?

choices.text: Heterozygous mutations in the KIT gene
Autosomal dominant mutations in TERT gene
Heterozygous mutations in the SNAI2 gene
Autosomal recessive mutations in the NOLA3 gene

questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) Heterozygous mutations in the KIT gene

 

Explanation:

  • The given clinical scenario of hypopigmented macules with white forelock and V-shaped leukoderma on the forehead is suggestive of piebaldism.
  • It is associated with heterozygous mutations in the KIT gene.

  • Piebaldism is a rare autosomal dominant disorder with congenital white patches that results from impairment of melanoblast migration in embryonal development.
  • The KIT gene encodes for the c-KIT protein, a receptor with tyrosine kinase activity, essential for various cellular processes, including melanocyte migration and proliferation, and throughout life.
  • When mutations occur in one allele of the KIT gene, it disrupts the normal function of c-KIT, leading to impaired melanocyte migration and proliferation.
  • This disruption leads to the formation of hypopigmented patches on the skin, which occur due to the absence of melanocytes in certain areas.
  • The forehead, chest, abdomen, and extremities are typically involved.
  • The distribution of the lesions remains for the entire life of affected individuals.

 

The TERT gene (Option B) encodes for telomerase reverse transcriptase, which plays a crucial role in maintaining telomere length and genomic stability.

  • Mutations in TERT have been associated with various conditions such as dyskeratosis congenita.
  • However, there is no established association between mutations in the TERT gene and piebaldism.

The SNAI2 gene (Option C) encodes for the zinc finger transcription factor Snail family transcriptional repressor 2 (SNAI2), also known as SLUG.

  • SNAI2 is involved in various cellular processes, including epithelial-mesenchymal transition and embryonic development.
  • There is no known association between SNAI2 mutations and piebaldism.

Autosomal recessive mutations in the NOLA3 (Option D) gene are incorrect, as piebaldism typically follows an autosomal dominant inheritance pattern.

questions.text: The following sign in breast MRI is characteristic of:
questions.solution:
The "Linguine Sign" is a characteristic MRI finding of an intracapsular breast implant rupture.

  • Intracapsular Rupture: The implant shell breaks, but the fibrous capsule remains intact, preventing silicone from leaking out.
    • On MRI, the collapsed shell appears as multiple wavy lines, resembling linguine.
    • On USG, it appears a stepladder appearance.
  • Extracapsular Rupture: Silicone escapes beyond the fibrous capsule, often seen as the "Snowstorm Sign" on ultrasound. (Option C)

Other MRI Signs:

  • "Keyhole Sign" / "Teardrop Sign": Silicone on both sides of a radial fold suggests rupture.
  • "Salad Oil Sign": Seen in double-lumen implant rupture with mixing of saline and silicone.

Management: Surgical removal is recommended to prevent silicone migration and complications.

 

Fibrocystic breast disease (Option A):

  • Benign condition with lumpy, painful breasts. Common imaging findings include cystic changes, fibrosis, and adenosis.

 

Fat necrosis of the breast (Option D):

  • Occurs due to trauma or surgery, presenting as oil cysts, calcifications, or irregular masses on mammography or ultrasound.

questions.text: A 25 y/o male presents to the emergency after a sports injury involving a sudden pivot on his left knee. An MRI reveals a tear in the anterior cruciate ligament (ACL). Which statement regarding the knee ligaments is true?

choices.text: Lateral collateral ligament attaches to the patella.
The medial meniscus is wider anteriorly.
PCL prevents anterior displacement of the femur.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) PCL prevents anterior displacement of the femur.

 

Explanation:

The PCL prevents anterior displacement of the femur and posterior displacement of the tibia when the knee is flexed, making it essential for knee stability.

 

Extracapsular Ligaments

Intracapsular Ligaments
  • Ligamentum Patellae:
    • Attaches from the lower border of the patella to the tibial tuberosity.
    • Continuation of the quadriceps femoris tendon.
  • Lateral (Fibular) Collateral Ligament: (Option B ruled out)
    • Cord-like structure attaching from the femur's lateral condyle to the fibula's head.
    • The Popliteus tendon is located between this ligament and the lateral meniscus.
  • Medial (Tibial) Collateral Ligament:
    • Flat band connecting the medial condyle of the femur to the medial surface of the tibia.
    • Firmly attached to the medial meniscus.
  • Oblique Popliteal Ligament:
    • Tendinous expansion from the semimembranosus muscle, strengthening the posterior capsule.
  • Medial Meniscus
    • Semicircular, wider posteriorly than anteriorly. (Option C ruled out)
    • The peripheral margin adheres to the deep part of the tibial collateral ligament; posterior fibres are continuous with the transverse ligament.
  • Lateral Meniscus
    • Circular.
    • The posterior end is attached to the medial condyle of the femur via two meniscofemoral ligaments; separated from the fibular collateral ligament by the popliteus tendon.
  • Anterior Cruciate Ligament (ACL): (Option A ruled out)
    • It attaches to the anterior intercondylar area of the tibia and ascends to the posterior part of the lateral femoral condyle.
    • Prevents posterior displacement of the femur and anterior displacement of the tibia when the knee is flexed.
    • It is extrasynovial.
  • Posterior Cruciate Ligament (PCL):
    • It attaches to the posterior intercondylar area of the tibia and extends to the anterior part of the medial femoral condyle.
    • Prevents anterior displacement of the femur and posterior displacement of the tibia when the knee is flexed.
    • It is extrasynovial.

Intercondylar area attachments

 

Classification of Ligaments and Menisci by Location and Synovial Relation

  • Intracapsular and Intrasynovial: Menisci (lie within the joint capsule and are bathed by synovial fluid).
  • Intracapsular but Extrasynovial: Cruciate ligaments (located within the joint capsule but outside the synovial cavity).
  • Extracapsular and Extrasynovial: Collateral ligaments (outside both the joint capsule and synovial cavity).

questions.text: A 37 y/o primigravida with type II DM on insulin is seen in antenatal OPD. Which of the following is not routinely checked on her further visits to diagnose complications of diabetes in her?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer : D) Fetal Doppler

Explanation:

Fetal Doppler is not routinely done in diabetic pregnancies, it is done if the pregnancy is complicated with fetal growth restriction. However fetal growth scans are recommended.

Fundus examination (Option A) is done to check for diabetic retinopathy. It will have proliferative retinopathy with neovascularisation and microaneurysms.

Fetal Echo (Option B) is recommended between 22 - 24 weeks to detect fetal CVS anomalies with pregestational diabetes, especially if uncontrolled.

A 24-hour urinary protein test (Option C) is done to diagnose diabetic nephropathy. In diabetic nephropathy, creatinine clearance is reduced, or there is persistent proteinuria (≥300 mg/24 hours) during the first 20 weeks of gestation.

questions.text: A 45 year out female presents with persistent ear discharge, hearing loss, and a feeling of fullness in the ear. Upon examination, the otolaryngologist performs an otoscopic examination, which reveals an abnormal growth in the ear canal. Which diagnostic test is most useful for assessing the extent of her condition and guiding surgical planning?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) High-resolution CT

 

Explanation:

  • Based on the symptoms described-persistent ear discharge, hearing loss, a feeling of fullness in the ear, and the finding of abnormal growth in the ear canal, the most probable diagnosis is a cholesteatoma.
  • High-resolution CT (HRCT) is critical for assessing the severity of the cholesteatoma, evaluating any osseous damage, and aiding in surgical planning.
  • HRCT provides detailed imaging of bony structures and helps identify the extent of the cholesteatoma.

 

Investigations for cholesteatoma:

  • Otoscopic Examination:
    • Direct inspection of the eardrum using otoscopy, video-otoscopy, otomicroscopy, or video-telescopy.
  • Radiological Examination:
    • CT Scan:
      • Primary imaging technique to assess disease severity, osseous damage, and malformations.
      • High-resolution CT (HRCT) is often used before surgery.
    • MRI:
      • Provides detailed tissue distinction with different pulse sequences.
      • Cholesteatomas typically appear hyperintense on T2WI and hypointense/isointense on T1WI.
  • Tympanometric and Audiometric Tests:
    • Assess hearing loss; audiometry identifies conductive deficiencies.
    • Rinne’s and Weber's tests differentiate between conductive and sensorineural hearing loss.
  • Cholesteatoma is diagnosed using a combination of otoscopic examination, CT, MRI, and ancillary tests like tympanometry and audiometry.

 

Video-Otoscopy (Option A) is useful for visualizing the ear canal and eardrum directly but does not provide detailed information on the extent of disease or bony structures.

 

Rinne Test (Option C) is an audiometric test used to differentiate between conductive and sensorineural hearing loss but does not provide information on the extent of cholesteatoma or guide surgical decisions.

 

Diffusion-weighted MRI (Option D) helps detect recurrence or residual cholesteatoma, particularly after surgery, but HRCT is the primary imaging tool for pre-surgical assessment of the disease extent.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents to the emergency department with an open tibial fracture following a motorcycle accident. The wound is 4 cm long with moderate soft tissue damage but no flaps or avulsions. After an initial assessment, what is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient's injury?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Wound debridement and irrigation

 

Explanation:

  • Based on the management protocol of open fractures, wound debridement and irrigation are crucial initial steps in the emergency care phase.
  • This process helps to remove contaminants and devitalized tissue, reducing the risk of infection and promoting proper healing.

Management of Open fractures

Phase

Management Steps

I: Emergency Care
  • Control bleeding
  • Wound care: Wash the wound under strict aseptic conditions with clean tap water or saline.
    • Cover with sterile dressing.
  • Splinting: Apply a splint to immobilize the fracture and prevent further soft tissue damage.
  • Antibiotics & Tetanus prophylaxis
  • Pain management
  • Imaging: Perform X-rays to evaluate the fracture and to plan further treatment.

II: Definitive Care
  • Wound debridement: Perform thorough debridement of all devitalized tissue. This may need to be repeated.
  • Fracture reduction & stabilization:
    • External fixation: Provides stability and permits access to soft tissues. Useful for severe soft tissue injuries.
    • Internal fixation: Used for more stable fractures. Becoming more common in trauma centers.
    • Plaster immobilization: For cases with moderate-size wounds where stable reduction can be achieved.
  • Wound closure:
    • Primary closure: For clean wounds debrided within 6-8 hours.
    • Delayed primary closure: For doubtful wounds, observe for 2-3 days before closing.
    • Secondary intention: For infected wounds or extensive soft tissue damage.
  • Bone grafting: May be necessary for bone loss or to promote union.
  • Vascular repair: If vascular injury is present, repair is crucial for limb salvage.

III: Rehabilitation
  • Early mobilization
  • Joint exercises & muscle strengthening
  • Functional rehabilitation: Gradually increase weight-bearing and return to normal activities as healing progresses.

 

Management of open fractures based on grade:

  • Grade 1 is managed like closed fracture.
  • Grade 2 and 3a if clean and less than 6 hrs manage like closed, otherwise open fracture.
  • Grade 3b and 3c are managed like open fracture.

 

Internal fixation is typically performed after proper wound care and assessment of the fracture and soft tissue damage. (Option A)

  • It falls under the definitive care phase.
  • It is done for grade 1 and 2 and 3A less than 6hrs with clean wounds.

While splinting is important, it comes after wound care and is not the most appropriate next step for an open fracture. (Option B)

Administration of tetanus prophylaxis is important but not the most immediate next step. (Option D)

  • It should be given as part of emergency care, but wound debridement and irrigation take precedence.

questions.text: A 60-kg male runner develops cramps, disorientation, and seizures after completing a marathon. On admission, serum sodium is 120 mEq/L and serum potassium is 3.2 meq/L. What is the approximate sodium deficit in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - 720 meq:

  • This patient has acute symptomatic hyponatremia and seizures after endurance exercise.
  • Sodium deficit calculation: 0.6 X weight X (Desired value – actual value)
  • Sodium deficit calculation: 0.6 X 60 X (140-120) = 720 meq
  • Remember if this was female patient the multiplication factor will be 0.5 instead of 0.6

questions.text: A 65-year-old male patient is admitted to the hospital after undergoing elective surgery. Post-anesthesia, he is found to be unconscious and placed in a supine position for monitoring. The healthcare team is concerned about the risk of aspiration due to his current state. Which location is most likely to collect aspirated material in this patient?

choices.text: Anterior Basal BPS of the right lower lobe
Posterior BPS of the right upper lobe
Apical Basal BPS of the right lower lobe
Lateral BPS of the right middle lobe

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Apical Basal BPS of the right lower lobe

 

Explanation:

  • The Apical Basal BPS of the right lower lobe is the most likely site for aspirated material in a supine, unconscious patient
  • Due to its anatomical position and tendency to collect fluids.
  • Other segments, while dependent, are less favorable for aspiration accumulation. (Option A, B, and D )

 

 

Right Lung:

  • Superior Lobe:
    • S1: Apical
    • S2: Posterior
    • S3: Anterior
  • Middle Lobe:
    • S4: Lateral
    • S5: Medial
  • Inferior Lobe:
    • S6: Superior (Apical)
    • S7: Medial Basal
    • S8: Anterior Basal
    • S9: Lateral Basal
    • S10: Posterior Basal

 

Most Dependent Location:

  • Superior segment of right lower lobe

 

Aspiration Risk:

  • Supine posture.
  • Coma and unconscious patients (e.g., post-anesthesia).

Collection Sites:

  • Posterior BPS of the right upper lobe.
  • Apical Basal BPS of the right lower lobe.

Preferred Collection Site:

  • Apical Basal BPS of the right lower lobe > Posterior BPS of the right upper lobe.

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient is diagnosed with malignant pheochromocytoma after presenting with persistent hypertension and elevated plasma metanephrines. Imaging reveals metastasis to various sites. Which of the following is not a common site for metastasis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Brain

 

Explanation:

Brain is not a common site for metastasis in malignant pheochromocytoma.


 

Malignant Pheochromocytoma

Tumors that have undergone metastasis to Lymph-node (or) Distant site (Biochemically same as Pheochromocytoma)

Survival Rate

5-year survival ranges from 20% to 45%.

Criteria of Malignancy

Malignancy is defined by the development of metastases

Common Sites of Metastasis

Axial skeleton, lymph nodes, liver, lung, and kidney. (Option A,C,D)

Diagnosis

  • MIBG & Gallium Dotate is Best for Diagnosis
  • Biopsy & FNAC are avoided in Malignant Pheochromocytoma
  • Confirmed by the presence of metastases in locations where neuroectodermal tissues are not normally found.
  • This is the primary criterion distinguishing malignant pheochromocytomas from benign ones, as histopathologic features alone are not reliable in predicting malignancy.

Histopathologic Criteria

No histopathologic criteria can accurately predict the clinical course of malignancy.

Primary Treatment

Surgical resection, even if not curative, can offer significant palliative benefits by managing mass effects and reducing catecholamine excess.

Response to Radiotherapy/Chemotherapy

Minimal response to radiotherapy and chemotherapy.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient has hypertension and hypokalemia. His blood pressure is consistently elevated despite being on multiple antihypertensive medications. Laboratory tests reveal elevated plasma aldosterone concentration and suppressed plasma renin activity. A CT scan of the abdomen shows an adrenal adenoma. Which is the most appropriate treatment for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Spironolactone

 

Explanation :

  • Primary hyperaldosteronism (Conn's syndrome) is characterised by excessive production of aldosterone from the adrenal glands, leading to hypertension and hypokalemia.
  • Spironolactone, an aldosterone antagonist and a potassium-sparing diuretic, is the most appropriate drug of choice.

Spironolactone:

  • Aldosterone combines with an intracellular mineralocorticoid (MR) receptor and induces the formation of aldosterone-induced proteins (AIPs), which promote Na+ reabsorption.
  • Spironolactone acts as a competitive antagonist and inhibits the formation of AIP by combining with MR.
  • This prevents aldosterone from promoting sodium reabsorption and potassium excretion, which are the primary mechanisms by which aldosterone increases blood pressure and causes hypokalemia.

Lisinopril (Option A) is an angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitor that reduces aldosterone levels by inhibiting the production of angiotensin II.

Hydrochlorothiazide (Option B) is a thiazide diuretic that inhibits the reabsorption of sodium and potassium; thus, hyperaldosteronism-induced hypokalemia will be worsened.

Amlodipine (Option C) is a calcium channel blocker that works by relaxing the smooth muscle.

questions.text: A preterm infant born at 28 weeks of gestation weighs 1.8 kg at birth. The infant's mother is HBsAg-positive. Which of the following is the correct management for hepatitis B vaccination in this infant?

choices.text: Administer the hepatitis B birth dose within the first 24 hours of life.
Defer the hepatitis B birth dose until the infant reaches 1 month of age.
Administer hepatitis B immunoglobulin (HBIG) and hepatitis B vaccine within 12 hours of birth.
Administer hepatitis B vaccine only after discharge from the hospital.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Administer hepatitis B immunoglobulin (HBIG) and hepatitis B vaccine within 12 hours of birth.

Explanation:

 

Preterm Infants:

  • General Recommendations: Vaccinate based on chronological age, similar to full-term infants.
  • Hepatitis B Vaccine:
    • For ≥ 2 kg and stable: Birth dose within 24 hours.
    • For < 2 kg: Birth dose deferred until 1 month or hospital discharge (if HBsAg-negative mother). All preterm, low-birthweight infants born to HBsAg-positive mothers should receive HBIG and hepatitis B vaccine within 12 hours of birth, with three additional doses starting at 1 month.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman with a history of SLE presents with fatigue, decreased urine output, and facial swelling. Lab tests show elevated serum creatinine, proteinuria, and hematuria. A renal biopsy is performed, and the histopathological examination image is attached. Which statement is true regarding this condition?

choices.text: >50% of glomeruli showing crescents is diagnostic.
More the number of crescents, better the prognosis.
Crescents are composed solely of endothelial cells.

questions.solution:
Answer: A) >50% of glomeruli showing crescents is diagnostic.

 

Explanation:

The provided clinical scenario and the histopathological image suggest a Rapidly Progressive Glomerulonephritis (RPGN) diagnosis in a patient with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE).

Crescentic glomerulonephritis (or RPGN) is characterised by the presence of crescents in more than 50% of glomeruli on renal biopsy.

 

More the number of crescents, the better the prognosis (Option B)

In RPGN, more crescents generally indicate a poor prognosis

 

Crescents are composed solely of endothelial cells (Option C)

Crescents are composed of fibrin, leucocytes, parietal and visceral layers of Bowman capsule.

 

Primarily caused by bacterial infections (Option D)

RPGN Type I, II, III can be due to varied causes.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with a 3-week history of difficulty in vision in her left eye, along with persistent headaches and occasional eye pain. She also reports trouble with colour perception. Fundoscopic examination reveals the findings shown in the image. Which type of optic neuritis is most likely to be seen?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Neuroretinitis

 

Explanation:

  • The clinical scenario with a macular star in fundoscopy suggests Neuroretinitis, a subtype of optic neuritis.
  • Optic neuritis is an inflammatory condition of the optic nerve that can cause vision loss, with symptoms including decreased vision, pain in eye movement, and visual field defects.

 

Classification of Optic neuritis:

 

Papillitis

(Option A)

Retrobulbar Neuritis

(Option B)

Neuroretinitis

(Option C)

Site

Optic disc

Optic nerve behind the eyeball.

Optic disc and surrounding retina in the macular area.

Characteristic features

Fundoscopy reveals a blurred disc margin due to leakage and increased capillary permeability, edematous and hyperaemic disc, and physiological cup is obliterated.
  • Pain on eye elevation
  • RAPD (relative afferent pupillary defect) is observed.
  • Fundoscopic examination typically reveals normal optic disc, at least initially, which is why the classic phrase, “the patient sees nothing, and the doctor sees nothing” is often used to describe retrobulbar neuritis.

A macular star is seen in fundoscopy (accumulation of lipids).

 

 

Clinical features,

It may be asymptomatic or associated with:

  • Visual loss: Monocular sudden, progressive and profound visual loss is the hallmark of acute optic neuritis.
  • Dark adaptation may be lowered.
  • Visual obscuration in bright light is a typical symptom of acute optic neuritis.
  • Impairment of color vision is always present in optic neuritis.
  • Visual acuity is usually reduced markedly.
  • Visual field changes: The most common field defect in optic neuritis is a relative central or centrocecal scotoma.
  • Contrast sensitivity is impaired.

 

Papilledema (Option D) is bilateral optic disc swelling due to increased intracranial pressure.

  • Findings include elevated optic disc, blurred disc margins, retinal hemorrhages, and venous congestion.
  • It can be associated with optic neuritis.

questions.text: Which of the following anaesthetic agents should be avoided in patients undergoing neurosurgery who are at risk for developing pneumocephalus?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Nitrous Oxide

 

Explanation:

  • Nitrous Oxide is known for its rapid onset and strong anaesthetic properties, but it should be avoided in patients at risk for pneumocephalus.
  • Nitrous oxide can diffuse into closed-air spaces, leading to the expansion of trapped air. In neurosurgical patients, this could worsen pneumocephalus by enlarging intracranial air pockets, leading to increased intracranial pressure and potential complications.

Note: Nitrous oxide is also contraindicated in bowel obstruction because it diffuses into closed air spaces, increasing bowel distension and the risk of complications.

 

Propofol (Option A):

  • It reduces cerebral blood flow and intracranial pressure, making it a good choice for neurosurgical patients.
  • However, it does not affect air-filled spaces in the body, so there is no risk of exacerbating pneumocephalus when using propofol.

 

Fentanyl (Option C):

  • Fentanyl is an opioid that is commonly used to manage pain during surgery.
  • It does not directly affect cerebral blood flow or alter intracranial air spaces.


Mannitol (Option D):

  • Mannitol is an osmotic diuretic that is frequently administered in neurosurgery to lower intracranial pressure by drawing fluid out of brain tissue.
  • While it helps reduce cerebral oedema, it does not affect air-filled spaces.

questions.text: What is the primary function of the Rapoport-Luebering Shunt in red blood cells?

choices.text: To produce 2,3-bisphosphoglycerate, which regulates oxygen binding to hemoglobin
To facilitate the conversion of glucose to glucose-6-phosphate

questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) To produce 2,3-bisphosphoglycerate, which regulates oxygen binding to hemoglobin

Explanation:

The Rapoport-Luebering Shunt forms 2,3-bisphosphoglycerate (2,3-BPG) through a series of enzymatic reactions involving 1,3-bisphosphoglycerate (1,3-BPG).

  • Formation of 1,3-BPG:
    • In glycolysis, glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate is converted to 1,3-bisphosphoglycerate by the enzyme glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate dehydrogenase.
    • This reaction involves the addition of an inorganic phosphate and the reduction of NAD+ to NADH.
  • Conversion to 2,3-BPG:
    • In the Rapoport-Luebering Shunt, 1,3-BPG is converted to 2,3-BPG by the enzyme bisphosphoglycerate mutase.
    • This reaction shifts the phosphate group from the first carbon to the second carbon of the glycerate molecule, forming 2,3-BPG.
  • Conversion of 2,3-BPG to 3-phosphoglycerate:
    • 2,3-BPG can be hydrolyzed to 3-phosphoglycerate by the enzyme 2,3-bisphosphoglycerate phosphatase.
    • This reaction removes a phosphate group, resulting in the formation of 3-phosphoglycerate, which then re-enters the glycolytic pathway.

 

The Rapoport-Luebering Shunt does not generate ATP; it bypasses an ATP-generating step in glycolysis (Option A).

 

The conversion of pyruvate to lactate is a function of lactate dehydrogenase and is not related to the Rapoport-Luebering Shunt (Option C).

 

The conversion of glucose to glucose-6-phosphate is catalyzed by hexokinase or glucokinase and occurs at the very beginning of glycolysis, unrelated to the Rapoport-Luebering Shunt (Option D).

questions.text: During Psychiatry rotations, the consultant presents a case study of a 20-year-old female patient diagnosed with Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder (OCD). The patient has a history of excessive handwashing, intrusive thoughts about contamination, and significant anxiety regarding the cleanliness of her environment. He emphasizes the importance of understanding common comorbidities associated with OCD, as they can impact treatment planning and patient outcomes. Which is the most common comorbid condition observed in patients with Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder (OCD)?
questions.solution:
Answer: B) Major Depressive Disorder

Explanation:

Major Depressive Disorder is the most common comorbidity seen in individuals with OCD. It is crucial to evaluate for depression in these patients, as the first line of treatment for patients of OCD with depression is pharmacotherapy.

 

Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder

  • Patient has recurrent obsessions and compulsions.
  • Recurrent obsessions or compulsions may cause severe distress or anxiety to the person.

 

Obsessions

Compulsions
  • Intrusive and unwanted repetitive thoughts, urges, or impulses.
  • Most common: Contamination
  • Repetitive actions or thoughts carried out in a strict, regulation-bound manner or reaction to obsessions
  • Performed to relieve anxiety or fear.
  • Most common: Checking

 

  • These are time-consuming (at least 1 hr/day) and significantly interfere with the person’s routine, occupational functioning, usual social activities, or relationships.
  • Patients can have only obsessions, only compulsions, or both obsessions and compulsions (most common).
  • Most common comorbidity associated with OCD is major depressive disorder (67%). (Option B)

 

  • Major symptom patterns:

Contamination / Cleansing
  • Most common presentation.
  • An obsession with contamination followed by washing and avoidance of the presumably contaminated object.

Pathological doubt /checking
  • Second most common presentation.
  • Obsession of doubt, usually followed by compulsion of checking.

Intrusive/forbidden thoughts
  • Third most common presentation.
  • Obsessed with intrusive thoughts of aggressive or sexual acts without a compulsion.

Symmetry/ordering
  • Fourth most common presentation.
  • Patient needs symmetry/precision which results in the compulsion of slowness.

Other symptoms
  • Religious obsessions and compulsive hoarding.

 

Epidemiology:

  • Lifetime prevalence- 2 to 3%.
  • More common in females than males (Adolescents M>F).
  • Mean age of onset in OCD is 19 years, early onset is more in males.

 

Etiology:

  • OCD has been linked to the striatum, orbitofrontal cortex, anterior cingulate, and corticostriatal–thalamic–cortical (CSTC) circuit.
  • Neurotransmitters implicated are neurotransmitter systems that contribute to OCD, including serotonergic, dopaminergic, glutamatergic, and GABAergic systems.
  • Genetic susceptibility plays a role in OCD.

 

Treatment:

Pharmacotherapy:

  • First line:
    • SSRIs (preferred) and Clomipramine
    • Treatment should be continued for 1-2 years
  • Augmenting agents:
    • Antipsychotics: Risperidone, Aripiprazole.
    • Others: Memantine, riluzole, ketamine, lamotrigine, and N-acetylcysteine (NAC).

Psychotherapy:

  • Cognitive Behaviour Therapy (CBT):
    • Exposure and response prevention (ERP).
    • Exposure to feared situations is given. The patient is asked not to engage in a compulsive response.
  • Other therapies are desensitization, thought-stopping, flooding, aversive conditioning, psychodynamic psychotherapy, and family therapy.
  • In younger patients, cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) is preferred first.
  • In more severe symptoms or comorbid depression, pharmacotherapy is preferred first.
  • Combination of CBT and pharmacotherapy is particularly useful.

Somatic Therapies:

  • Anterior cingulotomy and capsulotomy.
  • Deep brain stimulation with implantation of electrodes.

 

Generalized Anxiety Disorder (Option A): While frequently co-occurring, GAD is not the single most common comorbidity; Major Depressive Disorder has a higher prevalence rate among OCD patients.

Panic Disorder (Option C): Panic disorder is less frequently observed as a comorbidity in OCD patients compared to Major Depressive Disorder.

Social Anxiety Disorder (Option D): While possible, social anxiety disorder is not as commonly comorbid with OCD as Major Depressive Disorder.

questions.text:
Match the parts of the Papez circuit with their correct functions:


	
		
			
			Part of Papez Circuit
			
			
			Function
			
		
		
			
			1) Cingulate Gyrus
			
			
			A) Conversion of short-term memory to long-term memory
			
		
		
			
			2) Parahippocampal Gyrus
			
			
			B) Controls heart rate, blood pressure, cognitive and emotional processing
			
		
		
			
			3) Hippocampus
			
			
			C) Responsible for controlling recent memories of the brain
			
		
		
			
			4) Mammillary Body and Anterior Nucleus of Thalamus
			
			
			D) Spatial memory, the memory of three-dimensional space
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 1 - B, 2 - D, 3 - A, 4 - C

Explanation:
The Papez circuit is a neurocircuitry of the limbic system involved in learning and memory, emotion, and social behavior.

 

It has the following components:

Part of Papez Circuit

Function

Cingulate Gyrus

Controls heart rate, blood pressure, cognitive and emotional processing.

Parahippocampal Gyrus and Entorhinal Cortex

Spatial memory, the memory of three-dimensional space.

Hippocampus

Responsible for the conversion of short-term memory to long-term memory.

Mammillary Body and Anterior Nucleus of Thalamus

Responsible for controlling recent memories of the brain.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presents with a painless, slowly growing mass in her left parotid gland. Examination reveals a firm, mobile mass. Biopsy confirms pleomorphic adenoma with characteristic islands of cartilage and foci of bone in a myxoid stroma. Which of the following is incorrect regarding this condition?

choices.text: Mostly found in the parotid gland
Mixed tumours with ductal, myoepithelial and mesenchymal cells
Radiation exposure is a risk factor
Down-regulation of PLAG1 results in abnormal cell proliferation

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Down-regulation of PLAG1 results in abnormal cell proliferation

Explanation:

  • Pleomorphic adenoma is a benign mixed tumor predominantly of the parotid gland and is commonly seen in females.

  • It contains both epithelial (ductal and myoepithelial) and mesenchymal components (myxoid, chondroid, and osseous tissue).

  • Radiation exposure is a known risk factor for salivary gland tumors, including pleomorphic adenoma.

  • The PLAG1 (PLAG= Pleomorphic Adenoma Gene) gene is an oncogene, and up-regulation or overexpression (not down-regulation) of PLAG1 leads to abnormal cell proliferation and tumorigenesis in pleomorphic adenoma.

questions.text: A 37-year-old man is complaining of heart palpitations, nausea, and facial flushing after being bitten by the insect shown in the image. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Chagas disease.

 

Explanation:

  • The image is of the Reduviid bug, and the disease transmitted is Chagas disease.

 

Reduviid bug

Synonyms
  • Cone-nose bugs

Location
  • Mexico, Central America, and South America

Morphology
  • An inch or more in length
  • Adults have wings

Feeding

  • Exclusively on the blood

Habitat
  • Cracks, fissures, and other hiding places in walls, ceilings, and animal habitations

Health impact
  • Transmit Trypanosoma cruzi [a protozoa], the causative agent of Chagas' disease, causes intense itching, nausea, flushed face, and palpitations of the heart.

Control measures
  • Insecticides like HCH or dieldrin

 

Scrub typhus (Option B): Incorrect because it is transmitted by chiggers (larval mites), not Reduviid bugs.

Tularaemia (Option C): Incorrect because it is transmitted by ticks, deer flies, or direct contact with infected animals, not Reduviid bugs.

Sleeping sickness (Option D): Incorrect because it is transmitted by tsetse flies (Glossina species), not Reduviid bugs.

questions.text: A 28 y/o woman presents with persistent knee pain after recently undergoing bariatric surgery. She reports a history of significant weight loss and intermittent joint swelling. MRI was taken which revealed the following. What is the most likely reason behind this patient's condition?

choices.text: Postoperative autoimmune response leading to synovitis
Fat embolism from rapid adipose tissue breakdown

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Fat embolism from rapid adipose tissue breakdown

 

Explanation:

  • MRI reveals bone marrow oedema in the distal femur and proximal tibia which suggests osteonecrosis.
  • Rapid weight loss can lead to fat mobilisation and subsequent fat embolism, resulting in vascular obstruction and ischemia, which are key contributors to osteonecrosis.

 

Causes of Osteonecrosis

Trauma:

Fractures or dislocations disrupt blood supply, especially in the femoral neck, scaphoid, and talus.

Corticosteroid Use:

High-dose steroids cause fat cell swelling and intravascular stasis, leading to bone ischemia

Alcohol Abuse:

Chronic alcohol use leads to fat embolism and marrow swelling, causing venous stasis.

Sickle Cell Disease:

Sickled red cells obstruct blood vessels, leading to ischemia and bone death.

Gaucher’s Disease:

Lipid accumulation in bone marrow causes vascular compression and ischemia

Thrombophilia:

Increased blood clotting tendency leads to capillary thrombosis, causing bone necrosis.

Antiphospholipid Antibodies:

As seen in SLE, these antibodies promote clot formation, leading to ischemia.

Fat Embolism:

Fat emboli block capillaries, causing endothelial damage and thrombosis.

Venous Stasis:

Marrow swelling increases intraosseous pressure, leading to venous blockage and ischemia.

Dysbaric Osteonecrosis:.

Rapid decompression (e.g., in divers) causes gas bubbles in vessels, leading to bone necrosis.

Pregnancy:

Hormonal changes and fatty liver can decrease fibrinolysis, increasing clot formation.

Radiation Exposure:

Radiation damages blood vessels, leading to poor blood flow and bone necrosis

Postoperative autoimmune response leading to synovitis (Option A):

  • Postoperative autoimmune response leading to synovitis typically presents with widespread joint symptoms and inflammatory markers rather than localised bone marrow oedema seen in osteonecrosis

Osteoporosis due to nutritional deficiencies (Option C):

  • Nutritional deficiencies can lead to weakened bones, but they neither cause intermittent swelling nor osteonecrosis as suggested by the MRI findings.

Bed rest post-surgery (Option D):

  • Prolonged immobility could cause stiffness but is less likely to explain significant pain and swelling and the osteonecrosis suggested by the MRI findings.

questions.text: John & his 10-year-old son set off on a camping trip to a remote area for its beautiful streams and scenic views. They spot a river flowing with clear water however John warns his son to not drink from it directly and rather purify it first. Which of the following statements is true regarding the purification of water on a small scale?

choices.text: Boiling water is preferred over chlorination because it is cost-effective and provides long-term residual activity.
Boiling is not preferred as a mode of water purification because it requires re-treatment every 4-6 hours.
Chlorination is less effective than boiling because it lacks residual activity and requires frequent re-treatment.
Water should be turbid for chlorination to effectively take place.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Boiling is not preferred as a mode of water purification because it requires re-treatment every 4-6 hours.

 

Explanation:

This statement is true because boiling water is

  • Costly as it consumes a lot of gas.
  • It requires boiling water every 4-6 hours (re-treatment).
  • Therefore it has no residual activity.
  • Hence it is not the preferred method of purification.
  • Boiling water is costly and provides no residual activity, hence it is not preferred over chlorine.
  • However, it is still the best method available for purification (Option A ruled out)

Chlorine is a more effective mode of water purification than boiling (Option C ruled out) due to:

  • It has high residual activity and does not require frequent re-treatment of water.
  • This residual activity is also known as Free chlorine.
  • This makes it very cost-effective as well.
  • The most commonly used form of chlorination is bleaching powder
  • 100g of bleaching powder releases 33 grams of chlorine.
  • However, it is the 2nd best method available for water purification on a small scale. 
  • For water to be chlorinated, water should be free from turbidity as turbidity impedes efficient chlorination (Option D ruled out)

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman with a 20-year history of rheumatoid arthritis has a painless, progressively thinning area in the sclera of her left eye. The area appears as shown in the image below. Which of the following best describes the pathophysiological mechanism responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Type III hypersensitivity

Explanation:

The diagnosis in this scenario is Scleromalacia Perforans.

  • It is usually associated with long-standing rheumatoid arthritis and presents with scleral thinning, appearing bluish and without signs of inflammation.
  • The underlying cause of scleral thinning is probably ischemia because of vessel damage (Type III hypersensitivity).

 

  • Type II hypersensitivity (Option B) involves antibody-mediated cellular dysfunction or destruction.
  • Type IV hypersensitivity (Option C): Scleromalacia perforans is caused by immune complex–mediated vasculitis, not delayed-type hypersensitivity.
  • Infective etiology (Option D): Scleromalacia perforans is a sterile, autoimmune complication of systemic diseases.

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of acute chest pain with complaints of diaphoresis and lightheadedness. An ECG reveals ST-segment elevation in the inferior leads. Her blood pressure is 90/60 mm Hg, and her pulse is 42/min. The appropriate therapy is initiated, including medication to treat her bradycardia. The medication improved her vitals, but she now complains of severe right eye pain. Which of the following drugs can be used to treat this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Pilocarpine

Explanation: 

  • Given the clinical scenario, this patient had an inferior wall MI associated with bradycardia.
  • Atropine, an antimuscarinic drug, blocks vagal effects on the nodes of the heart, effectively increasing heart rate.
  • In the eye, it induces mydriasis, which narrows the anterior chamber angle and reduces aqueous humor outflow, potentially triggering acute angle-closure glaucoma.

 

  • The drug of choice for this condition is pilocarpine.
  • When applied topically to the eye, pilocarpine rapidly penetrates the cornea, causing miosis, ciliary muscle contraction, and reduced intraocular pressure.

 

 

Phenylephrine (Option A) is used as a mydriatic and nasal decongestant.

Pyridostigmine (Option B) is used to treat myasthenia gravis.

Bethanechol (Option D) is used to treat urinary retention and stimulate bladder function.

questions.text: A patient with epilepsy is prescribed both Phenytoin and lamotrigine for seizure control. The patient reports worsening seizures despite adhering to the prescribed regimen. Which of the following best explains the potential reason for the failure of the regimen?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Increased metabolism of lamotrigine

 

Explanation:

  • Lamotrigine is primarily metabolized by glucuronidation via the enzyme UGT1A4.
     
  • Phenytoin is a potent enzyme inducer, especially of UGT and CYP450 enzymes.
     
  • When given together, phenytoin induces the metabolism of lamotrigine, leading to:
     
    • Faster clearance of lamotrigine
       
    • Lower plasma levels
       
    • Subtherapeutic effect, resulting in worsening seizures despite compliance
       

Enzyme Inducers and Inhibitors

Enzyme Inducers:

  • These increase drug metabolism → ↓ Drug effect

Mnemonic – GRAASS:

Inducer

Effect

Griseofulvin

Antifungal – induces CYP enzymes

Rifampicin

Strong CYP3A4 inducer

Antiepileptics

Phenytoin, Carbamazepine, Phenobarbital – all induce metabolism

Alcohol (Chronic)

Induces CYP2E1

Smoking

Induces CYP1A2

St. John’s Wort

Induces CYP3A4 and P-gp

Enzyme Inhibitors:

  • These decrease metabolism → ↑ Drug levels (toxicity risk)

Mnemonic – G-PACMAN:

Inhibitor

Notes

Grapefruit juice

Inhibits intestinal CYP3A4

Protease inhibitors

e.g., ritonavir – inhibits CYP3A4

Azoles

e.g., ketoconazole – potent CYP inhibitors

Cimetidine

H2 blocker – inhibits multiple CYPs

Macrolides

e.g., erythromycin – inhibits CYP3A4

Amiodarone

Inhibits CYP2C9, CYP3A4

Non-DHP CCBs

Verapamil, Diltiazem – inhibit CYP3A4

 

Increased absorption of lamotrigine (Option A):

  • Phenytoin does not affect lamotrigine's absorption significantly.
  • The issue lies in its metabolism, not uptake.

Toxicity of lamotrigine (Option B):

  • Toxicity occurs when metabolism is inhibited (e.g., by valproate), not when induced. Here, levels drop.

Inhibition of transport of lamotrigine (Option D):

  • There’s no major known effect of phenytoin on lamotrigine transporters.

questions.text: Which of the following diagnostic methods provides the highest sensitivity for confirming the presence of Pneumocystis jirovecii?

choices.text: Induced sputum and staining with gomori methamine stain

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Polymerase Chain Reaction 

 

Explanation:

  • PCR of BAL fluid is the most sensitive test for diagnosing Pneumocystis jirovecii, especially when direct microscopy is negative. It has sensitivity rates up to 96%.
  • IF study is highly specific but less sensitive 
  • Sequence is PCR> IF > Gomori methamine staining

questions.text: A 30-year-old female is diagnosed with cervical dysplasia, and HPV testing reveals a high-risk strain. A histopathological examination of her cervical biopsy shows the following findings. Which viral protein is associated with the formation of these findings?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) E5 protein

 

Explanation:

  • The E5 protein is responsible for the formation of perinuclear vacuoles in infected cells, as shown in the figure, leading to cytoplasmic "halos."
  • These halos indicate a cytopathic effect associated with E5, as it localizes to the membranes of the endoplasmic reticulum.
  • The nuclear changes accompanying these vacuoles are referred to as koilocytic atypia.

HPV is a DNA virus belonging to the Papillomaviridae family.

Tropism: Selectively infects epithelial cells of skin and mucous membranes.

Morphology

  • Non-enveloped virus, 50–55 nm in size.
  • Icosahedral capsid containing circular double-stranded DNA (dsDNA).

Viral Genome

Early (E) Region: Includes E1-E7 genes coding for nonstructural proteins.

  • E1 and E2 Proteins: Regulate viral DNA replication. (Option A)
  • E4 Protein: Disrupts cytokeratins to facilitate the release of the virus.
  • E5 Protein: contributes to the formation of perinuclear vacuoles, leading to cytoplasmic “halos.” (Option D)
  • E6 Protein: Promotes degradation of the p53 tumor-suppressor protein. (Option B)
  • E7 Protein: inhibits retinoblastoma protein, contributing to oncogenesis. (Option C)

Late (L) Region: L1 and L2 genes code for structural capsid proteins.

  • Types: Over 100 HPV types, classified by DNA sequences in the L1 region.
  • L1 capsid protein is used for making vaccines.

HPV Mechanism of Oncogenesis
 
  • E6 Protein:
    • Promotes degradation of p53, blocking apoptosis and inhibiting p53-driven activation of tumor suppressor gene p21.
  • E7 Protein:
    • Inhibits the retinoblastoma (RB) tumor suppressor gene through direct RB inhibition and by interfering with p53 and p21 functions.
  • HPV infection alone is insufficient for malignancy; factors such as co-transfection with v-fos DNA, genetic mutations (e.g., mutated RAS gene), & environmental influences (e.g., smoking, microbial co-infections, dietary deficiencies, hormonal changes) enhance cancer risk.

questions.text: Which indicator is considered the principal impact indicator in the National Iodine Deficiency Disorders Control Program (NIDDCP), reflecting the effectiveness of salt iodization?

choices.text: Salt iodine content at the production site

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Median urinary iodine levels

 

Explanation:

  • In the NIDDCP, median urinary iodine levels are regarded as the principal impact indicator because they directly reflect the iodine status in the population following salt iodization programs.
  • This indicator is crucial for monitoring the effectiveness of iodine supplementation efforts.

 

National Iodine Deficiency Disorders Control Program (NIDDCP)

Indicators to Monitor Success

Process Indicators
  • Salt iodine content at production site, point of packaging, wholesale and retail levels & in households (Option D)
  • Manufacturing level: ≥30 ppm and Distribution level: ≥15 ppm on a dry weight basis

Impact Indicators
  • Urinary iodine excretion (Principal impact indicator) (Option A)
  • Goitre rate (chronic/long-term impact indicator) (Option B)
  • Neonatal hypothyroidism (sensitive indicator) (Option C)

Sustainability Indicators
  • Median urinary iodine levels in the target population
  • Availability of adequately iodized salt at the household level
  • Set of programmatic indicators

Epidemiological Assessment
  • Prevalence of goitre, cretinism, neonatal hypothyroidism
  • Urinary iodine excretion
  • Measurement of thyroid function (T4, TSH)

Programmatic Goal
  • <5% prevalence of IDD in 10-14 years age group
  • <10% incidence of IDD

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with blistering and severe itching on her arms after applying the juice from a black seed, as shown in the image. She also experiences nausea and abdominal pain. Which of the following statements is not true?

choices.text: Often used in malingering for artificial bruises.
Commonly used for Arrow and Cattle poisoning.
Large oral doses can be potentially fatal

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Commonly used for arrow and cattle poisoning.

 

Explanation:

  • The scenario of blistering and severe itching on her arms after applying the juice from the seed, as shown in the image, suggests Semecarpus Anacardium.
  • It is used to create artificial bruises (malingering) but is not commonly used for Arrow and cattle poisoning.
  • Abrus precatorius is used as an arrow poison and ideal cattle poison.

 

Semecarpus Anacardium:

  • Commonly known as the marking nut or bhilawanol (washermen use its juice to inscribe identification numbers on clothes).
  • Seeds:
    • Black, cone/heart-shaped with a rough projection at the base.
    • They have a thick pericarp that contains an acrid, brownish, oily juice that turns black upon exposure to air.

  • Active principles: Semecarpol and Bhilawanol (Option B)
  • Signs and Symptoms:
    • Skin exposure: Applying the juice can cause irritation, itching, and painful blisters filled with acrid serum.
      • Eczematous eruptions resembling bruises may also occur, potentially evolving into ulcers with sloughing.
    • Constitutional symptoms include fever and painful micturition, often accompanied by brown-colored urine.
    • Oral ingestion: A large dose can cause blisters in the mouth and throat, severe gastrointestinal irritation, dyspnea, tachycardia, hypotension, cyanosis, loss of reflexes, delirium, coma, and potentially death. (Option D)
    • Fatal dose: Approximately 5–10 g (5–8 seeds).
    • Fatal period: 12–24 hours.
  • Treatment:
    • Rinse the affected skin with soap and water.
    • Apply bland liniments.
    • Provide demulcent drinks and symptomatic treatment.
  • Medico-legal Aspects:
    • Criminal Use: The juice can be introduced vaginally as a form of punishment for infidelity or applied to the cervical os for illegal abortions.
    • Malingering: The juice can simulate conjunctivitis or falsely substantiate assault claims, as the lesions resemble bruises (Option A)

questions.text: A 7-year-old child presents with the eye condition shown in the image. The child reports severe eye pain, redness, and eyelid swelling.
