Examination reveals an inflamed conjunctiva with thick, adherent membranes that bleed when removed. Which of the following organisms is most likely responsible for this presentation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Corynebacterium diphtheria

 

Explanation:

  • Child symptoms like thick, adherent membranes that bleed upon removal, along with the image showing inflamed conjunctiva with adherent membrane, suggest the diagnosis of membranous conjunctivitis.
  • Corynebacterium diphtheria is the most common cause of membranous conjunctivitis.

 

Aspect

Membranous Conjunctivitis

Pseudomembranous Conjunctivitis

Characteristics

  • True membranes grow into the conjunctival epithelium and are more adherent.
  • Removal of these membranes often results in significant bleeding.
  • More superficial, with no growth into conjunctival epithelium, and are less adherent than true membranes.
  • These can be removed with minimal bleeding.

Causes

  • Bacterial: Corynebacterium diphtheria.
  • Drug Reactions: Hypersensitivity reactions, Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS).
  • Chemical or thermal injury.
  • Infectious: Mild Corynebacterium diphtheria infection, Neisseria gonorrhoeae (Option B ruled out), Streptococcus pyogenes (Option D ruled out), Staphylococcus aureus, adenovirus (Option A ruled out), COVID-19.
  • Inflammatory: Hypersensitivity reactions, foreign body reactions.
  • Ligneous Conjunctivitis

Image

Symptoms

  • Eye redness
  • Eyelid swelling
  • Watery discharge
  • Visual disturbances
  • Foreign body sensation

Signs

  • Conjunctival hyperemia
  • Chemosis
  • Eyelid edema
  • Corneal edema
  • Mucopurulent discharge

Management

  • Topical steroids and antibiotics.
  • Lubricants improve comfort and rehydrate the eye.
  • Membranes can dissolve on their own.
  • Peeling of pseudomembrane.
  • Topical steroids and antibiotics.
  • Removal of foreign bodies if present.
  • Washing the ocular surface to remove chemical irritants.

questions.text: Based on the microscopic image shown below, identify the organism?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) Aspergillus

Explanation:

The given image shows:

  • Acute angle dichotomous branching hyphae
  • Septate hyphae

These are the characteristic findings of Aspergillus.

 

Morphology of different fungi

FUNGI

MORPHOLOGY

MICROSCOPY

Aspergillus

Acute angle dichotomous branching hyphae + septate hyphae

Mucor and Rhizopus species

(Option A and B)

Broad, aseptate hyphae branching at 90 degrees or more

Candida

(Option C)

Single-cell with or without pseudohyphae

questions.text: Which of the following statements correctly describes the pathways of complement activation?

choices.text: The classical pathway is triggered by the spontaneous hydrolysis of C3 and does not require antibodies.
The alternative pathway is initiated by the binding of mannose-binding lectin (MBL) to mannose residues on pathogens.
The lectin pathway involves the binding of C1q to antigen-antibody complexes, leading to the formation of the membrane attack complex (MAC).
All three pathways converge at the formation of C3 convertase, which cleaves C3 into C3a and C3b.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) All three pathways converge at the formation of C3 convertase, which cleaves C3 into C3a and C3b.

Explanation:

The convergence of the pathways at C3 convertase is crucial for activating the complement cascade, regardless of the pathway triggered. This is a key feature of the complement system, allowing for a unified response to pathogen invasion.

 

Complement System:

  • Definition: A complex network of at least 30 proteins in the blood, crucial for innate and acquired immunity.
  • Functions:
    • Lysis: Directly kills pathogens by forming membrane pores.
    • Opsonization: Coats pathogens to enhance recognition and uptake by phagocytes.
    • Immune Clearance: Removes immune complexes from circulation.
    • Inflammation: Triggers release of mediators, recruiting immune cells.

Pathways of Complement Activation:

 

Pathway

Trigger Mechanism

Key Components Involved

Classical Pathway

Binding of C1q to antigen-antibody complexes (Option A ruled out)

C1q, C3 convertase, Membrane Attack Complex (MAC)

Alternative Pathway

Direct binding of complement proteins to pathogens (Option B ruled out)

C3, factors B and D, C3 convertase

Lectin Pathway

Binding of mannose-binding lectin (MBL) to mannose (Option C ruled out)

MBL, MASP1, MASP2, C4, C2, C3 convertase

 

Key Points:

  • Convergence: All pathways converge at the formation of the C3 convertase.
  • C3 Convertase: Cleaves C3 into C3a and C3b, leading to the formation of C5 convertase and, ultimately, MAC.
  • Regulation: The complement system is tightly regulated to prevent excessive activation and damage to host tissues.
  • Regulatory Proteins: Include inhibitors and inactivators that control the cascade.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman with a history of thyroid disease presents with bilateral eye bulging and difficulty closing her eyes. On examination, there is noticeable eye protrusion, eyelid swelling, and restricted extraocular movements. Which of the following best describes the pathogenesis of her eye condition?

choices.text: Extraocular muscles are the primary target of inflammation.
The earliest defective ocular movement seen in this patient is depression.
T-cells attack the orbital fibroblasts and adipocytes in the orbit.
Inflammation is primarily due to neutrophils.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) T-cells attack the orbital fibroblasts and adipocytes in the orbit.

 

Explanation:

  • This scenario is related to thyroid eye disease (Graves’ orbitopathy), where T-cells attack orbital fibroblasts and adipocytes.
  • This autoimmune response causes inflammation, increased fat formation, and swelling, leading to eye protrusion and eyelid swelling.
  • The extraocular muscles are affected secondarily.

Pathogenesis of Thyroid Eye Disease (Graves' Orbitopathy)

  • It involves an organ-specic autoimmune reaction in which anti-thyrotropin-receptor antibody reacts against thyroid gland cells and orbital broblasts.
  • Insulin-like growth factor 1 receptor (IGF-1R) and the thyroid-stimulating hormone receptor (TSHR) are upregulated in orbital and brow fat, leading to inflammation of extraocular muscles, interstitial tissues, orbital fat and lacrimal glands.
  • Osmotic imbibition of water (pleomorphic cellular infiltration (Option D ruled out) and increased secretion of glycosaminoglycans) and lipogenesis induced by broblasts and preadipocytes, which causes orbital fat enlargement.
  • Optic nerve may be compression (increased IOP).
  • Subsequent degeneration of muscle fibres results in restrictive myopathy and diplopia.
  • Primary Target: Orbital fibroblasts
  • Secondary Involvement: Extraocular muscles (Option A ruled out).
  • Optic nerve compression in thyroid ophthalmopathy is typically due to increased orbital volume (from inflammation and muscle swelling), not from vascular occlusion.
  • The increase in orbital contents can compress the optic nerve, leading to visual disturbances.

 

  • The earliest defective ocular movement seen in this patient is elevation. (Option B)

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy presents with persistent pain in his right leg, which is worse at night and relieved by ibuprofen. Physical examination is unremarkable, with no swelling or warmth over the affected area. An X-ray of the right leg is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Osteoid Osteoma

 

Explanation:

  • The patient presenting with persistent pain, relieved by NSAIDs and an X-ray showing a characteristic lesion with a sclerotic margin and radiolucent nidus, points towards an Osteoid Osteoma.

 

Osteoid Osteoma

A small, benign bone tumor composed of osteoid and woven bone with a surrounding halo of reactive bone

Demographics
  • Sex: Males > Females
  • Age: Young patients, but rare under 5 years and over 30.

Location
  • The diaphysis of long bones, especially the proximal tibia, and femur.
  • It can also occur in the spine, particularly the posterior arches.

Pathophysiology

The nidus releases prostaglandins which cause the characteristic pain that relieves on taking NSAIDs

Symptoms
  • Characterized by pain, often worse at night (Night crises), and relieved by NSAIDs (Therapeutic test).
  • When near joints, it may cause stiffness and effusion.
  • In the spine, it can lead to muscle spasms and scoliosis.

Radiology

X-Ray:

  • Dense sclerosis with a small, rounded area of osteolysis, often obscured by the surrounding sclerosis.
  • The characteristic lesion is less than 1.5 cm in diameter with a sclerotic margin and radiolucent nidus.

Isotope bone scans (Best investigation) are positive

Histology
  • Consists of a mesh of woven bone, osteoblastic rimming, osteoclasts, and dilated capillaries.
  • The mature osteoid forms the nidus, surrounded by dense, reactive bone and soft tissue with inflammatory changes.

Treatment
  • CT-guided radiofrequency ablation.
  • Surgical excision of the nidus (gold standard)

 

Simple bone cyst (Option A):

  • It is usually asymptomatic and occurs in the metaphysis.
  • On X-rays, it appears as a well-marginated, unilocular lytic lesion with a thin rim of sclerosis.

 

Brodie’s Abscess (Option C):

  • It is a subacute form of osteomyelitis that presents with localized pain, often associated with low-grade infection.
  • It can also have a radiolucent lesion but is usually accompanied by systemic signs like fever and swelling.

 

Ewing's Sarcoma (Option D):

  • It usually presents with systemic symptoms like fever and shows a characteristic onion-skin periosteal reaction on X-ray.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with symptoms including skin thickening on her fingers, fatigue, and shortness of breath with episodes of painful swelling in her fingertips and difficulty swallowing. During her examination, a specific immunofluorescence test is performed, revealing the presence of several autoantibodies. Which of the following auto-antibodies is most likely associated with severe skin involvement and interstitial lung disease in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Topoisomerase I (Scl-70)

Explanation:

  • The patient's symptoms, including skin thickening, fatigue, and shortness of breath, suggest systemic sclerosis with severe skin and pulmonary involvement.
  • Topoisomerase I (Scl-70) is associated with diffuse cutaneous SSc and linked to severe skin involvement, interstitial lung disease (ILD), and renal crisis.

Auto-Antibody

SSc Subset

Prominent Characteristic

Topoisomerase I (Scl-70)

dcSSc
  • Speckled pattern
  • Tendon friction rubs, digital ischemic ulcers, scleroderma, extensive skin involvement, early ILD, cardiac involvement, scleroderma renal crisis

Centromere proteins

lcSSc
  • Discrete speckled (centromere) pattern
  • Digital ischemic ulcers, calcinosis cutis, isolated PAH; renal crisis rare (Option A ruled out)

RNA polymerase III

dcSSc
  • Speckled pattern
  • Rapidly progressive skin involvement, tendon friction rubs, joint contractures, GAVE, renal crisis, contemporaneous cancers; digital ulcers rare (Option C ruled out)

U3-RNP (fibrillarin)

dc/lc SSc
  • Nucleolar pattern
  • PAH, ILD, scleroderma renal crisis, GI tract involvement, myositis

Th/To

dc/lc SSc
  • Nucleolar pattern
  • ILD, PAH

PM/Scl

dc/lc SSc
  • Nucleolar pattern
  • Calcinosis cutis, ILD, myositis overlap

Ku

overlap
  • Speckled pattern
  • SLE, myositis overlap

U1-RNP

dc/lc SSc
  • Speckled pattern
  • PAH, inflammatory arthritis, myositis overlap (Option D ruled out)

U11/U12 RNP

dc/lc SSc
  • Speckled pattern
  • ILD

Note:

  • Dc SSc- Diffuse cutaneous SSc
  • Lc SSc- Limited cutaneous SSc

questions.text:
Select which all statements are true from the following:


	For painless labor: T8 block
	For instrumental delivery: Pudendal nerve block
	Pain during early labor: T8-T10
	Pain during late labor: S2-S4
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 2, 4

 

Explanation:

Labor Pain:

  • Early labor pain is referred to dermatomes T10-T12. (Statement 3)
  • Late labor pain is referred to dermatomes S2-S4. (Statement 4)
  • For painless labor epidural anesthesia is administered at the level of T10 nerve root. (Statement 1)
  • For instrumental deliveries the pudendal nerve block is administered. (Statement 2)

 

Nerve Supply of Uterus:

Sympathetic nerve supply

T11-L1 of hypogastric plexus

Parasympathetic nerve supply

S2-S4 via pelvic plexus

Afferent nerves supplying uterus

T10-L1
  • Cervix and the upper part of vagina is innervated by S2-S4
  • Lower part of vagina and perineum is innervated by pudendal nerve.

questions.text:
A 55 y/o male heart transplant patient comes for a follow-up visit. He reports that he has been engaging in moderate exercise for about 30 minutes daily. Despite lacking sympathetic innervation to his transplanted heart, he notices an increase in his stamina and ability to exercise over time.

Given the patient's condition, what physiological mechanism allows him to experience an increase in cardiac output during exercise?

choices.text: Increased heart rate through parasympathetic withdrawal.
An enhanced force of contraction via the Frank-Starling mechanism.
Parasympathetic stimulation reduces heart rate variability.
Increased heart rate through sympathetic stimulation to heart.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Enhanced force of contraction via the Frank-Starling mechanism

Explanation:

The Frank-Starling mechanism allows the heart to increase stroke volume by enhancing the force of contraction in response to increased venous return during exercise, thereby increasing cardiac output.

While parasympathetic withdrawal can lead to a slight increase in heart rate, it is not the primary mechanism by which cardiac output is increased in a heart transplant patient during exercise(Option A).

 

Aspect

Details

Frank-Starling Mechanism

More heart muscle stretch during filling leads to stronger contractions and higher stroke volume.

Sympathetic Innervation

Lost in heart transplant patients; cannot increase heart rate through the sympathetic nervous system. (Option D)

Parasympathetic Innervation

Lost in heart transplant patients; cannot decrease heart rate through the parasympathetic nervous system. (Option C)

Stroke Volume Increase

Achieved by increased force of contraction in response to increased venous return during exercise.

Cardiac Output

Increased primarily due to higher stroke volume, not heart rate.

Comparison to Healthy Individuals

Less increase in cardiac output, relying on stroke volume rather than both stroke volume and heart rate.

So, in transplant patients,the increase in cardiac output during exercise is mainly due to an increase in stroke volume, not heart rate.

questions.text: A patient presents with autoimmune hemolytic anemia, thrombocytopenia and neutropenia. Based on the flow cytometry findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Hyper IgM syndrome

Explanation:

The clinical presentation of autoimmune hemolytic anaemia, thrombocytopenia and neutropenia with the flow cytometry findings showing CD40 negative and CD19 negative, is most likely suggestive of Hyper IgM syndrome.

Hyper IgM syndrome:

  • In hyper IgM syndrome, mature B cells are present, but they are incapable of Ig class switching and affinity maturation because of a defect in the CD40 receptor or CD40 ligand.
  • The patient’s serum will have elevated levels of IgM but no IgA or IgE and extremely low levels of IgG.
  • Occasionally, the IgM antibodies react with blood cells, giving rise to autoimmune hemolytic anemia, thrombocytopenia, and neutropenia.

Flow cytometry:

  • Flow cytometry results are typically represented as histograms or dot plots:
    • Histograms: Represent the frequency distribution of a single parameter.
    • Dot plots: Display two parameters on the x- and y-axes.
  • The given image is a dot plot and it has 4 quadrants as follows:

Quadrant 1 (green)

Negative for antigen A, positive for antigen B

Quadrant 2 (purple)

Negative for both antigens

Quadrant 3 (yellow)

Positive for both antigens

Quadrant 4 (red)

Positive for antigen A, negative for antigen B
  • The dot plot in the question has CD19 (pan B-cell marker) on the X-axis and CD40 on the Y-axis. The majority of the cells are in the double negative quadrant, indicating that both CD40 and CD19 are almost negative in this patient, suggesting the diagnosis of hyper IgM syndrome.

Hyper IgM syndrome (Option C) is characterized by CD40L deficiency (X-linked) or CD40 deficiency (autosomal recessive), which affects both B and T cells.

Paroxysmal Nocturnal Hemoglobinuria (Option A): A flow cytogram of blood from a patient with PNH shows a population of red cells that is deficient in both CD55 and CD59.

Glanzmann Thrombasthenia (Option D): It is a platelet disorder characterized by glycoprotein IIb/IIIa defect, also known as CD41 (GpIIb) and CD61 (GpIIIa). Hence CD41 and CD61 are both negative on flow cytometry.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man with a history of chronic alcohol abuse is admitted to the hospital due to severe alcohol withdrawal symptoms. After stabilisation, he expresses his desire to overcome his alcohol dependence and seeks assistance from the healthcare team. Which of the following is not an anti-craving drug commonly used in the management of alcohol dependence?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Disulfiram

 

Explanation:

  • Disulfiram is FDA-approved for alcohol dependence but is not an anti-craving drug, as it works by causing adverse reactions when alcohol is consumed.
 

Drug Name

Mechanism of Action

Notes

FDA-
approved anti-craving drugs

Naltrexone (Option A)

Blocks opioid receptors

Reduces cravings and desire to drink

Acamprosate (Option B)

Modulates glutamate & GABA systems

Reduces cravings and helps maintain abstinence

Not FDA-
approved (off-label use)

Baclofen

GABA agonist

Helps with alcohol withdrawal symptoms

Gabapentin

& Topiramate (Option D)

Modulates GABA & glutamate systems

Helps with alcohol withdrawal symptoms

questions.text: Which of the following is a specific objective of Navjaat Shishu Suraksha Karyakram (NSSK)?

choices.text: To increase access to prenatal care for expecting mothers.
To improve sanitation facilities in rural healthcare centers.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) To prevent Perinatal Asphyxia-Related mortality.

 

Explanation:

  • NSSK aims to reduce India's Neonatal Mortality Rate, aligning with global health targets, emphasizing improved newborn health outcomes and reduced mortality from conditions like perinatal asphyxia.

 

Navjaat Shishu Suraksha Karyakram(NSSK)
  • A training program launched by the Indian Government to equip doctors and nurses with essential newborn care skills, specifically addressing birth asphyxia.
  • Training program for medical officers (MOs) and auxiliary nurse-midwives (ANMs) is two days long
  • The ultimate goal is to reduce newborn mortality and morbidity.

Goals/Objectives
  • Reduce Neonatal Mortality Rate: Decrease India's Neonatal Mortality Rate to single digits by 2030.
  • Improve Newborn Care Quality: Enhance the quality of newborn care.
  • Prevent Perinatal Asphyxia-Related Issues: Reduce morbidity and mortality linked to perinatal asphyxia.

Strategies

  • Capacity Building: Equip healthcare providers with necessary knowledge and skills.
  • Essential Newborn Care and Resuscitation Training.
  • Updated Curriculum and Training Methodology
  • Standardized Equipment and Supplies: Provide clean, functional equipment.
  • Effective Knowledge and Skill Transfer: Improve practical application of training.
  • Focus on "Golden Minute": Quick assessment and resuscitation. Promoting Clean Birth Practices: Adhere to WHO's "six cleans". Kangaroo Mother Care (KMC). Promotion: Encourage KMC for low birth weight babies.
  • Timely Immunization: Ensure vaccination before discharge.
  • Educate parents on newborn care.
  • Effective Neonatal Transport: Establish protocols for the safe transport of sick newborns.

 

 

To promote exclusive breastfeeding practices (Option A): Incorrect because while important, this is mainly promoted by other programs like IMNCI or Breastfeeding promotion initiatives.

To increase access to prenatal care (Option B): Incorrect because NSSK focuses on newborn care, not prenatal care.

To improve sanitation facilities (Option C): Incorrect because sanitation is not an objective of NSSK but broader public health programs.

questions.text: A 26-year-old pregnant woman was treated with an antibiotic for chlamydia during-her 6th month of pregnancy. Nine months later, she delivered a healthy baby boy. As the child grew, he developed teeth resembling those in the provided image and had a short stature. Which antibiotic was most likely used?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Tetracyclines

 

Explanation:

  • Tetracyclines are contraindicated in pregnancy, lactation, and children due to the risk of calcium-tetracycline chelation, which can lead to permanent yellowish discolouration of teeth and inhibited bone growth.
  • It should also be avoided with dairy products as they reduce drug absorption.
  • Contraindication of tetracycline :
    • Pregnancy
    • Children
    • During lactation
    • Renal failure (Except Doxyxline)
  • Adverse effects of tetracycline are:
  • Acute hepatic necrosis: seen in pregnancy
  • Fanconi syndrome
  • Photosensitivity
  • Permanent discolouration of teeth (due to in-utero exposure)
  • Delayed growth
  • Diabetes insipidus
  • Rarely, ↑ ICP in children/pseudotumor cerebri
  • Vestibulotoxic (minocycline)
  • Exfoliative dermatitis (hypersensitivity reaction)

Amikacin (Option B) is also contraindicated during pregnancy due to potential ototoxicity and nephrotoxicity, but it does not affect bone growth or tooth colour.

Chloramphenicol (Option C) is contraindicated in pregnancy due to the risk of 'grey baby syndrome', which can lead to severe symptoms like hypotonia, distended abdomen, cyanosis, and cardiovascular collapse.

Sulfonamide (Option D) is a sulfa drug that displaces bilirubin from albumin, leading to unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia, which leads to kernicterus. Thus, it should be avoided during pregnancy and in neonates.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male with terminal cancer is being treated in a palliative care unit. The physician is aware that disclosing the full extent of his poor prognosis may cause severe distress and worsen his psychological state. However, his family is requesting detailed information about his condition to be disclosed to the patient. Which of the following ethical principles is most appropriate for the physician to apply in this situation?

choices.text: The physician should use full disclosure and inform the patient of all risks, benefits, and prognosis, allowing the patient to make an informed decision about further care.
The physician should apply therapeutic privilege, withholding certain information if it is believed that disclosing the full prognosis could harm the patient’s emotional well-being.
The physician should rely on therapeutic privilege but must always seek approval from the patient’s family before withholding any information.
The physician should provide the information to the family only, as full disclosure primarily concerns the patient's relatives in situations involving terminal illness.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) The physician should apply therapeutic privilege, withholding certain information if it is believed that disclosing the full prognosis could harm the patient’s emotional well-being.

 

Explanation:

Full Disclosure:

  • Refers to the physician's ethical responsibility to share all relevant information about the patient's diagnosis, prognosis, and treatment options.
  • This allows the patient to make informed decisions, emphasizing autonomy and respect for their right to know the full extent of their condition.
  • In this scenario, full disclosure would mean the physician informs the patient of all the details regarding their prognosis, even if it could cause psychological distress.
  • Full disclosure primarily concerns the patient, not the family.
  • While family members can be involved in discussions, the ethical duty to disclose information focuses on the patient’s right to know about their own condition. (Option D)
  • Full disclosure may not always be appropriate, especially in sensitive situations where revealing all information could cause psychological harm. (Option A)

 

Therapeutic Privilege:

  • Therapeutic privilege allows a physician to withhold certain information if revealing it could harm the patient's emotional or mental health.
  • This is used only in cases where full disclosure may cause more harm than benefit.
  • In the given scenario, the physician may choose not to disclose the full severity of the prognosis if it is deemed that this information would negatively impact the patient’s mental state.
  • Therapeutic privilege does not require the physician to seek approval from the family before withholding information. (Option C)
  • The decision to withhold information is primarily based on the physician's judgment about the potential harm to the patient, though family involvement may be helpful in some cases.

questions.text: A 9-month-old pediatric patient presents with hypotonia, seizures, and delays in achieving developmental milestones. The child exhibits characteristic facial features, including a prominent forehead, sparse eyebrows, and distinct hair appearance. Laboratory results reveal decreased levels of copper and ceruloplasmin. What is the pattern of inheritance for this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) X-linked recessive.

 

Explanation:

  • The patient exhibits hypotonia, seizures, and developmental delays, along with characteristic facial features such as a prominent forehead, sparse eyebrows, and kinky hair.
  • Laboratory tests reveal low levels of copper and ceruloplasmin.
  • These clinical signs are consistent with Menkes disease, an X-linked recessive disorder caused by mutations in the ATP7A gene, leading to impaired copper transport and significant neurological deficits, predominantly affecting males.

 

Menkes Kinky Hair Disease:

  • Menkes Kinky Hair Disease (also known as Menkes disease or Menkes syndrome) is a rare, X-linked recessive genetic disorder that affects copper levels in the body.
  • It is caused by mutations in the ATP7A gene, which is responsible for regulating the transport of copper in and out of cells.

 

Presentation:

Neurological Symptoms

Developmental delay, hypotonia (poor muscle tone), seizures

Hair Abnormalities

Brittle, sparse hair with a "kinky" or twisted appearance under a microscope.

Failure to Thrive

Poor feeding, vomiting, and lack of weight gain

Connective Tissue Issues

Weak bones (osteopenia), loose skin and joints due to lack of copper-dependent enzymes involved in collagen cross-linking

Characteristic Facial Features

Sagging cheeks, depressed nasal bridge

Blood Vessel Complications

Fragile arteries, leading to complications like subdural hemorrhage.

 

Diagnosis:

  • Genetic testing to identify mutations in the ATP7A gene (gold standard).
  • Plasma copper and ceruloplasmin levels are typically low.
  • Microscopic examination of hair shows the characteristic kinky or twisted appearance.

 

Management:

  • No cure for Menkes disease.
  • Early treatment with parenteral copper histidinate injections may improve outcomes if started early, though it is not fully curative.
  • Supportive care includes managing seizures, nutritional support, and physical therapy.

Autosomal recessive (Option A):
Incorrect because Menkes disease follows an X-linked, not autosomal, inheritance pattern.

Mitochondrial inheritance (Option B):
Incorrect because mitochondrial disorders are maternally inherited and do not match the copper metabolism defect seen here.

Autosomal dominant (Option D):
Incorrect because there is no dominant transmission pattern in Menkes; it is transmitted via the X chromosome.

questions.text: Which of the following anesthetics is ordered from lowest to highest in terms of Minimum Alveolar Concentration (MAC) values (indicating potency)?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Halothane, Isoflurane, Desflurane

Explanation:

  • Halothane has the lowest MAC and a higher blood-gas partition coefficient, making it the most potent of the three.
  • Isoflurane has a moderate MAC and partition coefficient.
  • Desflurane has the highest MAC, indicating it is the least potent of the three.

Mnemonic for most potent to least potent: MaHI Straight Drive - Methoxyflurane, Halothane, Isoflurane, Sevoflurane, Desflurane.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child presents to the community health centre with a fever, malaise, and an itchy, vesicular rash (shown in the image below) that began two days ago. The child's mother asks when it will be safe for her child to return to school without posing a risk of spreading the infection to other children. What is the appropriate advice regarding the duration of isolation for this child to prevent the spread of this infection?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Until all lesions are crusted

Explanation:

  • The given scenario and rash in the image depict Chickenpox caused by the varicella-zoster virus.
  • It is highly contagious and primarily spreads through respiratory droplets and direct contact with vesicular fluid from the rash.
  • Proper isolation and prevention strategies are crucial to prevent the spread of this infection, especially in settings like schools.

 

Period of isolation:

  • The separation of infected individuals or animals from others during the period when they can transmit the infection.

 

Disease

Duration of isolation

Chickenpox

Until all lesions are crusted, usually 6 days after the onset of the rash (Option D)

Measles

7 days after the onset of rash (Option A)

Diphtheria

Until 48 hrs of antibiotics or negative cultures after treatment (Option B)

Salmonellosis

Until 3 negative stool cultures (Option C)

Pertussis

4 weeks or until paroxysms cease

Mumps

Until swelling subsides

Tuberculosis

Until 3 weeks of effective chemotherapy

Cholera

3 days after tetracycline started

questions.text: A 28-year-old male presents to the clinic with painless ulcers on his genital region that have been present for about three weeks as shown below. He denies any associated symptoms such as fever, malaise, or lymphadenopathy. His sexual history reveals multiple partners in the past year. What is the most likely diagnosis based on the clinical presentation?
questions.solution:
Corect Answer: B) Primary syphilis

Explanation:

Primary syphilis is the initial stage of syphilis infection, typically occurring about three weeks after exposure to the bacterium Treponema pallidum. The hallmark of this stage is the development of a painless ulcer known as a chancre, which appears at the site where the bacteria entered the body—commonly on the genitals, anus, or mouth.

Characteristics of the Chancre:

  • The chancre is usually round, firm, and painless. It can vary in size, often resembling a small, raised sore.

  • It is highly infectious and typically lasts between three to six weeks. Even though it heals on its own, the absence of symptoms does not mean the infection is gone; the bacteria remain in the body.

Transmission:

Syphilis is primarily transmitted through sexual contact, but it can also spread from mother to child during pregnancy or childbirth, leading to congenital syphilis.

Symptoms:

  • The chancre is the only symptom in primary syphilis, but regional lymph nodes may become swollen and painless.

Diagnosis:

Diagnosis is often made through clinical examination of the chancre and serological tests that detect antibodies to Treponema pallidum.

Genital herpes (Option A): Usually presents with painful ulcers and is often associated with systemic symptoms like fever and malaise.

 

Chancroid (Option C): Typically causes painful ulcers and is associated with swollen lymph nodes (lymphadenopathy).


Lymphogranuloma venereum (Option D): Characterized by an ulcer, but typically presents with significant lymphadenopathy and systemic symptoms.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male with a significant smoking history presents with a persistent cough, dyspnea, weight loss, and fatigue. A Chest CT reveals a suspicious mass in the right upper lobe. A biopsy of the mass shows adenocarcinoma. Further molecular testing reveals high PD-L1 expression (>50%) and no actionable mutations in EGFR, ALK, or ROS1. Which of the following drugs would you choose as the first line of treatment in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Pembrolizumab

 

Explanation:

  • Pembrolizumab is an immune checkpoint inhibitor that targets the PD-1 receptor on T-cells.
  • The patient's symptoms, CT findings, molecular testing, and biopsy tests of adenocarcinoma (the most common subtype of NSCLC) results are typical presentations for a patient with non-small cell lung carcinoma (NSCLC).
  • Here, the patient has high PD-L1 expression (>50%).
  • Pembrolizumab is particularly effective in NSCLC patients with high PD-L1 expression (≥50%) and is approved as a first-line treatment for these patients when there are no actionable mutations in EGFR, ALK, or ROS1.

MOA of Immune Checkpoint Inhibitors:

 

Erlotinib (Option A):

  • It is a tyrosine kinase inhibitor (TKI) that targets the EGFR. These mutations are more common in non-smokers.

Bevacizumab (Option B):

  • It is a monoclonal antibody that inhibits VEGF, thereby inhibiting angiogenesis.
  • It is used in combination with chemotherapy for certain types of cancer, including NSCLC.

Ipilimumab (Option D):

  • It is a CTLA-4 inhibitor.
  • By blocking CTLA-4, ipilimumab enhances T-cell activation and proliferation, promoting an immune response against cancer cells.

 

Immune Checkpoint Inhibitors and their uses:

Blocks CTLA4 receptor

Blocks PD-L-1 receptor

Blocks PD-1 receptor
  • Ipilimumab
  • Tremelimumab

 
  • Atezolizumab
  • Avelumab
  • Durvalumab

 
  • Nivolumab
  • Cepilimumab
  • Pembrolizumab

questions.text: A 45-year-old male recipient of a kidney transplant presents with a sudden increase in serum creatinine levels three days post-transplant. Laboratory tests reveal the presence of donor-specific antibodies (DSAs) and linear C4d staining in peritubular capillaries on biopsy. Which of the following statements best describes the condition?

choices.text: It is primarily mediated by T-cell activation.
It is characterized by the presence of pre-existing antibodies against donor antigens.
It is commonly associated with chronic rejection mechanisms.
It usually resolves spontaneously without intervention.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) It is characterized by the presence of pre-existing antibodies against donor antigens.

Explanation:

Acute Humoral Rejection (AHR) is diagnosed through the presence of donor-specific antibodies (DSAs) in the serum, along with histological evidence of glomerulitis or peritubular capillaritis observed in biopsy samples. Additionally, linear C4d staining in peritubular capillaries serves as a critical marker for confirming the diagnosis.

 

Acute Humoral Rejection (AHR):

  • Definition
    • Significant complication in organ transplantation, particularly in kidney transplants.
    • Characterized by donor-specific antibodies (DSAs) targeting the vascular endothelium, leading to tissue injury and graft dysfunction.

Mechanisms of AHR:

  • Pathophysiology
    • Binding of DSAs to donor HLA molecules activates the complement system, resulting in:
      • Capillary Injury: Damage to peritubular capillaries is a hallmark of AHR.
      • C4d Deposition: A key diagnostic marker; approximately 30% of acute rejection biopsies show widespread C4d staining.
      • Histological Features: May include neutrophilic infiltration, glomerulitis, and fibrinoid necrosis in severe cases.

Diagnosis:

  • Diagnostic Criteria
    • Combination of clinical presentation, serological testing, and histopathological findings:
      • Histologic Evidence: Glomerulitis or peritubular capillaritis.
      • Antibody Interaction: Linear C4d staining indicates recent antibody interaction with vascular endothelium.
      • Detection of DSAs: Presence of DSAs in serum confirms diagnosis.

Clinical Presentation:

  • Symptoms
    • Patients may experience:
      • Acute Elevation in Creatinine: Noted within days to weeks post-transplant.
      • Fever and Malaise: General systemic inflammation signs.
      • Graft Tenderness: Possible tenderness over the transplant site.

Treatment:

  • Management Approaches
    • Aim to reduce antibody-mediated injury:
      • Plasmapheresis: Removes circulating antibodies.
      • Intravenous Immunoglobulin (IVIG): Modulates immune responses.
      • Rituximab: Targets CD20 on B cells to reduce antibody production.
      • Eculizumab: A complement inhibitor effective in severe AHR cases.

It is primarily mediated by T-cell activation (Option A) is incorrect because AHR is primarily mediated by antibody interactions, not T-cell responses.

 

It is commonly associated with chronic rejection mechanisms (Option C) is incorrect since AHR is an acute process, distinct from chronic rejection.

 

It usually resolves spontaneously without intervention (Option D) is incorrect; AHR typically requires immunosuppressive treatment for resolution.

questions.text:
A 60-year-old male with a history of glaucoma was recently diagnosed with primary Parkinson's disease and started treatment with syndopa (levodopa-carbidopa) therapy. The patient inquires about potential adverse events associated with the treatment. Which of the following statements is false?


	Nausea is the most common adverse effect due to the activation of D2 receptors inside the GIT.
	Dyskinesias and impulsiveness are common adverse effects associated with long-term levodopa use.
	Levodopa is contraindicated in this patient with a history of narrow-angle glaucoma.
	Long-term use of levodopa is associated with fluctuations in motor symptoms.
	Levodopa increases treatment efficacy with carbidopa.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Only 1 

 

Explanation:

  • Nausea/ vomiting: (Statement 1)
    • Most common
    • Due to D2 receptor activation in CTZ outside the blood-brain barrier.
    • Treat with domperidone (Blocks D2 receptor)

True statements:

Statement 2: Dyskinesias and impulsiveness are common adverse effects associated with long-term levodopa use.

Statement 3: Levodopa is contraindicated in this patient with a history of narrow-angle glaucoma, as it can block the trabecular outflow

Statement 4: On-off phenomenon- Fluctuating course of improved mobility followed by akinesia

Statement 5: Combining Levodopa with peripheral dopa decarboxylase inhibitors (Carbidopa/Bensarazide) prevents peripheral side effects. (Statement 5)

questions.text: A 72-year-old male presents with a 2-day history of progressive abdominal distension, constipation, and colicky pain. He has a history of chronic constipation and has been bedridden for the past few months due to a hip fracture. On examination, his abdomen is distended and tympanic, with mild tenderness. Abdominal guarding and rigidity not observed. X-ray of the abdomen is shown below. Which of the following factors does not predispose to this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Short pelvic mesocolon

 

Explanation:

  • Based on the clinical presentation and coffee bean sign in the X-ray abdomen, the most probable diagnosis is sigmoid volvulus
  • Long pelvic mesocolon allows the sigmoid colon to move excessively, predisposing it to twist upon its own mesenteric axis causing sigmoid volvulus.

 

Sigmoid volvulus:

  • It is the twist (rotation) in the axis of the loop of the bowel

 

Predisposing factors:

  • High-residue diet
  • Elderly patients with chronic constipation (Option A ruled out)
  • Chronic psychotropic drug
  • Anticholinergic drugs (Option B ruled out)
  • Mentally-retarded individuals (Option C ruled out)
  • Adhesions; Peridiverticulitis
  • Overloaded redundant pelvic colon
  • Long pelvic mesocolon (Option D)
  • Narrow attachment of sigmoid mesocolon

 

 

Investigations:

  • Plain X-ray
    • omega sign- single grossly distended loop of colon arising out of the pelvis and extending towards the diaphragm.
    • Coffee-bean sign or Bent-inner tube sign

  • Contrast enema:
    • Bird's beak sign (ace of spades appearance)- Upper end of the barium column tapers into the spirally twisted distal sigmoid colon.

questions.text: A 55-year-old female presents with hematuria, hemoptysis, and sinusitis. Renal biopsy reveals pauci-immune necrotising crescentic glomerulonephritis. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Wegener's Granulomatosis

Explanation :

The clinical presentation of a 55-year-old female with hematuria, hemoptysis, sinusitis, and renal biopsy showing pauci-immune necrotising crescentic glomerulonephritis is suggestive of Wegener’s granulomatosis.

Rapidly Progressive Glomerulonephritis (RPGN) classification:

  • Type I (Anti-GBM disease) → Anti-GBM antibodies → Goodpasture’s
  • Type II (Immune complex) → SLE, IgA nephropathy, PSGN
  • Type III (Pauci-immune) → ANCA-associated vasculitis (GPA, MPA, EGPA)

Wegener's Granulomatosis (Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis-GPA):

  • It is characterised by pauci-immune necrotising granulomatous vasculitis affecting small- to medium-sized vessels.
  • It causes Necrotizing granulomas in 3 key organs:
    • Respiratory tract (upper + lower) → sinusitis, otitis media, nasal septal perforation, hemoptysis
    • Kidneys → crescentic glomerulonephritis (RPGN type III) → hematuria
    • Blood vessels → systemic small vessel vasculitis
  • In GPA, there is a presence of anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (ANCA), specifically cytoplasmic ANCA (c-ANCA) targeting proteinase 3 (PR3) and sometimes p-ANCA targeting myeloperoxidase (MPO).
  • Another classical triad of GPA (ENT triad):
    • E: Ear → otitis media
    • N: Nose → nasal septal perforation (“saddle-nose”)
    • T: Throat/mouth → strawberry gums

Goodpasture Syndrome (Option B): It causes RPGN I and shows Anti-glomerular basement membrane antibodies (anti-GBM antibodies).

SLE (Option C):  It is a multi-system disorder causing RPGN II and has Anti-Nuclear antibodies (ANA).

Microscopic polyangiitis (Option D) (MPA): It can also cause RPGN III, but it doesn't show other symptoms like hemoptysis and sinusitis

questions.text: A 28-year-old nulliparous woman has been diagnosed with persistent CIN 1 for 2 years after initial observation and monitoring. Colposcopy reveals no high-grade lesions, and the entire lesion and squamocolumnar junction (SCJ) are fully visible. Which treatment option is most appropriate in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Cryoablation

Explanation:

Cryoablation is a local destructive method used to freeze and destroy abnormal cervical tissue, such as CIN 1. It is a suitable treatment option when there is a persistent lesion >2 years which is showing no signs of regression. Also, the entire lesion and SCJ must be visible during colposcopy. Most lesions have spontaneous regression and require no treatment as such.

Treatment Considerations for CIN 1:

  • CIN 1 persisting over 2 years with entire lesion and SCJ visible, no HSIL in endocervical sampling: Preferred treatment is cryoablation.
  • If above criteria not met (lesion visibility, HSIL absence): Excisional treatment is recommended; ablation is not suitable. (Option C)
  • Persistent LSIL may warrant treatment.
  • Patient factors (compliance, preference) may influence treatment decisions.
  • Colposcopy findings may indicate need for treatment.

 

Treatment Options:

  • Local Destructive Methods:
    • Cryosurgery: Freezing abnormal tissue.
    • Electrocoagulation: Using heat from electrical current.
    • Laser Ablation: Using a laser to destroy abnormal cells.
  • Excisional Treatments:
    • LEEP/LLETZ: Removing abnormal tissue with a wire loop electrode. (Option C)
    • Cone Biopsy: Removing a cone-shaped piece of tissue from the cervix.

Cryoablation
  • Local destructive treatment for CIN using freeze-thaw-freeze technique.
  • Instrument: Metal probe uses nitrous oxide to freeze tissue (cryonecrosis).
  • Mechanism: Freezes tissue to 4-5 mm depth using agents like CO2 (-60°C), Freon (-60°C), Nitrous Oxide (-80°C).
  • Indications for Cryoablation:
    • Small cervical lesions.
    • Entirely ectocervical lesions and visible SCJ.
    • Smooth cervical surface without deep crevices.
    • Circumferential length adequate to prevent vaginal wall thermal damage.
  • Advantages: Inexpensive, well-tolerated, painless OP procedure (lasts over 9 mins)
  • Exclusions: Not for previously treated patients, glandular abnormalities, or AIS.
  • Disadvantages:
    • Profuse discharge for 7-10 days post-procedure.
    • Challenges in subsequent colposcopy screenings due to junction retraction.


 

P16 immunochemistry testing (Option A) detects p16 protein overexpression associated with high-risk HPV infections and cervical dysplasia. It helps differentiate between LSIL and HSIL but does not treat CIN 1.

questions.text:
Match the following monoclonal antibody's with their respective mechanism of action.

 


	
		
			
			1. Burosumab
			
			
			A. Inhibits RANKL, reducing osteoclast formation and activity.
			
		
		
			
			2. Romosozumab
			
			
			B. Targets sclerostin, increasing bone formation and decreasing resorption.
			
		
		
			
			3. Denosumab
			
			
			C. Inhibits fibroblast growth factor 23 (FGF23)
			
		
		
			
			4. Rituximab
			
			
			D. Targets CD20 on B cells, leading to their depletion.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 1-C, 2-B, 3-A, 4-D

 

Explanation: 

Burosumab

Inhibits fibroblast growth factor 23 (FGF23).

Romosozumab

Targets sclerostin, increasing bone formation and decreasing resorption.

Denosumab

Inhibits RANKL, reducing osteoclast formation and activity.

Rituximab

Targets CD20 on B cells, leading to their depletion and affecting bone remodeling indirectly.
  • Denosumab is preferred in patients with osteoporosis and chronic kidney disease because it is not eliminated by the kidneys and does not need dose adjustments for renal impairment.
  • It effectively reduces fracture risk and increases bone density in postmenopausal women.

Monoclonal antibody

Description

Denosumab

Mechanism of action:

Denosumab → binds to RANKL (receptor activator of nuclear factor kappa-B ligand) → Prevents the interaction between RANKL and its receptor (RANK) on the surface of osteoclasts and osteoclast precursors → reduction in osteoclast formation, function, and survival → ↓ bone resorption.

Uses:

  • Osteoporosis treatment in postmenopausal women at high fracture risk.
  • Enhancing bone mass in men with osteoporosis.
  • Treat bone loss due to hormone ablation therapy in men with prostate cancer.
  • Hypercalcemia in malignancy.
  • Treatment of Giant cell tumour.

Burosumab

Mechanism of action:

Burosumab (monoclonal antibody) → binds to and inhibits fibroblast growth factor 23 (FGF23) → ↑ phosphate reabsorption in the kidney and ↑ production of active vitamin D.

Uses: Treatment of X-linked hypophosphatemia (XLH) (not osteoporosis)

Romosozumab

Mechanism of action:

Romosozumab → inhibits sclerostin → ↑ bone formation and ↓ bone resorption.

Uses: Osteoporosis in postmenopausal women at high risk of fracture.

Rituximab

Mechanism of action:

Rituximab → targets CD20 (a protein found on the surface of B-cells) → Destruction of B-cells.

Uses: B-cell non-Hodgkin's lymphoma, chronic lymphocytic leukaemia (CLL), and autoimmune diseases such as rheumatoid arthritis

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect with respect to the role of physiological pH of the vagina?

choices.text: The acidic pH of the vagina helps prevent the growth of pathogenic organisms.
Doderlein’s bacillus is responsible for maintaining the acidic pH by converting glycogen to lactic acid under the influence of estrogen.
Doderlein’s bacillus appears in the vagina 3–4 days after birth and disappears after 10–14 days, to reappear at puberty.
An increased vaginal pH can predispose to infections such as vulvovaginal candidiasis.

questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) An increased vaginal pH can predispose to infections such as vulvovaginal candidiasis.

Explanation:

Vulvovaginal candidiasis (yeast infection) typically occurs in a physiological pH of vagina (acidic environment) and is not associated with an increased vaginal pH.

The infections that typically occur in increased vaginal pH are Trichomoniasis and bacterial vaginosis.

Normal physiological pH of vagina i.e. 3.8-5.0 (acidic) helps prevent the growth of pathogenic organisms (Option A). Certain microorganisms thrive when vaginal pH is increased.

Vaginal pH is maintained by the Doderlein’s bacillus which converts glycogen to lactic acid under the influence of estrogen (Option B). Doderlein’s bacillus appears in the vagina 3–4 days after birth, disappears after 10–14 days, and reappears at puberty when estrogen levels rise (Option C).

 

Table: Vaginal pH, Symptoms, and Indications

pH

Symptoms

Diseases

3.8 to 4.4

Normal Physiological pH

-

3.8 to 4.4

Itching, burning, white thick curdy discharge

Vulvovaginal candidiasis

4.5 and above

Itching, fishy smell, thin homogeneous discharge (white to grayish)

Bacterial vaginosis

5.5 and above

Green or yellow, frothy discharge; foul odor; pain with sexual intercourse, vaginal soreness

Trichomoniasis

questions.text: A new drug designed to lower cholesterol levels is being tested. The testing involved 1000 participants. The null hypothesis is that "the new drug does not affect cholesterol levels". After analysing the data, the researchers conclude that the drug doesn't work, but in reality, it does have a small but clinically significant effect. What type of error has occurred?

choices.text: Both Type I and Type II errors

questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Type II error

Explanation:

This scenario describes a Type II error, also known as a "false negative."

  • Type II error occurs when we fail to reject a false null hypothesis.
  • In this case, a potentially beneficial drug might be overlooked.
  • Type II errors are particularly important in medical research, as they can lead to overlooking potentially beneficial treatments.
  • The power of a statistical test (1 - probability of Type II error) is crucial in designing studies to minimise this risk.

Type I error (Option A) occurs when you reject a true null hypothesis.

questions.text: Which of the following statements correctly describes the difference between Cost-Benefit Analysis and Cost-Effective Analysis in health management?

choices.text: Cost-Benefit Analysis focuses on the qualitative aspects of health services, while Cost-Effective Analysis focuses on quantitative aspects.
Cost-benefit analysis compares monetary costs and benefits, whereas Cost-Effectiveness Analysis compares the costs to achieve a specific non-monetary outcome.
Cost-Benefit Analysis is used for planning and budgeting, while Cost-Effective Analysis is used for project scheduling.
Cost-Benefit Analysis evaluates staff performance, whereas Cost-Effective Analysis evaluates patient outcomes.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Cost-benefit analysis compares monetary costs and benefits, whereas Cost-Effective Analysis compares the costs to achieve a specific non-monetary outcome.

 

Explanation:

  • Cost-Benefit Analysis
    • It is a management technique that compares a program's monetary costs with its monetary benefits, expressed in terms of economic gain.
    • It helps determine whether the benefits outweigh the costs in monetary terms.
    • The main drawback with this technique is that the benefits in the health field cannot always be expressed in monetary terms.
  • Cost-Effective Analysis
    • Compares the costs of different interventions to achieve a specific health outcome that is not expressed in monetary terms.
    • It is used to determine the most efficient way to achieve a particular health goal, such as lives saved or cases treated, without converting the outcomes into monetary values.

questions.text: A 62-year-old female presents with persistent pelvic pain and urinary incontinence. Imaging reveals a mass in the pelvic region compressing nearby blood vessels, raising suspicion of internal iliac artery involvement. Which of the following is not a branch of the internal iliac artery?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Deep circumflex iliac artery

 

Explanation:

Deep circumflex iliac artery originates from the external iliac artery, not the internal iliac artery.

 

  • Lateral sacral artery (Option A) is a branch of the posterior division of the internal iliac artery, supplying the sacral region.
  • Uterine artery (Option B) branches from the anterior division of the internal iliac artery and supplies the uterus.
  • Internal pudendal artery (Option C) also arises from the anterior division of the internal iliac artery, it supplies the perineum and external genitalia.

  • Common iliac artery is formed by the bifurcation of the abdominal aorta at the L4 vertebra and divides into the external and internal iliac arteries.
  • External iliac artery, after giving off its branches, continues as the femoral artery, while the internal iliac artery splits into anterior and posterior divisions.

Artery

Branches

Supplies

 

External Iliac Artery

Deep circumflex iliac artery

Muscles attached to

the iliac crest

Inferior epigastric artery

Muscles and overlying skin of rectus sheath

Internal Iliac Artery (Anterior Division)

Superior vesical artery
  • Urinary bladder’s superior surface
  • Muscular wall of ductus deferens

Obturator artery

Medial thigh

Middle rectal artery
  • Muscle coats of rectum
  • Prostate
  • Seminal vesicles

Inferior Vesical artery
  • Urinary bladder
  • Prostate
  • seminal vesicle
  • The lower part of the ureter

Inferior gluteal artery

Gluteal region

Internal Pudendal artery

Perineum region

Vaginal artery

Vagina and base of the urinary bladder

Uterine artery

Vagina and uterus

Internal Iliac Artery (Posterior Division) 

(Mnemonic - SIL)

Superior Gluteal artery

Muscles of the gluteal region
 

Iliolumbar artery
  • Iliacus
  • Muscles of back
  • Cauda equina
 

Lateral sacral artery
  • Cauda equina
  • Back muscles of the sacrum

questions.text: Which statement regarding Type 1 and Type 2 endometrial cancer is correct?

choices.text: Type 1 Endometrial CA is more aggressive and has a poor prognosis than Type 2
Type 1 Endometrial CA is associated with estrogen excess, in young & obese women
Type 2 Endometrial CA is typically low-grade and non-metastasized compared to Type 1
Type 2 Endometrial CA is often estrogen-dependent and associated with hyperplasia.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Type 1 Endometrial CA is associated with estrogen excess, in young & obese women

Explanation:

  • Type 1 Endometrial CA is associated with estrogen excess whereas Type 2 is independent of it.

 

  • In young women, particularly those with obesity, there is an increased production of estrogen due to adipose tissue converting androgens into estrogen.

 

Characteristic

Type 1 Endometrial Cancer

Type 2 Endometrial Cancer

Incidence

More common (80-85%)

Less common (15-20%)

Age at Diagnosis

Younger (around 50s-60s)

Older (postmenopausal women)

Histology

Endometrioid adenocarcinoma

Serous carcinoma, clear cell carcinoma, carcinosarcoma

Association with Hyperplasia

Present

Absent

Estrogen Dependence

Estrogen-driven;

ER +ve

Often estrogen-independent;

HER 2 neu +ve

Grade

Typically low-grade and less aggressive

Often high-grade and aggressive

Prognosis

Better

Worst

Metastatic Potential

Less likely to metastasize

More likely to metastasize

Associated Mutation

PTEN

P53

Type 1 Endometrial CA is more aggressive and has a poor prognosis than Type 2 (Option A) is incorrect because Type 2 endometrial carcinoma is the more aggressive subtype, often presenting as high-grade serous or clear cell carcinoma, with a worse prognosis due to early extrauterine spread, p53 mutations, and resistance to hormonal therapy.

Type 2 Endometrial CA is typically low-grade and non-metastasized compared to Type 1 (Option C) is incorrect because Type 2 cancers are high-grade, with a greater tendency to metastasise via lymphovascular invasion and peritoneal spread. In contrast, Type 1 cancers are generally confined to the uterus at presentation.

Type 2 Endometrial CA is often estrogen-dependent and associated with hyperplasia (Option D) is incorrect because Type 2 cancers are estrogen-independent and not associated with endometrial hyperplasia. They often arise in a background of atrophic endometrium, particularly in older postmenopausal women.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man presents with severe diarrhoea, abdominal cramps, and weight loss. He recently returned from a tropical region and has a history of HIV with a low CD4 count. The stool analysis finding is given in the image. Which of the following statements about the identified organism is not true?

choices.text: Cotrimoxazole is used for the treatment

questions.solution:
• The clinical scenario of diarrhoea in an immunocompromised host and a stool sample showing oval oocysts suggests cystoisospora belli.
  • The incubation period of cystoisospora is 1-4 days, not 2-14 days.

 

Intestinal Coccidian Parasites:

  • Cryptosporidium species: C.parvum (mammals) & C.hominis (primarily humans)
  • Cyclospora cayetanensis
  • Cystoisospora belli

 

Clinical Features:

  • Immunocompetent Hosts: Symptoms are often mild and may include watery, non-bloody diarrhoea, abdominal pain, nausea, and fever. They are typically self-limiting.
  • Immunocompromised Hosts (e.g., AIDS): Severe, persistent diarrhoea (up to 25 litres/day), significant weight loss & extraintestinal manifestations (Biliary infections)
    • Severity increases with lower CD4+ T cell counts

Features

Cryptosporidium

Cyclospora

Cystoisospora

Transmission

Ingestion of contaminated food/water, autoinfection

Ingestion of contaminated food/water

Ingestion of sporulated oocysts

Infective form

Sporulated oocyst

Sporulated oocyst

Sporulated oocyst

Diagnostic form

Sporulated oocyst

Unsporulated oocyst

Unsporulated oocyst

Incubation Period

2-14 days

1-7 days

1-4 days

Oocyst shape

Round

Round

Oval

Oocyst size

4-6 µm

8-10 µm

20–33 µm

Sporulated oocyst

Four sporozoites

Two sporocysts, each having two sporozoites

Two sporocysts, each having four sporozoites

Acid-fastness

Uniformly acid-fast

Variable acid-fast

Uniformly acid-fast

Autofluorescence

–

++

+/-

Resistance to chlorination

+

–

–

Sporulation of the oocyst

Inside the host cells (enterocytes)

soil

soil

Zoonotic potential

Yes

Uncertain

No

Treatment

Nitazoxanide

Cotrimoxazole

Cotrimoxazole
 

 

Cotrimoxazole is used for the treatment (Option A):
Correct – TMP-SMX is the drug of choice for treating Cystoisospora belli infection.

Oocysts are usually between 20–33 µm (Option B):
Correct – The oocysts are typically oval and large (20–33 µm), easily visualized with modified acid-fast stain.

The organism shows variable autofluorescence (Option C):
Correct – Cystoisospora belli oocysts exhibit autofluorescence under UV light microscopy.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female patient with treatment-resistant schizophrenia has started on clozapine. What is the appropriate duration and frequency of blood test monitoring for this patient taking clozapine?

choices.text: Weekly for 6 months, bi-weekly for 6 months, then monthly.
Monthly for 6 months, then every 3 months.
Weekly for 3 months, bi-weekly for 3 months, then monthly.
Monthly for 1 year, then every 6 months.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Weekly for 6 months, bi-weekly for 6 months, then monthly.

Explanation:

  • Clozapine is associated with a risk of agranulocytosis, especially during the first year of treatment.

  • Regular monitoring of Absolute Neutrophil Count (ANC) is mandatory to detect early neutropenia or agranulocytosis.

  • The standard hematological monitoring schedule for patients on clozapine is:

    • Weekly for the first 6 months

    • Every 2 weeks (bi-weekly) for the next 6 months

    • Monthly after 1 year, if ANC remains stable

Monitoring Phase Frequency Duration
Initial phase Weekly First 6 months
Intermediate Bi-weekly Next 6 months
Maintenance Monthly After 1 year, lifelong while on clozapine

 

Monthly for 6 months, then every 3 months (Option B): This monitoring frequency is dangerously infrequent for clozapine, especially during the crucial initial months, and does not meet safety guidelines for agranulocytosis risk.

Weekly for 3 months, bi-weekly for 3 months, then monthly (Option C): This option has an insufficient duration of intensified weekly and bi-weekly monitoring (only 3 months each), leaving patients at higher risk for undetected agranulocytosis compared to the standard 6-month periods.

Monthly for 1 year, then every 6 months (Option D): This schedule is grossly inadequate for clozapine safety monitoring, particularly during the critical first year, and would not allow for timely detection of severe neutropenia or agranulocytosis.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with hot flashes, night sweats, and irregular menstrual cycles, suggesting a decrease in estrogen levels. Which of the following is a primary source of estrogen in premenopausal women, and which of the following is an effect of estrogen on the body?

choices.text: Adrenal cortex; Maintenance of bone density

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Granulosa cells, proliferation of endometrium

Explanation:

Estrogen is primarily secreted by ovaries in granulosa cells and one of its effects is proliferation of endometrium.
 

 

Estrogen

Progesterone

Source

Granulosa cells (Option C), corpus luteum, and placenta

Corpus luteum, placenta and ovarian follicles

Effects on female genitalia
  • Growth of ovarian follicle
  • Proliferation of endometrium (Option C)
  • Increase the motility of the uterine tubes
  • Increase blood flow in the uterus
  • Increase the amount of uterine muscle and contractility.
  • Antiestrogenic effect on the myometrium, decreasing their excitability
  • Secretory effect on the endometrium

Female Secondary Sex Characteristics
  • Enlargement of breasts
  • Female distribution of fat
  • Wide carrying angle
  • Stimulates the development of lobules and alveoli

Effects on the Central Nervous System
  • Increase libido
  • Increase the proliferation of dendrites on neurons and the number of synaptic knobs
  • Thermogenic and responsible for the rise in basal body temperature during ovulation

Effects on Endocrine Organs
  • Increased secretion of angiotensinogen and thyroid-binding globulin
  • Large doses of progesterone inhibit LH secretion and potentiate the inhibitory effect of estrogens, preventing ovulation.

Other effects
  • Retention of salt and water and gain weight just before menstruation
  • Plasma cholesterol-lowering action
  • Vasodilation by increasing the local production of NO.
  • Maintains bone mineral density
  • Stimulates respiration, and the alveolar PCO2
  • Increases plasma LDL and decreases HDL (Option D)

Adrenal cortex; Maintenance of bone density (Option A) The amount of progestin, androgen, and estrogen produced by the adrenal cortex is a minor fraction of the total amount produced in the body. Hence, not the primary source of estrogen.

 

Hepatocytes; enlargement of breast (Option B) Hepatocytes are not involved in estrogen production. Breast enlargement is an effect of estrogen.

 

Corpus luteum, decreases HDL cholesterol (Option D) Corpus luteum secretes more progesterone than estrogen.

questions.text: A 5-month-old male infant with a history of vomiting, irritability, and developmental delay. The onset of symptoms coincided with the introduction of formula feed. Physical examination revealed hepatomegaly and signs of encephalopathy. Blood tests revealed elevated ammonia levels and high glutamine, uracil, and orotic acid concentrations. Citrulline levels were normal. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Type 2 Hyperammonemia

 

Explanation:

The infant's symptoms and laboratory findings with the timing of symptom onset after the introduction of the formula are highly suggestive of Type 2 Hyperammonemia.

 

Feature

Type 1 Hyperammonemia

Type 2 Hyperammonemia

Defective Enzyme

Carbamoyl Phosphate Synthetase I (CPS1)

Ornithine Transcarbamylase (OTC)

Inheritance

Autosomal recessive

X-linked recessive

Mechanism

The inability to synthesize carbamoyl phosphate blocks the urea cycle.

Accumulation of carbamoyl phosphate in the mitochondria, which then spills over into the cytoplasm.

Metabolic Consequences
  • Elevated ammonia and glutamate
  • Normal orotic acid and uracil
  • Low citrulline. (Option A)
  • Elevated ammonia, glutamate, and glutamine.
  • High uracil and orotic acid (excess carbamoyl phosphate enters pyrimidine synthesis).
  • Normal citrulline.

Clinical Presentation
  • Symptoms coincide with increased protein intake.
  • CNS: Lethargy, drowsiness, coma, Convulsions, vomiting, respiratory stimulation, hyperventilation.
  • Similar to Type 1.
  • Hepatomegaly.


 

Citrullinemia and Argininosuccinate aciduria (Option C and D) would result in elevated citrulline levels, contradicting the normal citrulline finding in this scenario.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with a large soft tissue defect on his lower leg following a motorcycle accident. The wound measures 10 cm x 15 cm and involves exposure of the tibia. The plastic surgeon is considering an axial flap for reconstruction. Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding the usage of an axial flap?

choices.text: Axial pattern flaps derive their blood supply directly from a fasciocutaneous artery that runs beneath the flap's longitudinal axis.
It allows for a larger flap design compared to random pattern flaps and delivers better cosmetic results
Deltopectoral flap is a type of axial flap
Due to larger size, axial flaps require a high complexity, multi-step method for reconstruction of defects

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Due to larger size, axial flaps require a high complexity, multi-step method for reconstruction of defects.

 

Explanation:

  • Axial flaps can provide a low complexity, one-step method for reconstruction for defects that are larger in area.
  • An axial pattern flap incorporates an anatomically named vascular pedicle.
  • Axial pattern flaps derive their blood supply directly from this fasciocutaneous artery that runs beneath the flap's longitudinal axis. (Option A ruled out)
  • These arteries ensure blood supply to the subdermal plexus and guarantee blood supply to the flap.
  • It allows for a larger flap design compared to random pattern flaps and delivers better cosmetic results (Option B ruled out)

 

Examples of axial flaps include:

  • Deltopectoral flap (Option C ruled out)
  • Nasolabial flap off of the angular vessels
  • Paramedian forehead flap off of the supratrochlear vessels
  • Facial artery musculo-mucosal flap
  • Melolabial flap

questions.text: A 55-year-old male carpenter presents with symptoms of persistent nasal congestion, facial swelling, and occasional nasal bleeding. He has a long history of working in the hardwood furniture industry for 30 years. CT scan reveals findings, as shown in the image. Which type of carcinoma is he most at risk for?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Adenocarcinoma

 

Explanation:

  • Long-term exposure to hardwood dust has been linked to an increased risk of developing adenocarcinoma, particularly in the sinuses.
  • In contrast, exposure to softwood dust is more specifically associated with an increased risk of squamous cell carcinoma.

 

Neoplasms of Paranasal Sinuses:

1. Benign Neoplasms:

Osteomas
  • Frontal sinus (M/C), followed by ethmoid and maxillary sinuses.
  • Often asymptomatic; discovered incidentally on X-rays.

Fibrous Dysplasia
  • Mostly affects maxillary sinus
  • Causes Facial disfigurement, nasal obstruction, eye displacement

Ossifying Fibroma

Common in young adults & tumours are easily shellable.

Ameloblastoma (Adamantinoma)

Arises from odontogenic tissue, invades maxillary sinus.

Rare Tumors:

Inverted papilloma, Meningioma, and Hemangioma.

 

2. Malignant Neoplasms:

  • Common Sites: Maxillary (M/C), followed by ethmoid, frontal, and sphenoid sinuses.
  • Aetiology: Occupational Risks:
    • Wood dust impairs mucociliary clearance, increasing carcinogenic risk.
      • Hardwoods: Increase risk of adenocarcinoma.
      • Softwoods: Associated with squamous cell carcinoma (SCC).
    • Nickel Exposure: Increases the risk of sinonasal SCC by 250-fold.
    • Others: Chromium, Polycyclic Hydrocarbons, Aflatoxin, Mustard Gas

Squamous Cell Carcinoma (Option A): While SCC is the most common sinonasal malignancy overall, hardwood dust exposure specifically increases the risk for adenocarcinoma, not SCC.

Small Cell Carcinoma (Option C): Small cell carcinoma is a rare neuroendocrine tumor in this region and has no established occupational link to hardwood dust exposure.

Basal Cell Carcinoma (Option D): Basal cell carcinoma is primarily a skin cancer and is exceedingly rare in the sinonasal mucosa; it has no association with hardwood dust.

questions.text: A 34-year-old pregnant woman at 39 weeks gestation presents with severe abdominal pain, followed by per-vaginal bleeding. She reports a history of recent trauma after a car accident. The patient is not in labor. On physical examination, she is found to be unstable, and fetal heart rate monitoring shows fetal distress. Immediate resuscitation efforts are initiated. What is the definitive management for this case?

choices.text: Continue to observe and wait for normal vaginal delivery
Induction of labour by low rupture of membrane

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Immediate cesarean section

 

Explanation:

Given is a scenario of the revealed type of abruptio placentae. Fetal distress is an indication of Cesarean section in abruptio placentae.

 

Vaginal delivery is favoured in:
  1. Limited placental abruption.
  2. FHR tracing is reassuring.
  3. Facilities for continuous fetal monitoring are available.
  4. The prospect of vaginal delivery is soon.
  5. Placental abruption with a dead fetus.

Cesarean section is favoured in:
  1. Bleeding continues, and the placental abruption is greater than in Grade 1.
  2. Severe abruption with a live fetus.
  3. An amniotomy could not be done due to an unfavourable cervix.
  4. The prospect of immediate vaginal delivery is remote despite attempts.
  5. Amniotomy failed to control bleeding.
  6. Amniotomy failed to arrest the process of abruption, evidenced by rising fundal height or the appearance of adverse features (e.g., fetal distress, falling fibrinogen level, oliguria).

 Continue to observe and wait for normal vaginal delivery (Option A): It is incorrect because the mother is unstable and the fetus is in distress. Delaying delivery can worsen both maternal and fetal outcomes.
Observation is contraindicated in the setting of suspected abruption with hemodynamic compromise.

Induction of labour by low rupture of membrane (Option C): It is inappropriate in this setting. Labour induction takes time and is unsafe when:

  • There is maternal instability

  • Fetal distress is present

  • There is a need for urgent delivery

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with a 10-year history of type 2 diabetes mellitus presents to the clinic for a follow-up appointment. He is currently on metformin and glipizide but has not achieved adequate glycemic control. His HbA1c is 8.2%, and he experiences frequent episodes of postprandial hyperglycemia. The physician decides to initiate a basal-bolus insulin regimen. Which of the following insulin regimens would be most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Insulin glargine at bedtime and insulin lispro before meals.
Insulin detemir twice daily and insulin aspart before meals.
Insulin degludec once daily and regular insulin before meals.
NPH insulin twice daily and insulin glulisine before meals.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Insulin glargine at bedtime and insulin lispro before meals

Explanation:

Basal-Bolus Regimen:

  • Involves long-acting insulin once daily for basal coverage and rapid-acting insulin before meals for post-prandial glucose control.
  • Aimed at achieving round-the-clock euglycemia.
  • Long-Acting Insulin: Eg., Insulin glargine
    • Injected once daily, typically at bedtime.
    • Provides smooth, peakless basal insulin coverage.
  • Rapid-Acting Insulin: Eg., Insulin lispro or insulin aspart.
    • Injected 0–20 minutes before meals.
    • Provides postprandial insulin control.

Type of Insulin

Name of Insulin

Duration of Action

Properties

Long-acting

Glargine (Lantus)

12-24 hrs

Clear solution with a pH of 4.0 that stabilises the insulin hexamer; when injected into the neutral pH of the subcutaneous space, aggregation occurs, resulting in prolonged, predictable absorption from the injection site
 

Detemir

6-10 hrs

Modified by the addition of a saturated fatty acid to the ε amino group of LysB29, yielding myristoylated insulin that binds to albumin via its fatty acid chain when injected subcutaneously

Ultra-long acting

Degludec

>24 hrs

Forms multi hexamers after injection subcutaneously and is associated with less severe hypoglycemia than glargine

 

Insulin detemir twice daily and insulin aspart before meals (Option B): Less convenient due to twice daily basal dosing, though acceptable.

Insulin degludec once daily and regular insulin before meals (Option C): Regular insulin slower onset is less ideal for postprandial spikes.

NPH insulin twice daily and insulin glulisine before meals (Option D): NPH’s peak action increases hypoglycemia risk and less physiologic basal control.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presented to the clinic with painless nodular skin lesions on her cheeks and nose for the past three months which occasionally become tender and itchy on exposure to sunlight. She had intermittent episodes of dry cough, shortness of breath, and exercise intolerance. Chest X-ray revealed bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy. What is the most likely diagnosis
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Lupus pernio
Explanation:

The clinical presentation of reddish-purple nodules along with systemic illness suggests the diagnosis of Lupus pernio which is a chronic specific cutaneous manifestation of sarcoidosis, a multisystem granulomatous disorder.

Lupus Pernio:

  • It is characterized by the presence of violaceous infiltrative plaques with telangiectasia on the convexities of the face.
  • It is often associated with disorders of the upper respiratory tract and can also be associated with pulmonary fibrosis, chronic uveitis, and bony cysts, particularly affecting terminal phalanges.
  • Diagnosis can be made by classical clinical findings and histopathology showing non-caseating epithelioid cell granuloma.
  • Treatment involves topical and systemic steroids, hydroxychloroquine, and methotrexate.

Acne vulgaris (Option A)

  • It is a chronic inflammatory disease of the pilosebaceous unit.
  • The clinical lesions include non‐inflammatory open and closed comedones with or without papules, pustules, and nodules of varying degrees of inflammation and depth.
  • Treated with retinoids and antibiotics.

 

Rosacea (Option C)

  • Rosacea is a common chronic inflammatory condition marked by recurrent episodes of flushing, erythema, telangiectasia, papules, or pustules.
  • It primarily affects the nose, chin, cheeks, and forehead but spares the perioral area.
  • It is usually triggered by certain factors like environmental temperature and other dietary factors.

 

Lupus vulgaris (Option D)

  • It represents a chronic, progressive, paucibacillary variant of cutaneous tuberculosis.
  • The characteristic lesion manifests as a plaque, comprising soft, reddish-brown papules, exhibiting a diascopic appearance resembling apple jelly.

questions.text: A 36 year old woman undergoes an operative hysteroscopy. What early complication can be expected after this procedure?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Fluid overload

 

Explanation:

Fluid overload is an early complication of operative hysteroscopy.

 

Complications of operative hysteroscopy:

Early complications

Distention media related:

  • Fluid overload (Option A)
  • Hyponatremia
  • Gas embolism
  • Glycine toxicity

Operative:

  • Uterine perforation
  • Hemorrhage
  • Thermal burns
  • Infection

Late complications
  • Scar rupture in the next pregnancy (Option C)
  • Uterine adhesions (Option D)
  • Hematoma (Option B)
  • Post-ablation sterilization syndrome

questions.text:
A 65-year-old male presents with high pulse pressure. Histopathological examination is shown below. The arteries appear thickened, but there is no significant luminal narrowing. Which of the following conditions is the likely cause?



{{caption_text}}
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Monckeberg medial calcific sclerosis

Explanation:

  • Monckeberg medial calcific sclerosis, also known as calcific medial degeneration:
    • Calcific: Blue coloured dystrophic calcification due to old age.
    • Medial: Calcium is getting deposited into the tunica media of the blood vessel.
    • Degeneration: Degeneration occurring due to old age and not due to any pathology.
  • It is often asymptomatic and discovered incidentally in imaging studies such as X-rays or histopathological examinations.

Atherosclerosis (Option A): Due to hypercholesterolemia, and on HPE foam cells are seen in blood vessels.

Hyperplastic arteriosclerosis (Option C): Seen in malignant hypertension.

Hyaline arteriosclerosis (Option D): Seen in benign hypertension and diabetes.

questions.text: A patient presents with left-sided chest pain, which started 5 hours ago, radiating to the left arm and doesn’t get relieved on taking rest. An ECG is taken immediately which is given below. Which of the following is the drug for definitive management in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Reteplase

 

Explanation:

  • The above ECG shows ST-segment elevation in leads II, III, and aVF, which suggests ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI - inferior MI in this case).
  • Reperfusion should be the definitive treatment; hence, reteplase (thrombolytic) should be ideal.
  • Management of MI:

Definitive management

Reperfusion therapy:

  • Primary percutaneous coronary intervention: If it presents within 12 hours.
 

(door to balloon time <90 minutes)

 
  • Thrombolysis: If it presents more than 12 hours or has no access to PCI within 2 hours of presentation.
 
  • Recombinant tissue plasminogen activators: alteplase, reteplase, and tenecteplase.
 

(door to needle time <30 minutes)
