Nitroglycerin (Option A): Incorrect, as it provides symptomatic relief but does not reperfuse myocardium.

Aspirin & ticagrelor (Option C): Incorrect alone; they are adjunctive antiplatelet agents but do not restore vessel patency alone.

Morphine (Option D): Incorrect, as it only manages pain but does not affect the underlying occlusion.

questions.text: A 70-year-old male presents with an elevated PSA level of 12 ng/mL. A transrectal ultrasound-guided biopsy reveals a Gleason score of 9 (4 + 5). Which of the following is the most appropriate initial management approach for this patient?

choices.text: Active surveillance with regular PSA monitoring and repeat biopsies

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Hormone therapy and possibly radiation

 

Explanation:

  • A Gleason score of 9 (4 + 5) indicates a very high-grade and aggressive prostate cancer, likely to spread rapidly.
  • The elevated PSA level and high Gleason score suggest advanced disease.
  • Hormone therapy, which reduces or blocks testosterone, is a key treatment for advanced prostate cancer.
  • Radiation therapy may also be considered to control local disease.

 

Gleason

Score

Grade

Components

Cancer

Grade

Description

6

3 + 3

Low-grade

Cells resemble healthy tissue; low likelihood of growth and spread.

7

3 + 4 or 4 + 3

Intermediate-grade

Cells show more variation; moderate risk of growth and spread.

8

4 + 4, 3 + 5, or 5 + 3

High-grade

Cells look very different; higher likelihood of rapid growth and spread.

9 or 10

4 + 5, 5 + 4, or 5 + 5

Very high-grade

Cells are highly aggressive; very likely to grow and spread quickly.

 

Management Strategy

Key Points

Active Surveillance (Option A ruled out)

For low-risk cases; regular monitoring

Radical Prostatectomy (Option B ruled out)

Surgery for localized cancer; potentially curative

Radiation Therapy

High-energy rays; external or brachytherapy

Hormone Therapy (Option C)

Reduces/block testosterone; for advanced/metastatic cases

Chemotherapy

Systemic drug treatment; for advanced/metastatic cases

questions.text: All of the following are true regarding the usage of pessary in a prolapse patient except?

choices.text: Are a non-surgical option for managing pelvic organ prolapse.
Can be used as a temporary measure before surgical intervention.
Regular follow-up is not required once a pessary is adequately fitted.
Pessaries can be used to treat stress urinary incontinence.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Regular follow-up is not required once a pessary is adequately fitted.

Explanation:

Vaginal pessary

Types

Ring Pessary, Gellhorn Pessary, Donut Pessary.

Mechanism
  • Provides mechanical support to the pelvic organs
  • Helps with urinary and bowel symptoms

Conditions
  • Patients with complications (stress urinary incontinence, combined prolapse) (Option D)
  • Non-surgical management for inoperable cases (Option A)
  • Patients awaiting surgery (temporary relief) (Option B)
  • Prolapse in a pregnant female.

Disadvantages
  • Vaginal irritation, discharge, infection.
  • Pressure necrosis
  • Regular follow-up (Option C)

Contraindications
  • Active pelvic infection
  • Allergic reaction to material
  • Non-compliance with follow-up

Checking adequate retention of pessary:

  • One finger can be inserted between the vaginal side wall & edge of the pessary
  • Pessary should not descent down till introitus
  • VALSALVA / COUGH: Some descent of pessary is expected but it should return to its normal position.

questions.text: A multigravida G2P1L1 delivers a baby at 37 weeks of gestation by cesarean section. On assessment, the baby was completely cyanosed having slow and irregular breathing with a heart rate of 76 bpm, and he was showing slight flexion on stimulation along with a slight frown when stimulated by an orogastric tube. Calculate the APGAR score for the baby.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 4

 

Explanation: Completely cyanosed -0, slow and irregular breathing-1, HR of 76 bpm-1, slight flexion-1, slight frown-1 =4

APGAR score

  • The APGAR score is an objective method of evaluating the newborn’s condition.
  • It is performed at 1 minute and again at 5 minutes after birth.
  • Resuscitation must be initiated before the 1 minute score is assigned, therefore, it is not used to guide the resuscitation.
  • The components, along with scores, are,
 

0

1

2

Appearance

Completely blue or pale

The body is pink, and the extremities are blue

Completely pink

Pulse rate

Absent

<100/min

>100/min

Grimace

No response

Grimaces only

Coughs/sneezes

Activity

Limp and flaccid

Some flexion present

Flexed posture and actively moving limbs

Respiratory effort

None

Slow and irregular

Normal/strong

 

Interpretation:

  • Normal APGAR score is ≥7
  • Maximum score = 10; Minimum score = 0
  • Score for severe birth asphyxia = 0 - 3

 

Therefore, the APGAR score for the above case is 4. This indicates moderate distress at birth.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents to the emergency department 24 hours after a vaginal delivery with complaints of severe perineal pain and difficulty with bowel movements. Upon examination, a third-degree perineal tear is diagnosed. What is not done as the next step in management
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) immediate repair of the tear

Explanation:

For third-degree perineal tears presenting more than 24 hours after delivery, immediate repair is typically not recommended due to the increased risk of infection.

The appropriate management involves starting broad-spectrum antibiotics to prevent infection and planning for surgical repair after a three-month period.

Management:

  • Immediate Repair: After placenta delivery to reduce infection risk and blood loss.
  • Delayed Repair: If >24 hours, start antibiotics and wound care & plan for delayed repair (secondary repair) once the wound if free of exudate and infection.

Initiate broad-spectrum antibiotics (Option B): It is done in delayed presentation of third-degree tears to prevent or manage infection. Antibiotics cover common perineal flora and help reduce the risk of wound sepsis. 

Provide pain management & wound care (Option C): It is essential and appropriate in both immediate and delayed presentations. Wound care, sitz baths, analgesics, and stool softeners are standard supportive measures.

Plan for delayed repair (Option D): It is the appropriate course of action for tears diagnosed >24 hours after delivery. It allows inflammation to subside and ensures better healing conditions.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male is undergoing surgery and is given repeated doses of suxamethonium for muscle relaxation. After some time, his muscle response starts to fade despite continuous stimulation. This is most likely due to the development of a phase II block. Which of the following is not a characteristic feature of phase II block with suxamethonium?

choices.text: It is associated with a fade in muscle response during repetitive nerve stimulation
It can be influenced by prolonged exposure to suxamethonium
It responds predictably to cholinesterase inhibitors like neostigmine
Fast-twitch muscle fibres are more susceptible to phase II block than slow-twitch fibres

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) It responds predictably to cholinesterase inhibitors like neostigmine

Explanation:

The response to cholinesterase inhibitors is unpredictable and may even worsen the block.

 

Phase II Block (accommodation):

It occurs with continuous or repeated exposure to depolarizing muscle relaxants, particularly suxamethonium, and is characterised by a gradual fade in muscle response. (Option A ruled out)

Mechanisms Behind Phase II Block:

  • Prejunctional effects: High concentrations of suxamethonium can block prejunctional acetylcholine receptors (AChRs), affecting acetylcholine synthesis and release.
  • Postjunctional effects: Fade may also stem from changes in postjunctional AChR sensitivity or kinetics, resulting in reduced response despite the continued presence of the relaxant.

TOF of Phase II depolarizing block

 

Factors Influencing Phase II Block:

  • Duration of exposure: Prolonged exposure to suxamethonium increases the chance of developing Phase II block. (Option B ruled out)
  • Drug concentration: Higher suxamethonium concentrations make Phase II block more likely.
  • Muscle type: Fast-twitch muscle fibres are more susceptible to Phase II block than slow-twitch fibres. (Option D ruled out)
  • Interaction with other agents: Anesthetics or other drugs can affect the development of Phase II block.

Reversal of Phase II Block:

  • Cholinesterase inhibitors (e.g., neostigmine): Not recommended as the response is unpredictable and could worsen the block. (Option C).

questions.text:
Match the following with their correct answers.


	
		
			
			1
			
			
			C3a
			
			
			i
			
			
			Decay accelerating factor
			
		
		
			
			2
			
			
			C3b
			
			
			ii
			
			
			EBV receptor
			
		
		
			
			3
			
			
			CR2
			
			
			iii
			
			
			Anaphylatoxin
			
		
		
			
			4
			
			
			CD55
			
			
			iv
			
			
			Opsonin
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 1-iii, 2-iv, 3-ii, 4-i

Explanation:

  • Anaphylatoxins: C3a, C4a, and C5a.
  • Opsonins: C3b, C4b, and C5b.
    • Opsonins when coats the bacteria, makes it more tasty for phagocytosis.
    • Overall most important opsonin: IgG
    • Most important complement opsonin: C3b
  • CR2/CD21/C3d: Complement receptor 2 for EBV
    • When EBV enters the body, it attacks the B-cells.
    • To enter into B-cells, it uses CD21/CR2.
  • CD55: Decay-accelerating factor (DAF).
  • CD59: Membrane inhibitor of reactive lysis (MIRL)
    • Missing CD55 and CD59 leads to Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH).

questions.text: Worth's Four Dot Test for a 6 y/o child reveals that the child sees two red and three green lights as shown below in the image. Based on the test result, what is the most likely diagnosis in this child?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Diplopia

 

Explanation:

  • Seeing two red lights and three green lights on Worth's Four Dot Test indicates the presence of diplopia (double vision), where the patient perceives two distinct images due to misalignment.

 

Binocular Single Vision Tests

Name of the test

Procedure

Results

Worth’s Four Dot test


 
  • The patient wears a red lens on the right eye and a green lens on the left eye.
  • They are shown a box with four lights: one red, two green, and one white.
  • The patient is asked how many lights they see.
  • All four lights: BSV (binocular single vision). (Option A ruled out)
  • All four lights with manifest squint: Harmonious ARC (anomalous retinal correspondence).
  • Two red lights: Right eye suppression. (Option C ruled out)
  • Three green lights: Left eye suppression. (Option B ruled out)
  • Alternating red and green lights: Alternating suppression.
  • Two red and three green lights: Diplopia (double vision).(Option D)

questions.text: You are intern posted in ICU. Nurse calls you to assist for a sepsis patient whose ECG monitor is showing the following display and she has started chest compressions. Which of the following is the first step in managment of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is B: Defibrillation

  • ECG shows chaotic, irregular waveforms without distinct QRS complexes or P waves seen in ventricular fibrillation. This is a shockable rythm 
  • Immediate defibrillation is the primary treatment to restore a normal heart rhythm

questions.text: A 59-year-old male with T2N2bM0 squamous cell carcinoma of the buccal mucosa underwent surgery. The postoperative histopathology report reveals close surgical margin (< 5 mm) and extracapsular extension in two lymph nodes. What is the most appropriate adjuvant treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Concurrent chemoradiotherapy

 

Explanation:

  • Concurrent chemoradiotherapy is the most appropriate adjuvant treatment for this patient due to the presence of high-risk features: close surgical margins and extracapsular extension (ECE) in lymph nodes.
  • In this case, the close margin and ECE in multiple nodes warrant the addition of chemotherapy to radiotherapy to improve locoregional control and overall survival.

 

Indications for Adjuvant Therapy:

 

Therapy

Indications

Radiotherapy alone

Intermediate risk features:

  • T3 or T4a primary tumors
  • N2 or N3 nodal disease (without extracapsular extension)
  • Perineural invasion
  • Lymphovascular invasion
  • Single node >3 cm or multiple positive nodes
  • Close margins (between 5mm and 1cm)

Concurrent chemoradiotherapy

High-risk features:

  • Positive surgical margins
  • Extracapsular extension of nodal disease
  • T4b tumors
  • N3 nodal disease
  • Multiple positive nodes with extracapsular extension

Specific indications
  • pT3 or pT4 primary tumors
  • N2 or N3 neck disease
  • Perineural invasion
  • Vascular embolism
  • Lymphatic invasion

Considerations for chemotherapy addition
  • Age <70 years
  • Good performance status
  • No significant comorbidities

questions.text: A 50 y/o man presents with severe epigastric pain radiating to the back for the past two days. His serum lipase is elevated to five times the normal limit. An abdominal X-ray shows a dilated loop of small intestine near the pancreas. Which of the following is the most likely imaging sign observed on the X-ray in this patient?
questions.solution:
The patient’s clinical presentation of severe epigastric pain radiating to the back and elevated lipase levels strongly suggests acute pancreatitis. Sentinel loop sign is a classic X-ray finding in acute pancreatitis, showing a dilated loop of the small intestine near the pancreas due to localized ileus caused by the inflammation.

Acute Pancreatitis

Clinical Diagnosis (Requires 2 of 3):

  1. Abdominal pain is strongly suggestive of acute pancreatitis.
  2. Serum amylase and/or lipase level at least 3 times the upper limit of normal.
  3. Imaging findings characteristic of acute pancreatitis.

 

X-ray Features

 

• Sentinel loop sign (Option C): 

◦ Dilated loop of small intestine near the inflamed pancreas due to localized ileus.

◦ Significance: Early indicator of acute pancreatitis on X-ray.

Sentinel loop sign

• Colon cut-off sign: 

◦ Abrupt termination of gas in the colon at the splenic flexure, with collapsed distal colon loops.

◦ Significance: Suggests localized pancreatic inflammation, causing colonic spasm as an indirect sign of acute pancreatitis

Investigations of Choice:

  • Contrast-enhanced CT (CECT): Primary tool for assessing pancreatic necrosis, peripancreatic inflammation, fluid collections, and complications.
    • Most reliable for staging and detecting complications.
    • May underestimate necrosis if done in the first 24 hours.

Morphological Types (Revised Atlanta Classification 2008):

  1. Interstitial oedematous pancreatitis:: Mild form with pancreatic oedema and swelling but no necrosis.
  2. Necrotising pancreatitis: Severe form involving pancreatic parenchymal necrosis, associated with higher morbidity and mortality.

Colon cut-off sign (Option A): Seen in acute pancreatitis, it indicates abrupt gas cut-off in the colon at the splenic flexure but doesn't explain small intestine dilation abdominal X-ray findings.

Pneumoperitoneum (Option B): Refers to free air under the diaphragm, often due to bowel perforation, and is not linked to acute pancreatitis.

Ground-glass opacity (Option D): Typically seen in lung imaging (e.g., pneumonia, ARDS), not related to pancreatitis or abdominal X-ray findings.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman from a rural area has nasal obstruction, crusting, and a history of progressive nasal swelling over the past several months. On examination, nodular masses in the nasal cavity are noted. A biopsy is done and shown below. Which of the following histopathological findings is characteristic of the condition in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Mikulicz cells

 

Explanation:

  • The clinical presentation of nasal obstruction, crusting, and progressive nodular nasal swelling is most consistent with rhinoscleroma.
  • It is caused by the bacteria Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis.
  • Mikulicz cells are large, foamy histiocytes filled with bacteria, which are characteristic of Rhinoscleroma.

 

Diagnosis of Rhinoscleroma:

  • Confirmatory diagnosis is done by biopsy
  • On biopsy/ HPE:
    • Infiltration of submucosa with plasma cells, lymphocytes, eosinophils, Mikulicz cells, and Russell bodies.
    • Mikulicz cells: Large foamy cells with a central nucleus and vacuolated cytoplasm containing bacilli.
    • Russell bodies: Eosinophilic inclusions in plasma cells. It forms due to the accumulation of immunoglobulins secreted by the plasma cells.

  • Culture from the biopsy

 

Psammoma Bodies (Option A): These are concentric, laminated calcifications often seen in certain tumors, such as papillary thyroid carcinoma, serous papillary ovarian carcinoma, meningioma, and mesotheliomas. They are not characteristic of rhinoscleroma.

Aschoff Bodies (Option C): These are specific granulomatous lesions found in the myocardium in cases of acute rheumatic fever. They are not associated with nasal pathology or rhinoscleroma.

Verocay Bodies (Option D): These are palisading arrangements of Schwann cells and nuclei within Antoni A areas of schwannomas (neurilemomas), often appearing as alternating cellular and anuclear zones. They are a feature of neural sheath tumors, not infectious granulomas like rhinoscleroma.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man is found dead at home and poisoning is suspected. During the autopsy, the forensic pathologist decides to dissect the stomach to examine its contents. Which of the following is the most appropriate procedure for stomach dissection to preserve evidence of poisoning and ensure accurate forensic analysis?

choices.text: Open the stomach along the greater curvature and discard the contents
Open the stomach along the lesser curvature and collect the contents for toxicology
Open the stomach along the greater curvature and collect the contents for toxicology
Incise the stomach along the pylorus and drain the contents into the small intestine

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Open the stomach along the greater curvature and collect the contents for toxicology

 

Explanation:

  • In forensic autopsies, the stomach is usually opened along the greater curvature to minimize disruption of stomach anatomy and allows the pathologist to collect and examine the stomach contents effectively, which is critical in cases of suspected poisoning.

 

Procedure for Stomach Dissection:

  1. Two ligatures are applied at the cardiac end of the esophagus and two ligatures are below the pyloric end of the stomach.
  2. The stomach is removed by cutting between the double ligatures at both ends.
  3. The stomach is then opened along the greater curvature.
  4. The mucous membrane is examined for the presence of any stains, congestion, hemorrhage, desquamation, ulceration, sloughing, or perforation.
  5. The contents of the stomach are noted with respect to quantity, nature of material/food, state of digestion, color, and smell.

 

Open the stomach along the greater curvature and discard the contents (Option A): This is incorrect. While opening along the greater curvature is common for ease of access, discarding the contents is completely inappropriate when poisoning is suspected. The stomach contents are crucial evidence for toxicological analysis.

Open the stomach along the lesser curvature and collect the contents for toxicology (Option B): This is generally considered less ideal than opening along the greater curvature. Opening along the lesser curvature can make it more difficult to fully visualize and collect all the contents due to the anatomical folds and the proximity of blood vessels and nerves. However, collecting the contents is the correct step for toxicology.

Incise the stomach along the pylorus and drain the contents into the small intestine (Option D): This is incorrect and would contaminate other parts of the digestive tract. Draining the contents into the small intestine would mix the gastric contents with intestinal contents, making toxicological analysis much more complicated and potentially diluting or altering the evidence. It would also lead to loss of the isolated gastric contents as evidence.

questions.text: A body has been presented to the forensic department for autopsy, exhibiting typically visible post-mortem changes given below as an image, including blanching and a shift of pattern occurring upon handling and moving the body. Based on these observations, what is the approximate time of death?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Within 4 hours

 

Explanation:

  • Post-mortem lividity generally begins to appear within 1-4 hours after death, as blood settles in dependent parts of the body, creating reddish-purple discoloration.
  • The presence of blanching indicates that the blood remains fluid and has not yet clotted.
  • Additionally, the ability to shift the lividity pattern upon handling suggests that it is not fixed, which typically occurs after 6 to 12 hours.
  • Therefore, these observations indicate that the time of death is approximately within 4 hours.

 

Appearance of Hypostasis

Onset

Begins approximately 30 minutes after death. Initially unfixed and can shift with body position changes.

Visibility

Becomes visibly apparent within 4 hours and reaches maximum intensity between 6-12 hours.

Fixation

Typically it becomes fixed by around 8 hours (between 6-12 hours). Staining won't move after fixation.

Confirmation Test

Apply pressure to the area:

 
  • Blanching indicates blood is still within vessels, staining is not yet fixed.
  • No blanching means staining is fixed, indicating breakdown of vessels and leakage into tissues.

 

Immediately after death (Option A): Livor mortis typically starts 30 minutes to 2 hours after death, so it wouldn't be "immediately after death" if blanching and shifting are observed.

After 12 hours (Option C): By 12 hours, livor mortis is usually fixed and would not blanch or shift significantly upon repositioning.

After 24 hours (Option D): At 24 hours, livor mortis is fully fixed and non-blanching, and rigor mortis would also be fully established and potentially receding, with decomposition changes beginning.

questions.text: A 68 year old male with atrial fibrillation, on chronic warfarin therapy for stroke prevention, is scheduled for elective hip replacement surgery. How many days prior to the surgery should the warfarin be stopped?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 2-5 days

 

Explanation:

Warfarin should be stopped 5 days before elective surgery to allow INR to fall below 1.5, minimising bleeding risk.

INR is reassessed before surgery to ensure it is safe to proceed.

Bridging anticoagulation (e.g., with LMWH) is considered for patients at high thromboembolic risk.

 

Medication

Continue or stop preoperatively

Oral Anticoagulants
  • Stop 2-5 days prior to noncardiac surgery
  • Continue in high-patient risk (e.g., high-risk mechanical valves)

Aspirin

  • Low-dose aspirin (75–100 mg/day): Often continued perioperatively in patients with high cardiovascular risk (e.g., recent stent).

  • High-dose aspirin (>300 mg/day): Typically stopped 7–10 days prior to surgery due to higher bleeding risk.

  • Decision to continue or stop aspirin depends on bleeding risk of surgery vs thrombotic risk of the patient.

Statins
  • Continue

Thienopyridines (e.g., Clopidogrel)
  • Discontinue 2 weeks before surgery

 

Note: Incase of a patient with coronary stent:

  • Aspirin should be continued
  • P2Y12 Inhibitors (e.g., clopidogrel, ticagrelor, prasugrel) should be discontinued

 

1 day (Option B): IToo short. INR would still be elevated, increasing bleeding risk.

7 days (Option C): Longer than needed in most cases; not routinely necessary.

10 days (Option D): Excessively long and may unnecessarily increase thrombotic risk.
